column3: `Plugin Container for Firefox has stopped working` after driver.quit()
column4: Windows 7 Python 27 Selenium 3.0.2 Firefox 49 example code: ``` from selenium import webdriver from selenium.webdriver.firefox.firefox_binary import FirefoxBinary import os   # check gecko is in PATH gecko_path = 'C:\\Program Files\\Geckodriver\\' if 'Geckodriver' not in os.environ['PATH']:     os.environ['PATH'] += os.pathsep + gecko_path    profile = webdriver.FirefoxProfile() firefox_path = 'C:\\Program Files\\Mozilla Firefox\\firefox.exe' binary = FirefoxBinary(firefox_path)  driver = webdriver.Firefox(firefox_binary=binary, firefox_profile=profile) driver.get("http://www.python.org") driver.quit() ``` `Plugin Container for Firefox has stopped working` get this error from `werfault.exe` after calling .quit() on driver renaming or deleting plugin-container hangs Firefox upon next execution fault module name: `mozglue.dll`  tested also on Firefox 50, 51 which doesn't have Plugin Container error message,  but crash nonetheless with same fault module name.  driver.close() not working  also tried killing manually by pid, but can't get pid of firefox, since driver.binary doesn't seem to have `.process`: `driver.binary.process` throws error `AttributeError: 'FirefoxBinary' object has no attribute 'process'` `driver.binary.profile` throws error `AttributeError: 'FirefoxBinary' object has no attribute 'profile'`

column3: Code review: SelectByText promises to substring match, but match is on exact text
column4: While investigating an issue where certain text does not get selected, I encountered the following on the [**dotnet** branch](selenium/dotnet/src/support/UI/SelectElement.cs):  In the currect version, the method `SelectElement.SelectByText(string text)` promises to select the text on substring match:  ```         /// The text of the option to be selected. If an exact match is not found,         /// this method will perform a substring match. ```  but when I am looking in how the item(s) to select are picked from a list of candidates, the text from a select node is compared to the literal text:  ```    foreach (IWebElement option in candidates)                 {                     if (text == option.Text)   // <-- literal match                     {                         SetSelected(option, true); //... ```  Do you agree that this is indeed an issue?

column3: Missing Methods in WindowUtils class in new Release of Selenium(3.2.0)
column4: while in earlier Releases of Selenium I used to use methods like  WindowsUtils.readIntRegistryValue(location); and  WindowsUtils.writeIntRegistryValue(location, 0);  to read and write to Window Registery.     As I transit from earlier releases to new Release 3.2; to my surprise these methods were missing in new release of selenium.  Kindly mention the alternate that has replaced those methods or the strategy to perform tasks such as reading and writing to Window Registery in selenium 3.1 and Selenium 3.2.

column3: Release prereleases of selenium-webdriver as @next, not @latest
column4: When you call `npm install selenium-webdriver` you'll get `3.0.0-beta-3`. `npm install selenium-webdriver` is equivalent to `npm install selenium-webdriver@latest`. I'd expect to get the latest _stable_ release here. To publish unstable prereleases like `3.0.0-beta-3` you'd probably use the `@next` tag. If you want  `3.0.0-beta-3` you would call `npm install selenium-webdriver@next`. More information [here](https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/tag#purpose).  I struggled here, because I installed `selenium-webdriver` and got `Error: The geckodriver executable could not be found on the current PATH. Please download the latest version from https://github.com/mozilla/geckodriver/releases/WebDriver and ensure it can be found on your PATH.` Maybe it would be good too not just link to `geckodriver`, but also pass a link which explains the differences between 2.x and 3.x and the motivation behind the change.  While the stack trace of this error helped me to find out that it was thrown by `selenium-webdriver` in the first place, IMHO I prefer to use `throw 'foo'` here instead of `throw new Error('foo')` _when_ `"foo"` is descriptive enough to tell me _who_ throws the error and _why_ this error is thrown. I expect a stack trace for more "unintentional" errors.

column3: Selenium raises uninformative error when connection fails.
column4: When using Selenium with Appium, I received an error message which I found very uninformative. What had happened is that my code had a race condition. A script manually started the Appium server, and then immediately after, some tests ran using it. Raising an error here makes sense, and the fault was not with Selenium.  However, this is the error Selenium raised:  `INFO:remote_connection.py::__init__:Could not get IP address for host: 127.0.0.1`  It seems to be raised from here: https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/py/selenium/webdriver/remote/remote_connection.py#L189  I think this message is very uninformative. There was no difference in behaviour when substituting `127.0.0.1` for `localhost`.   Reporting the above message when that makes sense is fine, however, in this case, since the issue is that Selenium couldn't connect on the port and IP, the error message should indicate that.  ## Meta -  OS:   OSX Darwin 15.6.0 Darwin Kernel Version 15.6.0: Mon Aug 29 20:21:34 PDT 2016; root:xnu-3248.60.11~1/RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64 Selenium Version:   2.53.6 Browser:   N/A ## Expected Behavior -  An error message indicating that the connection is failed is raised, which helps a user to understand what the problem is. ## Actual Behavior -  Selenium raises the above error, which seems quite misleading. ## Steps to reproduce -  Create an Appium server instance, and connect to it immediately (within 1 second).  Thank you for your consideration.

column3: Selenium 3.0 does not run on firefox on the grid
column4: When I run my scripts using Selenium 3.0 on the grid, only firefox instances open and nothing happens.  My setup is like this: Selenium - 3.0.0  Selenium Grid - hub and node started using Selenium 3.0.0 and with below options:  hub - java -jar selenium-server-standalone.jar -role hub -timeout 300000  node - java -Dwebdriver.gecko.driver=C:\Grid2\geckodriver-v0.11.1-win64\geckodriver.exe -jar selenium-server-standalone.jar -role node -hub http://localhost:4444/grid/register -port 5556 -nodeConfig se2config.txt  se2config.txt contents -  {    "capabilities":   [     {       "browserName": "firefox",       "maxInstances": 1,       "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"     },     {       "browserName": "chrome",       "maxInstances": 1,       "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"     },     {       "browserName": "internet explorer",       "maxInstances": 1,       "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"     }   ],   "proxy": "org.openqa.grid.selenium.proxy.DefaultRemoteProxy",   "maxSession": 1,   "port": 5556,   "register": true,   "registerCycle": 5000,   "hub": "http://localhost:4444",   "nodeStatusCheckTimeout": 5000,   "nodePolling": 5000,   "role": "node",   "unregisterIfStillDownAfter": 60000,   "downPollingLimit": 2,   "debug": false,   "servlets" : [],   "withoutServlets": [],   "custom": {}     }  Firefox version - 47.0.2  Added geckodriver.exe path to PATH variable and also in the code using:      System.setProperty("webdriver.gecko.driver","")  The scripts run fine locally, but when run on the grid, it just launches the firefox browser and does not do anything. column3: .NET bindings - Actions.Perform() is broken for a wrapped IWebDriver that implements IHasInputDevices in Selenium 3.0
column4: We have a WebDriverWrapper class that is implementing IHasInputDevices (since this used to be a requirement with Selenium 2.0)  As a result, in the constructor of Actions(), our wrapped driver is being saved as the driver for the Actions instance. This is causing .Perform() to throw a NullReferenceException since it tries to cast the wrapped driver object to IActionExecutor, which fails, and then on the following line checks "if (actionExecutor.IsActionExecutor)"  This is not a critical issue since we can work around the problem by removing IHasInputDevices from our wrapper and adding IWrapsDriver , but is still inconvenient.

column3: JavaScript bindings for Chrome network emulation
column4: Update WebDriverJS to support the Chrome debugging protocol functionality for getting and setting network emulation settings.  This functionality was added to ChromeDriver in March of 2015 (https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src.git/+/12a55ff7369b35adb29cd28f5e3dd4ef923e3e6c), but hasn't been implemented in the JavaScript bindings.  Example script using this functionality: var webdriver = require('selenium-webdriver');  var driver = new webdriver.Builder() .forBrowser('chrome') .build();  var latency = 5; var throughput = 500 * 1024; driver.setNetworkConditions(latency, throughput, throughput) .then(() => driver.getNetworkConditions()) .then(network => { console.log(network); driver.get('https://fast.com/'); }) // once selenium disconnects from remote debugging protocol, // emulation settings are discarded .then(() => driver.sleep(60000));  - [X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: C# implementation of RemoteWebDriver fails to install Chrome extension
column4: This ticket is related to [ticket 1578](https://github.com/seleniumhq/selenium/issues/1578), but my issue is with Chrome and not Firefox as in that ticket.  Installing and configuring an extension works when using a local driver. Doing the same using the C# implementation of RemoteWebDriver does not. Tested this with Chrome.  In my test case, the remote execution was done against SauceLabs. Contacted their support and they verified that installing extensions via RemoteWebDriver works in the JAVA implementation, but fails using the C# implementation.   To quote from their support ticket:  "I tried this myself and I was running into issues on my own end, so this may be a flaw with the C# Selenium bindings with RemoteWebDriver."  This is my code.   ` private IWebDriver GetSauceLabsDriver()         {  ```         var outPutDirectory = Path.GetDirectoryName(Assembly.GetExecutingAssembly().Location);         ChromeOptions options = new ChromeOptions();         options.AddExtensions(outPutDirectory + @"\3.1.3_0.crx");         //DesiredCapabilities caps = (DesiredCapabilities)options.ToCapabilities();         var caps = new DesiredCapabilities();         caps.SetCapability(ChromeOptions.Capability, options.Extensions[0]);         caps.SetCapability(CapabilityType.BrowserName, "chrome");         caps.SetCapability(CapabilityType.Version, "53.0");         caps.SetCapability(CapabilityType.Platform, "Windows 10");         caps.SetCapability("deviceName", "");         caps.SetCapability("deviceOrientation", "");         caps.SetCapability("username", "kin");         caps.SetCapability("accessKey", "9cd6-438e-8d58-a9635b70953d");         caps.SetCapability("name", TestContext.CurrentContext.Test.Name);          return new RemoteWebDriver(new Uri("http://ondemand.saucelabs.com:80/wd/hub"), caps,             TimeSpan.FromSeconds(600));     }` ```  OS:   Windows 10 Selenium Version:  2.53.1 Browser:  Chrome Browser Version:  53.0 ## Expected Behavior -  Chrome extension is added to the RemoteDriver ## Actual Behavior -  Chrome extension is not added to the RemoteDriver ## Steps to reproduce -

column3: [py] remove blank lines so flake8 passes
column4: This PR removes some extra blank lines in python test files.  These blank lines were causing `flake8` linting errors, which caused travis-ci python builds to go red.  With this change, `flake8` runs clean against the /py/ files.  - [X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: [py] fix shutdown and process termination
column4: This PR addresses 2 issues with how webdriver stops services from the python bindings.  1. Changes the order of events to stop a process.  Previously. the order was `terminate()`->`kill()`->`wait()`.  So... it would send a SIGTERM signal to the process, immediately followed by a SIGKILL signal.  Since `wait()` is called after the process has already been forcefully stopped, there is nothing to wait on, so it does nothing.  The proper sequence should be:  `terminate()`->`wait()`->`kill()`.  That will send a SIGINT, wait for graceful process termination, then send a SIGKILL to forcefully stop it as a last resort.  2. ~~Removes the `__del__()` method from the `Service()` class.  The existence of this method is causing #3216.  Using `__del__()` to call `stop()` is unreliable and not a good idea in Python. The proper way to stop the service is to explicitly call the `stop()` method~~  2. Add a try/except inside `__del__()` so inconsequential exceptions arent displayed  ----  - [X ] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: [rb] move driver related functionality to Service classes
column4: This moves extraction of service arguments out of Bridge classes and into Service classes where they belong.  Additionally, in an attempt to better control / make more uniform what gets passed in directly to driver initialization, this creates `#driver_opts` for specifying switches by hash instead of an array of strings.  This code is backward compatible, but throws warnings for the outdated means of interacting with the driver. I contemplated requiring `:port` & `:driver_path` parameters to also go into the `:driver_opts` hash, but since every `Bridge` accepts these, I've leaned toward it not being necessary to deprecate current behavior.

column3: FluentWait should provide wait while semantics for code clarity.
column4: This issue is regarding the API, so not specific to a single platform or version.  ## Actual Behaviour  Currently the interface to **FluentWait** provides _wait until_ semantics, e.g.  `wait.until(isTrue)`  In some situation this can lead to opaque semantics, and double negative conditions which reduces clarity and increases complexity.  `webDriverWait.until(!ExpectedConditionsvisibilityOf(webElement));`  `webDriverWait.until(ExpectedConditions.not(ExpectedConditions.visibilityOf(webElement)));`  ## Desired Behaviour -  The could be easily be improved with `wait while` semantics, e.g.  wait.while(isTrue)

column3: Grid Hub and Nodes stops after a node is turned off or cable unplugged
column4: This issue is a duplication of one opened in appium https://github.com/appium/appium/issues/6360#issuecomment-269289130  Hello guys!  I facing a problem that I presume could be a bug. I have a lot of devices in a grid (12), but it occurs with two or more devices.  **Configs (for testing propouse)** - Selenium/Appium grid with a hub and node in same machine - Nodes correctly configured (udid, appium post and bp port always unique)  **Scenario** - Same app executing in parallel through separated threads  **Action** - After the test execution in the devices I can do two things to throw the error: - *\* Power off the device - *\* Unplug the USB cable - *\* [For emulator] Close the window of emulator  **Versions** - Selenium Server 2.53.0 - Appium 1.5.1  *_Error *_ _on console (Eclipse)_ `org.openqa.selenium.WebDriverException: An unknown server-side error occurred while processing the command. Original error: UiAUtomator shut down unexpectedly (WARNING: The server did not provide any stacktrace information)`  _on node closed_ `Unhandled rejection Error: No device connected, cannot run adb shell command "am force-stop com.eliasnogueira.buttontest"`  _on the other nodes_ `Unhandled rejection Error: Error executing adbExec. Original error: Command '/Users/eliasnogueira/android-sdk/platform-tools/adb -P 5037 -s 192.168.56.102:5555 shell am force-stop com.eliasnogueira.buttontest' exited with code 255{"stdout":"","stderr":"error: device '192.168.56.102:5555' not found\n","code":255}`  **What I expect** Not stop the Grid after the node stop (shutdown or unplug cable)  Full logs attached. column3: Tests: executing JavaScript before a page is loaded
column4: This is related to the Selenium test suite.  Regarding PageLoadingTest.[testShouldDoNothingIfThereIsNothingToGoBackTo()](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/java/client/test/org/openqa/selenium/PageLoadingTest.java#L277) and ExecutingJavascriptTest.[testShouldThrowExceptionIfExecutingOnNoPage()](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/java/client/test/org/openqa/selenium/ExecutingJavascriptTest.java#L499)  The first one:  1. Calls `driver.getWindowHandles()` 2. Executes JavaScript 3. Is expected to succeed  The second one:  1. Executes JavaScript 2. Is expected to fail   I guess they are contradicting, or `driver.getWindowHandles()` is expected to allow execution of JavaScript somehow.  This is needed to make the `HtmlUnitDriver` pass for both.  Appreciate your feedback.

column3: Introduce marks for xfailing tests against specific drivers
column4: This is not intended for merging as is, but I'd like to get some feedback from pytest devs (maybe @RonnyPfannschmidt and @The-Compiler) as this is currently using pytest internals and I'm wondering if there's a better approach. Basically this allows us to mark tests as expected to fail based on the value of a parameter for a fixture. Rather than an imperative xfail, this allows tests to run to completion, and therefore also allows them to xpass. /cc @AutomatedTester

column3: [rb] Initial implementation of Logger class
column4: This is initial and dead simple implementation of Logger for Ruby.  Apart from obvious `logger.debug` calls, it takes all the output from child processes allowing to write them to log as well.  By default, it writes log to a tempfile (though doesn't unlink it after) which means it's silent unless you tell it to write to a known location or standard output:  ```ruby Selenium::WebDriver::Logger.io = STDOUT # or File.open Selenium::WebDriver::Logger.level = Logger::DEBUG # or any other level ```  There is still a lot to wrap here, but I'd like to hear your thoughts on this.

column3: Standalone server does not start Firefox with the right profile
Chromedriver does not support keep-alive connections
column4: This is an informational ticket which may be closed, but may serve to aid others running into the same issue. ## Meta -  OS:   Ubuntu Selenium Version:   2.53.1 Browser:   Chrome ## Expected Behavior -  When Chrome webdriver makes a request to Chromedriver, the underlying tcp connection should be re-used. As indicated by "keep_alive=True" ## Actual Behavior -  Chromedriver does not support persistent connections and each new command execution will open a new connection to the chromedriver server.  See https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromedriver/issues/detail?id=1529  This can lead to port exhaustion, client crash, and a stacktrace similar to this:    File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 461, in execute_script     {'script': script, 'args':converted_args})['value']   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 231, in execute     response = self.command_executor.execute(driver_command, params)   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/remote_connection.py", line 395, in execute     return self._request(command_info[0], url, body=data)   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/remote_connection.py", line 425, in _request     self._conn.request(method, parsed_url.path, body, headers)   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/httplib.py", line 983, in request     self._send_request(method, url, body, headers)   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/httplib.py", line 1017, in _send_request     self.endheaders(body)   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/httplib.py", line 979, in endheaders     self._send_output(message_body)   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/httplib.py", line 839, in _send_output     self.send(msg)   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/httplib.py", line 801, in send     self.connect()   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/httplib.py", line 782, in connect     self.timeout, self.source_address)   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/socket.py", line 571, in create_connection     raise err socket.error: [Errno 99] Cannot assign requested address

column3: Deprecate and remove the WebDriverJS promise manager
column4: This is a tracking bug for deprecating and removing the promise manager used by WebDriverJS. ## Background  WebDriverJS is an asynchronous API, where every command returns a promise. This can make even the simplest WebDriver scripts very verbose. Consider the canonical "Google search" test:  ``` js let driver = new Builder().forBrowser('firefox').build(); driver.get('http://www.google.com/ncr')     .then(_ => driver.findElement(By.name('q')))     .then(q => q.sendKeys('webdriver'))     .then(_ => driver.findElement(By.name('btnG')))     .then(btnG => btnG.click())     .then(_ => driver.wait(until.titleIs('webdriver - Google Search'), 1000))     .then(_ => driver.quit(), e => {       console.error(e);       driver.quit();     }); ```  WebDriverJS uses a [promise manager](http://seleniumhq.github.io/selenium/docs/api/javascript/module/selenium-webdriver/lib/promise.html) that tracks command execution, allowing tests to be written as if they were using a synchronous API:  ``` js let driver = new Builder().forBrowser('firefox').build(); driver.get('http://www.google.com/ncr'); driver.findElement(By.name('q')).sendKeys('webdriver'); driver.findElement(By.name('btnG')).click(); driver.wait(until.titleIs('webdriver - Google Search'), 1000); driver.quit(); ```  The original goal for the promise manager was to make it easier to read and reason about a test's intent. Unfortunately, any benefits on this front come at the cost of increased implementation complexity and reduced debuggabilityâ€”in the example above, inserting a break point before the first `findElement` call will break before the `findElement` command is _scheduled_. To break before the command actually _executes_, you would have to modify the test to break in a callback to the `driver.get()` command:  ``` js let driver = new Builder().forBrowser('firefox').build(); driver.get('http://www.google.com/ncr').then(_ => debugger); driver.findElement(By.name('q')).sendKeys('webdriver'); ```  To help with debugging, tests can be written with generators and WebDriver's `promise.consume` function (or equivalent, from libraries like [task.js](http://taskjs.org/)). These libraries are "promise aware": if a generator yields a promise, the library will defer calling `next()` until the promise has resolved (if the promise is rejected, the generator's `throw()` function will be called with the rejection reason). While users will have to make liberal use of the `yield` keyword, they can use this strategy to write "synchronous" tests with predictable breakpoints.  ``` js const {Builder, By, promise, until} = require('selenium-webdriver');  let result = promise.consume(function* doGoogleSearch() {   let driver = new Builder().forBrowser('firefox').build();   yield driver.get('http://www.google.com/ncr');   yield driver.findElement(By.name('q')).sendKeys('webdriver');   yield driver.findElement(By.name('btnG')).click();   yield driver.wait(until.titleIs('webdriver - Google Search'), 1000);   yield driver.quit(); });  result.then(_ => console.log('SUCCESS!'), e => console.error('FAILURE: ' + e)); ```  The need to use `promise.consume`/task.js will be eliminated in [TC39](http://tc39.github.io/ecmascript-asyncawait/) with the introduction of async functions:  ``` js async function doGoogleSearch() {   let driver = new Builder().forBrowser('firefox').build();   await driver.get('http://www.google.com/ncr');   await driver.findElement(By.name('q')).sendKeys('webdriver');   await driver.findElement(By.name('btnG')).click();   await driver.wait(until.titleIs('webdriver - Google Search'), 1000);   await driver.quit(); }  doGoogleSearch()     .then(_ => console.log('SUCCESS!'), e => console.error('FAILURE: ' + e)); ```  Given that the JavaScript language continues to evolve with more support for asynchronous programming (and promises in particular), the benefits to WebDriver's promise manager no longer outweigh the costs. Therefore, we will be deprecating the promise manager and eventually removing it in favor of native language constructs. ## Deprecation Plan ### Phase 1: allow users to opt-out of the promise manager  Estimated date: now (selenium-webdriver@3.0) 1. Within `selenium-webdriver`, replace all hard dependencies on the `selenium-webdriver/promise.ControlFlow` class with a new interface: `selenium-webdriver/promise.Scheduler`.        ``` js    /** @interface */    class Scheduler {     execute(fn) {}     timeout(ms) {}     wait(condition, opt_timeout) {}    }    ``` 2. Add a Scheduler implementation that executes everything immediately using native Promises.        ``` js    /** @implements {Scheduler} */    class SimpleScheduler {     /** @override */ execute(fn) {       return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {         try {           resolve(fn());         } catch (ex) {           reject(ex);         }       });     }         /** @override */ timeout(ms) {       return new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(_ => resolve(), ms));     }         /** @override */ wait(condition, opt_timeout) {       // Implementation omitted for brevity     }    }    ``` 3. Introduce the `SELENIUM_PROMISE_MANAGER` environment variable. When set to 1, `selenium-webdriver` will use the existing `ControlFlow` scheduler. When set to 0, the `SimpleScheduler` will be used.        When `SELENIUM_PROMISE_MANAGER=0`, any attempts to use the `ControlFlow` class will trigger an error. This will help users catch any unexpected direct dependencies. This will also impact the use of the `promise.Deferred` and `promise.Promise` classes, as well as the `promise.fulfilled()` and `promise.rejected()` functions, which all have a hard dependency on the control flow. Users should use the native equivalents.        At this point, `SELENIUM_PROMISE_MANAGER` will default to 1, preserving existing functionality. ### Phase 2: opt-in to the promise manager  Estimated date: October 2017, Node 8.0  Following the release of a Node LTS that contains async functions, change the `SELENIUM_PROMISE_MANAGER` default value to 0. Users must explicitly set this environment variable to continue using the ControlFlow scheduler. ### Phase 3: removing the promise manager  Estimated date: October 2018, Node 10.0  On the release of the _second_ major Node LTS with async functions, the ControlFlow class and all related code will be removed. The `SELENIUM_PROMISE_MANAGER` environment variable will no longer have any effect.

column3: Fix issue 2950
column4: This is a proposed fix to [issue 2950](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/issues/2950) that tries to fix the issue while not making rubocop angry by mutating constants. It converts the QUIT_ERRORS constant into a class variable and provides a class-level "setter," `protect_against`, on the `Bridge` class to add errors to the list of errors that `Bridge`s ignore when quitting. - [x] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: Add case-insensitive option for `text_to_by_present_in_element` expected condition
column4: This has come up because of what appears to be an inconsistency in Edge WebDriver implementation, but seems like it could be a useful feature.  I'd like to add an optional flag to `text_to_be_present_in_element` expected to condition, to match the text case-insensitively. By default, this would be off (current behavior).  My specific issue is that I have an element where the text has been upper-cased by CSS.  * In Firefox, Chrome, Safari, and IE: the text returned by element.text is the uppercase text,  * but edge webdriver returns the lowercase text  So, for my crossbrowser test to work I need to compare the text case insensitively.

column3: New FirefoxDriver ctor precedence logic and moz:firefoxOptions suâ€¦
column4: This change tries to make sense of the keyword arguments accepted by FirefoxDriver's constructor in the transition phase between the Firefox add-on driver and the Mozilla supported geckodriver HTTP service.  Prior to this patch, which arguments were consumed and respected varied greatly on whether the `capabilities["marionette"]` key was set to true. Following this change, the options passed on to geckodriver will consistently come out of firefox.Options.  The patch implements precedence logic for `capabilities`, `firefox_options`, and `firefox_binary`/`firefox_profile`.  They will populate the underlying data model in that order, which means a binary- or profile location set in `firefox_options` will override one set in the `capabilities` dictionary, and that `firefox_binary` and `firefox_profile` will override both of these.  The goal is to make it predictable what key is chosen, and to make the underlying data model somewhat easier to understand.  The latter is particularly important because the extension connection used for the old Firefox add-on does not accept a binary, profile, or arguments through capabilities since it is the Python bindings themselves that manage the lifetime of the browser.  In the case of geckodriver, which is an external HTTP service, it manages the lifetime and accepts a `moz:firefoxOptions` dictionary that is not unlike `chromeOptions` as of version 0.11.0.  Versions prior to geckodriver 0.11.0 accepted `firefox_binary`, `firefox_profile`, and `firefox_args` as top-level entries on the capabilities JSON Object. This is no longer supported behaviour by either the Python bindings or geckodriver.  Fixes https://github.com/mozilla/geckodriver/issues/228.

column3: Handle EPIPE errors along with the current ECONNRESET
column4: There is an open issue with Node.js throwing EPIPE errors when you pipe to a closed stream.  This was causing me unpredictable errors while loading pages.  The errors are pretty similar to ECONNRESET in the sense that you could simply try again and shouldn't throw every time it happens.  More info here: https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/947  - [x] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: Provide shim for submitting form command
column4: The W3C WebDriver specification does not specify a command for submitting a form. Many language bindings in Selenium provide a `webElement.submit()` function that no longer has a corresponding primitive in the remote end.  Selenium will need to provide a shim for submitting a form.  Given an HTML form,  ``` html       ```  one could imagine the workaround looking at `element.form.submit()` through JavaScript.

column3: Python Selenium client 3.3.0 doesn't support Python 3 any more
column4: The Python Selenium client verson 3.3 at [PyPI](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/selenium/), which was uploaded today, doesn't work on Python 3 any more. Version 3.0.2 works fine.  It now produces errors like this:  ``` env/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py:92: in __init__     self.start_session(desired_capabilities, browser_profile) env/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py:179: in start_session     response = self.execute(Command.NEW_SESSION, capabilities) env/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py:236: in execute     response = self.command_executor.execute(driver_command, params) env/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/remote_connection.py:415: in execute     return self._request(command_info[0], url, body=data) env/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/remote_connection.py:479: in _request     base64string = base64.b64encode('%s:%s' % (parsed_url.username, parsed_url.password)) env/lib/python3.4/base64.py:62: in b64encode     encoded = binascii.b2a_base64(s)[:-1] E   TypeError: 'str' does not support the buffer interface ```  If you can't reproduce this, let me know and I'll figure out exactly what's in my `desired_capabilities` dict.

column3: Confusing chrome driver download page
column4: The download page [linked](http://chromedriver.storage.googleapis.com/index.html) on npm page is pretty confusing, at least for me. It took me half an hour to realize why it throws strange errors. It may make people to think 2.9 is the latest version, but in fact it's outdated and the latest one is 2.25. Maybe link to the [chrome driver site](https://sites.google.com/a/chromium.org/chromedriver/) where it clearly states the latest version?  Thanks

column3: Allow for customisation of TestSlot
column4: The current implementation does not let downstream consumers of the Grid provide a customised way of  injecting a TestSlot.  This is very useful when one needs to build an On-Demand Grid,  wherein there are no real proxies, but a ghost proxy stands  for the real proxy and based on new session requests,  nodes are spun off.  Fixed this by defining a method for instantiating a  TestSlot so that downstream RemoteProxy implementations can choose to provide their own customised TestSlots.  Also enhanced the SeleniumProtocol enum to house all logic related to forming the protocol and the path from a desired capability into it.  - [X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: Enable extension of RemoteWebDriver and HttpCommandExecutor
column4: The ability to implement sub-classes of RemoteWebDriver and HttpCommandExecutor in the Java client is very limited, since these classes have private data members, with no protected accessors. In order to increase the extensibility of these classes, protected accessors were added, and methods that accessed these fields directly were changed to use these accessors.  The fields that are now accessible by sub-classes are: RemoteWebDriver.capabilities HttpCommandExecutor.commandCodec HttpCommandExecutor.responseCodec HttpCommandExecutor.client  - [X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: Ruby bindings: Security vulnerability in rubyzip dependency
column4: The `rubyzip` version required by the `selenium-webdriver` gem has a vulnerability that allows directory traversal:  https://github.com/rubyzip/rubyzip/issues/315, was fixed in version `1.2.1`  Not exactly sure how critical this is for the webdriver gem but an upgrade is highly appreciated in order to prevent dependeny conflicts due to different required versions, since other gems are upgrading to the latest `rubyzip` as well.

column3: With Selenium v2.53.x and v3.x is the timeOut and browserTimeout in seconds or milliseconds?
column4: The [official documentation](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/wiki/Grid2) seems to indicate that it's in seconds, but we are seeing some timeout errors in our runs, so I wanted to confirm.  On that page it says -  1. -timeout 30 (300 is default) The timeout in seconds before the hub automatically releases a node that hasn't received any requests for more than the specified number of seconds. 2.  On the hub you can also set -browserTimeout 60 to make the maximum time a node is willing to hang inside the browser 60 seconds.  Does [this](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/f1daf662a0622b87918b389885f4016f8c81f867/java/server/src/org/openqa/grid/internal/utils/configuration/StandaloneConfiguration.java#L77) and [this](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/f1daf662a0622b87918b389885f4016f8c81f867/java/server/src/org/openqa/grid/internal/utils/configuration/StandaloneConfiguration.java#L118) confirm that it is indeed in seconds and not milliseconds?  Also what is [newSessionWaitTimeout](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/f1daf662a0622b87918b389885f4016f8c81f867/java/server/src/org/openqa/grid/internal/utils/configuration/GridHubConfiguration.java#L68)?  Is StandaloneConfiguration.java the correct class to look for parameters that can be passed to the grid hub?

column3: WebElement cannot be wrapped in a Proxy
column4: Sometimes it is necessary to wrap a WebElement in a proxy - the most obvious choice could be java.lang.reflect.Proxy. However, existing implementation does not allow to use such proxied WebElements as arguments in the calls to JavascriptExecutor.executeScript().  Normally Proxy instance is created by specifying a set of interfaces that it should implement, but in WebElementToJsonConverter.apply() (https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/java/client/src/org/openqa/selenium/remote/internal/WebElementToJsonConverter.java#L53) which is used from executeScript() there is a test for a RemoteWebElement concrete class which proxy obviously cannot model.  One way to circumvent this would be to have proxy implement WrapsElement, but it would require additional logic to distinguish between invocations of WrapsElement methods and everything else. Would it be possible in WebElementToJsonConverter to test for HasIdentity instead of RemoteWebElement? I am not sufficiently familiar with Selenium's internal API but it does not look unreasonable to me on first glance.  Pertains both to Selenium 3.0 and earlier versions.

column3: Selenium documentation still specifies selenium is intended for testing purposes.
column4: So I recently ran into the fact that selenium provides no way to access the HTTP response code.  Apparently this is a WONTFIX issue, as specified here: https://github.com/seleniumhq/selenium-google-code-issue-archive/issues/141  However, https://github.com/seleniumhq/selenium-google-code-issue-archive/issues/141 also notes that selenium is **NOT** a tool for testing web-pages, but rather a tool only intended to allow "emulating user actions", and "Selenium is a browser automation framework, not an HTTP recording framework".  Given this fact, that means that much of the documentation needs to be corrected, and apparently has been incorrect for several years.  If selenium is a framework for web testing, accessing the HTTP response code is a code part of many tests, and it's therefore an issue that selenium does not support this.  If automated testing is not a design target of selenium (as #141 states), the lack of HTTP response code is in-scope, but the great majority of the documentation is therefore incorrect, as it specifies functionality that is apparently intentionally not supported by the selenium webdriver protocol.

column3: selenium-java 3.0.x has cyclical dependency
column4: selenium-java 3.0.1 depends on phantomjsdriver 1.3.0 which in turn depends on selenium-java 2.53.0  This is causing problems when resolving.  Not sure whether selenium or phantomjs is in error. To fix selenium-java, I'd suggest an exclusion in the maven pom  ```xml      com.codeborne     phantomjsdriver     1.3.0                           org.seleniumhq.selenium             selenium-java                ```  Though I'm not sure how to do that with selenium's build system.

column3: selenium-java depends on org.apache.commons:commons-exec but does not declare it
column4: Selenium Version: 2.53.1  ```org.openqa.selenium.os.UnixProcess``` imports and uses ```org.apache.commons.exec.DaemonExecutor``` which comes from ```org.apache.commons:commons-exec```. selenium-java's pom.xml file does not declare a runtime dependency from ```org.apache.commons:commons-exec```.  The Selenium parent pom.xml dependency management section lists ```org.apache.commons:commons-exec:1.3```.  Attempting to run tests based on selenium-java results in below error if the project doesn't otherwise depend on ```org.apache.commons:commons-exec```.  The issue can be worked around by declaring a dependency from ```org.apache.commons:commons-exec:1.3``` in the pom.xml file of the project which also depends on selenium-java.  ``` org.jbehave.core.failures.BeforeOrAfterFailed: Method beforeStory (annotated with @BeforeStory in class org.jbehave.web.selenium.PerStoryWebDriverSteps) failed: java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/apache/commons/exec/DaemonExecutor 	at org.jbehave.core.steps.StepCreator$BeforeOrAfterStep.perform(StepCreator.java:460) 	at org.jbehave.core.embedder.StoryRunner$FineSoFar.run(StoryRunner.java:499)         [...] 	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:615) 	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745) Caused by: java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/apache/commons/exec/DaemonExecutor 	at org.openqa.selenium.os.UnixProcess.(UnixProcess.java:52) 	at org.openqa.selenium.os.CommandLine.(CommandLine.java:47) 	at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxBinary.startProfile(FirefoxBinary.java:97) 	at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.internal.NewProfileExtensionConnection.start(NewProfileExtensionConnection.java:100) 	at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver.startClient(FirefoxDriver.java:271) 	at org.openqa.selenium.remote.RemoteWebDriver.(RemoteWebDriver.java:119)         [...] 	at org.jbehave.core.steps.StepCreator$BeforeOrAfterStep.perform(StepCreator.java:458) 	... 12 more Caused by: java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: org.apache.commons.exec.DaemonExecutor 	at java.net.URLClassLoader$1.run(URLClassLoader.java:366)         [...] 	at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(ClassLoader.java:358) 	... 32 more ```

column3: Use Get Element Rect/Set Element Rect when talking to W3C WebDriver remotes
column4: Selenium language bindings should use the Get Element Rect and Set Element Rect commands when talking to W3C WebDriver remotes:  * Set Element Rect: POST `/session/{session id}/window/rect` * Get Element Rect: GET `/session/{session id}/window/rect`  These two endpoints replace the four endpoints used for setting- and getting window position, and setting- and getting the window size.  I havenâ€™t yet investigated which language bindings this applies to.

column3: Selenium 3 doesn't work/support WebDriverEventListener
column4: Selenium 3 doesn't work/support WebDriverEventListener

column3: Enhancement request: access to text nodes
column4: Select only the text nodes inside ``, without the text in the  `` children  ``` html        dolore ipsum     Ah, the pain itself     Ah, the pain   ```  Selector:  ``` java driver.findElement(By.xpath("//*[@id='one']/text()")); ```  Result:  ``` org.openqa.selenium.InvalidSelectorException: invalid selector:  The result of the xpath expression "//*[@id='one']/text()" is: [object Text]. It should be an element. ```

column3: [js] fix consequences of replacing Promise -> ManagedPromise
column4: Seems like it was a blind replace. Also I added a link to an [article](https://jakearchibald.com/2015/tasks-microtasks-queues-and-schedules/) explaining microtasks.  - [x] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: Error: PhantomJS executable may have wrong permissions
column4: Running Selenium locally on flask. Im using the PhantomJS driver.  `driver = webdriver.PhantomJS(executable_path='/Users/MyAcc/Documents/MY-WEBAPP/venv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/phantomjs')`  Here's the error code I got when I run `selenium.common.exceptions.WebDriverException: Message: 'phantomjs' executable may have wrong permissions. `

column3: Create ChromeOptions and FirefoxOptions classes
column4: Ruby currently just uses hashes which causes confusion between strings and symbols and snake case vs camel case. Creating objects will support using parameters in the "Ruby way."

column3: Split Open/Read Timeouts, defaulting Http::Default open_timeout to nil
column4: Ruby 2.3 changed `Net::HTTP#open_timeout` default from `nil` to `60`. As a result, debuggers that freeze the process (like RubyMine) timeout when evaluating browser operations. [Details here](https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/RUBY-18301).  The following changes were made: - Split `Remote::HTTP::Common#timeout` accessor to `open_timeout` and `read_timeout`. - Added backwards compatibility for `#timeout=`. - Defaulted `Remote::HTTP::Default#http` open_timeout to nil (maintains behaviour w/ Ruby 2.2 and earlier). - Added specs for above.  - [x] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: Remove resolve_ip feature from RemoteConnection
column4: Resolving the IP never necessary, httplib does that for us. Worse, it is always the wrong thing to do when dealing with HTTPS connections, as no certificates are issued for IP-adresses. IMHO there is no reason to keep this feature around.  While I was at it, I also added HTTPS support for keepalive connections; which always defaulted to HTTP, even if a HTTPS url was provided.  Fixes #1729 Fixes #2509 Fixes #3514  - [x] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)   --- This change isâ€‚[](https://reviewable.io/reviews/seleniumhq/selenium/3515)

column3: sys.meta_path is None, Python is likely shutting down
column4: Reproduced using:  Python 3.6.0 (latest at the moment) Selenium 3.0.2 (latest at the moment) ChromeDriver 2.27 (latest at the moment)  Mac OS   The code I'm executing:  ```python from selenium import webdriver from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import WebDriverWait from selenium.webdriver.support import expected_conditions as EC  driver = webdriver.Chrome(executable_path="/usr/local/bin/chromedriver") driver.get('http://videohost.site/play/A11QStEaNdVZfvV/')  video = WebDriverWait(driver, 10).until(EC.presence_of_element_located((By.TAG_NAME, "video"))) print(video.get_attribute("src"))  driver.close() ```  The error I'm getting:  ``` Exception ignored in: > Traceback (most recent call last):   File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/common/service.py", line 173, in __del__   File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/common/service.py", line 149, in stop   File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/common/service.py", line 120, in send_remote_shutdown_command ImportError: sys.meta_path is None, Python is likely shutting down ```  Why is this happening?  Note: I can workaround it using `driver.quit()` instead of `driver.close()`.  Thanks!  Cross-linking the SO post: http://stackoverflow.com/q/41480148/771848

column3: Updated multiple browser instance launch test

column3: [Ruby client] remove freeze for Selenium::WebDriver::SearchContext::FINDERS for appium_lib
column4: Remove `.freeze` for `Selenium::WebDriver::SearchContext::FINDERS`  I used `selenium-webdriver 3.0`'s ruby client with Appium. Then I found failed case to start devices via appium server and `appium_lib` which is appium ruby client. The `appium_lib` extends `Selenium::WebDriver::SearchContext::FINDERS` to extend some search elements for mobile application. ( [search results](https://github.com/appium/ruby_lib/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=searchContext) )  BTW, `Selenium::WebDriver::SearchContext::FINDERS` is freezed from `selenium-webdriver 3.0`. Could you unfreeze `FINDERS` to works fine `appium_lib` ?   ---  I accepted CLA.

column3: base64 str encoding failing in python 3.6
column4: python3 is expecting a â€œbytes-like objectâ€ (https://docs.python.org/3/glossary.html#term-bytes-like-object)  so it is failing when sending a string (username & password)  see https://docs.python.org/3/library/base64.html#base64.b64encode  to convert to a bytes object, just call encode() method to turn it into a set of 8-bit byte values  - [x] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: [py] update test/ci configs to use python 3.6
column4: Python 3.6 was released on December 23, 2016. This PR updates the Python version used in Tox/Travis-CI tests from 3.5 to 3.6.  Changes:  * update Tox configuration to use Python 3.6 rather than Python 3.5  * update Travis-Ci configuration to use Python 3.6 rather than Python 3.5  * update classifiers in setup.py to include Python 3.6  - [X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: [rb] refrain from sending unnecessary default capabilities for w3c
column4: Previously, 'any' was sent for some capabilities if they weren't set by the user, which does not line up with the current state of the W3C spec. Instead, leave them as undefined.  - [X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: Throw an exception if new session returns an error.
column4: Previously if the http response code was not an error response, then an exception would not be thrown even if the response contained an error field or a non-zero status. This was specifically a problem for Chromedriver.  - [X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: Firefox 49 works with my signed WebDriver but it does not with Selenium's unsigned one
column4: Please read the issue an not mark it as duplicate of #2559 ## Meta -  OS:   Ubuntu 16.04 Selenium Version:   2.53.1 Browser:   Firefox  Browser Version:   49.0 (64-bit) ## Expected Behavior -  Firefox 48+ should work with Selenium's WebDriver just as it works with [my signed WebDriver](https://my.owndrive.com/index.php/s/cEXRnP1Y6rLeDEV) ## Actual Behavior -  Selenium replaces my WebDriver which works with v49 with the unsigned one which does not work with Firefox v48+ ## Steps to reproduce -  Install [my signed web driver](https://my.owndrive.com/index.php/s/cEXRnP1Y6rLeDEV) and start Protractor or Selenium.

column3: Can't find related product for selenium webdriver on the bugreport.apple.com
column4: Please explain the correct way to post bugs for safari webdriver. There is no product webdriver (or selenium or safaridriver) on the bugreport.apple.com.  I posted an issue with webdriver to the "Safari Technology Preview" product on the 24th of February and it still in Open status without any comments.  But here I got answer the same day https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/issues/3593.   Thanks.

column3: Selenium2Library fail to SELECT pop-uo window
column4: OS: Windows 7 Selenium Version:   2.47 and 2.53.1 Browser:   Internet Explorer Browser Version:  11  I am using Selenium2Library to control the Browser(IE) There is one button on the webpage. The ID is "confirm" When the button is clicked, 3 stuff will show at the same time: 1. Alert with OK button 2. Pop-up window 3. Download bar (After closed the Alert) ![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15870347/20129286/922cdae4-a689-11e6-9453-44851935c9b9.PNG)  `Click Button          id=confirm` `Sleep              2s` `Alert Should Be Present                alert message` `Sleep                            10s #the pop-up window will load some content` `Select Window                        title=Reports` `Sleep                                2s` `Close Window                       #close the pop-up`  However, the robot will waiting on Select Window. Maybe still searching the target pop-up? My pop-up will load around 15s at least. So it won't have title of pop-up window. I cannot get the log.html. The robot won't stop.

column3: Selenium 3.0 chromedriver 2.25 open new tab(Crtl+T) doesn't work
column4: OS: WIN7  Selenium Version: 3.0  Browser: Chrome  Browser Version: 54.0.2840.87 m (64-bit)  Selenium 3.0 chromedriver 2.25 open new tab doesn't work, but the same code could be worked on 2.53 version  Output : there is no error after send "Keys.CONTROL + t", but no new tab open.  Code: JAVA   ``` @Test(groups = { "New tab bug" }) 	public void newTabBug() {  		System.setProperty("webdriver.chrome.driver", 				ClassLoader.getSystemResource("Driver").getPath().substring(1) + "/chromedriver.exe");  		ChromeOptions options = new ChromeOptions(); 		options.addArguments("lang=en_US.UTF-8", "--disable-extensions", "--incognito", "--start-maximized");  		WebDriver driver = new EventFiringWebDriver(new ChromeDriver(options)) 				.register(new WebDriverListenerRedefine());  		driver.get("http://www.baidu.com");  		driver.findElement(By.tagName("body")).sendKeys(Keys.CONTROL + "t"); 		Set allWindowsId = driver.getWindowHandles(); 		for (String windowId : allWindowsId) { 			if (driver.switchTo().window(windowId).getTitle().contains("New Tab")) { 				driver.switchTo().window(windowId); 				break; 			} 		}  		driver.navigate().to("http://www.qq.com/"); 	} ```

column3: JS client no longer connects to an already launched standalone server
column4: OS:  Windows 8.1 Selenium Version:   standalone server 3.0.0 Client: JavaScript selenium-webdriver@3.0.0-beta-3 Browser:  Chrome  For an instance of the standalone server launched with:  ``` shell java -Dselenium.LOGGER.level=INFO -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.0.0.jar ```  Running this code :  ``` js var webdriver = require('selenium-webdriver'); var driver = new webdriver.Builder()   .forBrowser('chrome')   .usingServer('http://127.0.0.1:4444/wd/hub')   .build(); ```  Raise this exception:  ``` js selenium-webdriver\lib\promise.js:2291         throw error;         ^  Error: Server terminated early with status 1     at Error (native)     at selenium-webdriver\remote\index.js:255:22     at process._tickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:103:7) From: Task: WebDriver.createSession()     at Function.createSession (selenium-webdriver\lib\webdriver.js:366:24)     at Driver (selenium-webdriver\chrome.js:716:38)     at selenium-webdriver\index.js:86:17     at Builder.build (selenium-webdriver\index.js:540:16)     at Object. (suite.js:7:4)     at Module._compile (module.js:413:34)     at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:422:10)     at Module.load (module.js:357:32)     at Function.Module._load (module.js:314:12)     at Function.Module.runMain (module.js:447:10) ```  It looks like the client is trying to launch the standalone server where it should be connecting the server that is already launched.  The server doesn't show any connection attempt:  ``` INFO - Selenium build info: version: '3.0.0', revision: '350cf60' INFO - Launching a standalone Selenium Server INFO::main: Logging initialized @409ms INFO - Driver class not found: com.opera.core.systems.OperaDriver INFO - Driver provider com.opera.core.systems.OperaDriver registration is skipped: Unable to create new instances on this machine. INFO - Driver class not found: com.opera.core.systems.OperaDriver INFO - Driver provider com.opera.core.systems.OperaDriver is not registered INFO - Driver provider org.openqa.selenium.safari.SafariDriver registration is skipped:  registration capabilities Capabilities [{browserName=safari, version=, platform=MAC}] does not match the current platform WI N8_1 INFO:osjs.Server:main: jetty-9.2.15.v20160210 INFO:osjsh.ContextHandler:main: Started o.s.j.s.ServletContextHandler@15be6bb{/,null,AVAILABLE} INFO:osjs.ServerConnector:main: Started ServerConnector@461048{HTTP/1.1}{0.0.0.0:4444} INFO:osjs.Server:main: Started @660ms INFO - Selenium Server is up and running ```  Note that I can successfully connect to the server with the Python client (3.0.0):  ``` python from selenium import webdriver capabilities = webdriver.DesiredCapabilities.CHROME driver = webdriver.Remote("http://127.0.0.1:4444/wd/hub", desired_capabilities=capabilities) ```

column3: Out of heap space on 104mb FF profile Selenium 3.0.1
column4: OS:  Windows 7 running Standalone Jar file Selenium Version:  3.0.1 Browser:  Firefox with Gecko Driver Browser Version:  47.0.1  ## Background - I am running the Selenium Standalone JAR file on windows 7 32bit boxes, my tests then connect to these servers using webdriver.Remote in the python binding.  All through Selenium 2 this has worked fine, but I am now getting an error when running FireFox from with Selenium 3.  I am using this line to start the Selenium Server (all on a single line): java -Xmx1600m -Dwebdriver.firefox.profile="webdriver" -Dwebdriver.ie.driver="c:/selenium/IEDriverServer.exe" -Dwebdriver.gecko.driver="c:/selenium/geckodriver.exe" -Dwebdriver.chrome.driver="c:/selenium/chromedriver.exe" -jar C:\selenium\selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1.jar    ## Expected Behavior - When using the the -Dwebdriver.firefox.profile="webdriver" option on the standalone server I would expect Selenium to launch FireFox using that profile (it has done in all 2.X versions I have used) The profile is a total of 104mb in size.  ## Actual Behavior - When trying to launch the FireFox browser Selenium throws: java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException: org.openqa.selenium.WebDriverException: java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException  And eventually a WARN - Exception: Java heap space  If I remove the -Dwebdriver.firefox.profile="webdriver" option when starting the standalone server then Selenium starts a FireFox browser with a default profile.  ## Steps to reproduce - Log attached  [selenium_log.docx](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/files/710921/selenium_log.docx)

column3: Android Mobile Automation with selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1.jar and Appium
column4: OS:  Windows 7 Selenium Version:  3.0.1 Mobile with Appium  Current version of selenium ie 3.0.1 is not supporting Android device with appium.We can create androiddriver session and app is opening in device, but element not found exception is happening. After 2 days investigation with diff changes atlast found this is an issue with selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1.jar. I replaced with selenium-server-standalone-2.46.jar and its working perfectly.

column3: Unable to launch Firefox 47.0.1 on 3.3.1 grid node
column4: OS:  Windows 2012 Selenium Version:   Webdriver 3.3 .NET bindings selenium-server-standalone-3.3.1.jar  Browser:  Firefox  Browser Version:  47.0.1  ## Expected Behavior - Tests can be run using RemoteWebDriver and a grid running 3.3.1  ## Actual Behavior - The following exception is generated when creating a RemoteWebDriver instance: An unhandled exception of type 'System.InvalidOperationException' occurred in WebDriver.dll  Additional information: org.openqa.selenium.remote.service.DriverCommandExecutor cannot be cast to org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver$LazyCommandExecutor   ## Steps to reproduce - C# code snippet below....  using System; using OpenQA.Selenium; using OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox; using OpenQA.Selenium.Remote;  namespace FFStartUpProblem {     internal class Program     {         private static void Main(string[] args)         {             IWebDriver driver;             Uri _internalSeleniumGrid = new Uri("http://x.x.x.x:4444/wd/hub");              FirefoxProfile profile = new FirefoxProfile();             FirefoxOptions options = new FirefoxOptions             {                 UseLegacyImplementation = true             };             DesiredCapabilities capabilities = (DesiredCapabilities)options.ToCapabilities();             capabilities.SetCapability(FirefoxDriver.ProfileCapabilityName, profile.ToBase64String());              driver = new RemoteWebDriver(_internalSeleniumGrid, capabilities);             driver.Navigate().GoToUrl("http://www.google.com");             driver.Quit();         }     } }  The same code snippet works when using 3.2.0 grid node

column3: Wrong Cookie.Path/.Domain for session cookies in InternetExplorerDriver
column4: OS:  Windows 10 Selenium Version: Selenium NuGet package: 3.0.1, IEDriverServer.exe: 2.53.1 Browser:  IE Browser Version:  IE 11.0.37 (11.672.10586.0)  ## Expected Behavior Correct `Path` and `Domain` is returned for session cookies.  ## Actual Behavior `Path` is always "/", `Domain` is null for session cookies in IE. (Non-session cookies in IE work; both types work with ChromeDriver/FirefoxDriver).  ## Steps to reproduce Repro sample using OWIN and Nancy: ```C# static void Main() {     var baseUrl = "http://localhost:8080/Temporary_Listen_Addresses/";     using (WebApp.Start(baseUrl, app => app.UseNancy()))         TestWebDriver(baseUrl); }  public class SessionModule : NancyModule {     public SessionModule()     {         Console.WriteLine();         Get["/nonsessioncookie"] = _ =>             Response.AsText("cookie was set")                     .WithCookie(new NancyCookie("nonsessioncookie", "val")                     {                         Path = Context.Request.Url.BasePath + "/",                         Expires = DateTime.Now.AddDays(10),                     });          Get["/sessioncookie"] = _ =>             Response.AsText("cookie was set")                 .WithCookie(new NancyCookie("sessioncookie", "val")                 {                     Path = Context.Request.Url.BasePath + "/",                     Expires = null,                 });     } }  static void TestWebDriver(string baseUrl) {     var driverDirPath = @"[...]";      //var webDriver = new FirefoxDriver(FirefoxDriverService.CreateDefaultService(driverDirPath));     //var webDriver = new ChromeDriver(driverDirPath);     var webDriver = new InternetExplorerDriver(driverDirPath);      using (webDriver)     {         webDriver.Navigate().GoToUrl(baseUrl + "/nonsessioncookie");         // Prints "nonsessioncookie=val; expires=[...]; path=/Temporary_Listen_Addresses/; domain=localhost":         Console.WriteLine(webDriver.Manage().Cookies.GetCookieNamed("nonsessioncookie").ToString());          webDriver.Navigate().GoToUrl(baseUrl + "/sessioncookie");         // Prints "sessioncookie=val; path=/":         Console.WriteLine(webDriver.Manage().Cookies.GetCookieNamed("sessioncookie").ToString());     } } ```

column3: ChromeOptions Not Being Used
column4: OS:  Ubuntu Xenial 16.04 Selenium Version:  3 beta 4 Browser:  Chrome 53  I notice that I can set google chrome options from the command line such as --app=http://mysite.com but when I use addArguments with ChromeOptions and even with a DesiredCapabilities object, the arguments are ignored. column3: Negative values for setScriptTimeout() not working as mentioned in the documentation. (node selenium-webdriver)
column4: OS:  UBUNTU 16.04 Selenium Version: Node.js 3.3.0  Browser: Chrome  The negative value for setScriptTimeout() don't seem to be working as it should for executeAsyncScript(). I'm trying to execute a script that can run for an indefinite amount of time and executeAsyncScript() is not working if I'm not giving it positive values, which I have no way of knowing. ``` var script = "         var callback = arguments[arguments.length - 1];         window.onbeforeunload = function(e){           var confirmationMessage = "Are you sure you want to leave this page and close the app?";           (e || window.event).returnValue = confirmationMessage;           return confirmationMessage;           callback('CLOSED!');         }      "  driver.executeAsyncScript(script).then(function(val){        console.log(val);      }) ```  ## Expected Behavior - I should get "CLOSED!" log after the window is closed.  ## Actual Behavior - timeout === 0 ScriptTimeoutError: asynchronous script timeout: result was not received in 0 seconds.  timeout ===  -1 ScriptTimeoutError: asynchronous script timeout: result was not received in -1 seconds   I do not want to give a specific timeout. Is this feature working? Is it a bug? Most of the solutions for this online seem to have been solved by using a large enough estimate for a positive timeout. But I haven't found anything on how to use negative timeout properly.

column3: client.end() should return its promise operand
column4: OS:  OS: Mac OS X 10.11.4 x86_64 Selenium Version:  v2.53.1, with Core v2.53.1. Built from revision a36b8b1 Browser:  Firefox (but n/a)  When a callback provided to Selenium throws an exception or returns a rejected promise, the client properly bubbles up the error, except when chaining `.end()`.  I tested errors generated as follows: - `throw new Error("an exception happens here")` - `return Promise.reject(new Error("a promise gets rejected"))` - `return Promise.reject("a promise gets rejected")`  Here is a demonstration of throwing an exception that works properly:  ``` js var promise = webdriverio     .remote(options).init()     .url('http://www.google.com')     .getTitle().then(function(title) {         throw new Error("an exception happens here");         console.log('Title was: ' + title);     });     promise.end(); showError(promise);  function showError(promise) {     if (typeof promise.then === 'function') {         promise.catch(function (err) {             if (err instanceof Error)                 console.log(err);             else                 console.log("Rejected promise: "+ err);         });     }     else         console.log("not a promise"); }  // Error: an exception happens here //     at Object. (/repos/arepo/tests/test_errs.js:26:15) //     at Object.exec (/repos/arepo/node_modules/webdriverio/build/lib/helpers/safeExecute.js:28:24) //     at Object.resolve (/repos/arepo/node_modules/webdriverio/build/lib/webdriverio.js:189:29) ```  If we instead return the result of chaining `.end()`, we get this:  ``` js var promise = webdriverio     .remote(options).init()     .url('http://www.google.com')     .getTitle().then(function(title) {         throw new Error("an exception happens here");         console.log('Title was: ' + title);     })     .end(); showError(promise);  // Error: an exception happens here //     at title() - getTitle.js:29:28 //     at end() - webdriverio.js:16:6 ```  For completeness, here are comparisons of chaining vs not chaining returning rejected promises:  ``` js         return Promise.reject(new Error("a promise gets rejected"));  /* NOT CHAINED */ // Error: a promise gets rejected //     at Object. (/repos/arepo/tests/test_errs.js:56:31) //     at Object.exec (/repos/arepo/node_modules/webdriverio/build/lib/helpers/safeExecute.js:28:24) //     at Object.resolve (/repos/arepo/node_modules/webdriverio/build/lib/webdriverio.js:189:29)  /* CHAINED */ // Error: a promise gets rejected //     at title() - getTitle.js:29:28 //     at end() - test_errs.js:45:6 ```  ``` js         return Promise.reject("a promise gets rejected");  /* NOT CHAINED */ // Rejected promise: a promise gets rejected  /* CHAINED */ // (nothing is output in this scenario) ```  I suspect a decision must be made about whether `.end()` should return a promise that propagates a callback error. If the answer is yes, it should be made consistent. If the answer is no, `.end()` should return no error information instead of a confused mix of information. The inconsistencies had me pulling my hair out looking for the proper resolution.  My preference is to be able to include include the following in my tests and have it properly propagate errors to the test harness:  ``` js var t = require('tap');  t.test("load the home page", function (t) {     return webdriverio         .remote(options).init()         .url('http://www.google.com')         .getTitle().then(function(title) {             console.log('Title was: ' + title);         })         .end(); }); ```  Note that [`tap`](https://github.com/tapjs/node-tap) properly handles the returned promise in all of these cases, reporting the error.

column3: Suddenly having multiple issues with Ruby selenium-webdriver ex.. ECONNREFUSED, browser window closing...
column4: OS:  Mac 10.11.6 selenium-webdriver 3.0.0 (Ruby) Browser:  Chrome, Firefox, Safari  Suddenly when I tried to use selenium-webdriver today to automate my browser, I'm getting all sorts of strange issues.  1) I'm getting ``rescue in block in connect': Failed to open TCP connection to 127.0.0.1:4444 (Connection refused - connect(2) for "127.0.0.1" port 4444) (Errno::ECONNREFUSED)` This error has popped up with every browser I've tried... with Chrome, my ruby script crashes after the browser pops up, the browser window stays open (shows "data;" in the URL). When trying Firefox and Safari, the browser window pops up and my script freezes... when I ctrl+C, I get the above error.  2) In Firefox and Safari, I won't see any errors, including the one above, until I ctrl+C (after the browser window opens). After I hit ctrl+C, exceptions such as selenium not seeing a page link show up, but not until I hit ctrl+C... which has never been the case before. Normally I see exceptions straight away..  Sorry for posting this in the general selenium github, but I figure it's the best place since I'm experiencing problems on multiple browsers. Any thoughts on what caused this massive change in behavior?

column4: OS:  Linux Selenium Version: 3.3.1 Browser:  Hub related issue  I have pulled the last version of the docker image : selenium/hub  In the docker hub log i got:  ``` 12:43:35.509 WARN - Cleaning up stale test sessions on the unregistered node http://172.17.0.50:5555 12:43:40.514 INFO - Registered a node http://172.17.0.50:5555 12:43:50.535 INFO - Marking the node http://172.17.0.50:5555 as down: cannot reach the node for 2 tries 12:44:50.613 INFO - Unregistering the node http://172.17.0.50:5555 because it's been down for 60078 milliseconds 12:44:50.613 WARN - Cleaning up stale test sessions on the unregistered node http://172.17.0.50:5555 12:44:55.610 INFO - Registered a node http://172.17.0.50:5555 12:45:05.626 INFO - Marking the node http://172.17.0.50:5555 as down: cannot reach the node for 2 tries 12:46:05.694 INFO - Unregistering the node http://172.17.0.50:5555 because it's been down for 60068 milliseconds 12:46:05.694 WARN - Cleaning up stale test sessions on the unregistered node http://172.17.0.50:5555 12:46:05.719 INFO - Registered a node http://172.17.0.50:5555 12:46:15.733 INFO - Marking the node http://172.17.0.50:5555 as down: cannot reach the node for 2 tries ```  I'm not the one having that issue, see in comments place : https://hub.docker.com/r/selenium/hub/  A workaround might be to tweak : nodeStatusCheckTimeout unregisterIfStillDownAfter ( default 60 seconds )  Thx for help, trix

column3: KeyboardEvent key property is unassigned when sendKeys()
column4: OS:  any  Selenium Version: any selenium webdriver version Browser:  any  Keyboard event key property:   https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/KeyboardEvent/key  is supported by all desktop browsers except Safari. A lot of developers starting to use it.  I just had an issue it was very hard to find out why sendKeys() method wasn't working. The problem was that selenium generated keyboard event had this property "key" empty and because of it validation didn't work. Please consider assigning this property on every keyboard events with selenium.

column3: Potential Issue with Phantom JS or WebDriver 3.0
column4: OS:   Ubuntu Xenial 16.04 Selenium Version:   3.0 Browser:  PhantomJS (Apple Webkit)  I am going to reference this ticket because of relatively large issue with PhantomJS that occurs when an element is constantly attempted to be accessed. I am trying to run many concurrent tests in PhantomJS using Selenium 3 but continually get the cleanup error. Further inspection of the DEBUG log level output shows that selenium is constantly retrying to find an element which it says exists. The output and issue can be found at the Phantom JS page :  #https://github.com/ariya/phantomjs/issues/14588.  Perhaps you could take a look as well? There are now bugs open on detro/ghostdriver, ariya/phantomjs, and here. Thanks

Check is element isDisplayed()  Run: ```Java 		driver = new FirefoxDriver(); //		driver = new ChromeDriver();  		driver.get( 				"https://buy.garmin.com/en-US/US/p/134491#accessories"); 		Thread.sleep(5000);  		WebElement webEl = driver.findElement( 				By.cssSelector(".app__accessories__group #js__010-11430-00")); 		System.out.println(webEl.isDisplayed());  		driver.quit(); ```
