column3: I am unable to locate any elements on any page in IE11 Windows 10 with IEDriver
column4: OS:   Windows 10 Selenium Version:   3.2.0 (but can use any) Browser:   IE11 Browser Version:   11.576.14393.0 can use 32 or 64 bit version  Posted this on Stack Overflow but thought better placed here..  I've searched all over for an answer and I can't find any fix to my issue. I am trying to run my Selenium tests in IE11. All other browsers work fine (including Edge). A simple test as follows will cause the issue...  ``` System.setProperty("webdriver.ie.driver.loglevel","TRACE"); System.setProperty("webdriver.ie.driver.logfile", "C:/Projects/logme.txt"); driver = new InternetExplorerDriver(); driver.manage().timeouts().implicitlyWait(3, TimeUnit.SECONDS); driver.manage().deleteAllCookies(); driver.manage().window().maximize(); driver.get("http://www.google.com"); driver.findElement(By.id("lst-ib")).click; ```  IE11 will launch and navigate to a URL but it cannot find any elements anywhere on any page. Again, I'm aware people have had this issue but no suggestions have fixed my problem. This is the error i get back every time:  ``` org.openqa.selenium.NoSuchElementException: Unable to find element with id == lst-ib (WARNING: The server did not provide any stacktrace information) Command duration or timeout: 3.23 seconds For documentation on this error, please visit: http://seleniumhq.org/exceptions/no_such_element.html Build info: version: '3.2.0', revision: '8c03df6b79', time: '2017-02-23 10:51:31 +0000'System info: host: 'DESKTOP-63BRP93', ip: '10.0.110.68', os.name: 'Windows 10', os.arch: 'x86', os.version: '10.0', java.version: '1.8.0_121' Driver info: org.openqa.selenium.ie.InternetExplorerDriverCapabilities [{browserAttachTimeout=0, ie.enableFullPageScreenshot=true, enablePersistentHover=true, ie.forceCreateProcessApi=false, ie.forceShellWindowsApi=false, pageLoadStrategy=normal, ignoreZoomSetting=false, ie.fileUploadDialogTimeout=3000, version=11, platform=WINDOWS, nativeEvents=true, ie.ensureCleanSession=false, elementScrollBehavior=0, ie.browserCommandLineSwitches=, requireWindowFocus=false, browserName=internet explorer, initialBrowserUrl=http://localhost:38992/, javascriptEnabled=true, ignoreProtectedModeSettings=false, enableElementCacheCleanup=true, unexpectedAlertBehaviour=dismiss}] Session ID: 0fbcebc8-6775-4a6c-b10a-47350502598f *** Element info: {Using=id, value=lst-ib}     at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method)     at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:62)     at sun.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45) at java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Constructor.java:423)  ```  Here is what I've tried/done...  1. Set Enabled Protected Mode to disabled and enabled for all zones 2. Set Allow Scripting option on the advanced tab or IE options 3. Tried every IEDriver capability known to man e.g. setCapability(InternetExplorerDriver.IE_ENSURE_CLEAN_SESSION,true); 4. Tried IE11 32 and 64bit 5. Attempted to find an element by, class, tagname and all the rest of the locators to no avail. 6. Added the 2 registry keys BFCACHE for both 32 and 64bit instances of IE 7. Cried a lot  Below is the attached logs and I've located where the code falls over. It seems to be security related but JavaScript is enabled and I don't know where else to look...  ``` T 2017-03-06 17:27:41:529 Browser.cpp(613) Entering Browser::GetDocumentFromWindow T 2017-03-06 17:27:41:532 Script.cpp(49) Entering Script::Initialize T 2017-03-06 17:27:41:532 Script.cpp(70) Entering Script::AddArgument(std::wstring) T 2017-03-06 17:27:41:532 Script.cpp(105) Entering Script::AddArgument(VARIANT) T 2017-03-06 17:27:41:532 Script.cpp(70) Entering Script::AddArgument(std::wstring) T 2017-03-06 17:27:41:532 Script.cpp(105) Entering Script::AddArgument(VARIANT) T 2017-03-06 17:27:41:532 Script.cpp(169) Entering Script::Execute T 2017-03-06 17:27:41:532 Script.cpp(477) Entering Script::CreateAnonymousFunction W 2017-03-06 17:27:41:539 Script.cpp(494) -2147024891 [Access is denied.]: Unable to execute code, call to IHTMLWindow2::execScript failed W 2017-03-06 17:27:41:540 Script.cpp(180) Cannot create anonymous function W 2017-03-06 17:27:41:540 ElementFinder.cpp(98) A JavaScript error was encountered executing the findElement atom. ```  If anyone has seen or fixed this issue, please help me!  Thanks

column3: Erro in class invisibility_of_element_located
column4: OS:   Windows 10 Selenium Version:   3.0.2, IDE ATOM Browser:   Firefox and Chromium  Browser Version:   FF 51.01 (64-bit) Chromie VersÃ£o 55.0.2883.87 m  Script Test:  ``` from selenium import webdriver from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import WebDriverWait from time import sleep from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By from selenium.webdriver.support import expected_conditions from selenium.common.exceptions import ElementNotVisibleException from selenium.common import exceptions  driver = webdriver.Firefox() driver.get("http://www.jqueryrain.com/?eKV1bCMa")  def wait_element_present(driver, elem):     present = WebDriverWait(driver, 60).until(         expected_conditions.presence_of_element_located((By.CSS_SELECTOR, elem))     )     print(present)     return present  def wait_element_not_present(driver, elem):     present = WebDriverWait(driver, 15, ignored_exceptions=\             exceptions.NoSuchElementException).until(         expected_conditions.invisibility_of_element_located((By.CSS_SELECTOR, elem))     )     print(present)     return present  driver.switch_to.frame(0) button = wait_element_present(driver, "button#quick_demo") button.click()  test = wait_element_present(driver, ".loadingoverlay") test2 = wait_element_not_present(driver, ".loadingoverlay") ```  Show Error:  ```       {"error":"no such element","message":"Unable to locate element: .loadingoverlay"} Traceback (most recent call last):   File "D:\Dropbox\Dropbox\Meu Curso de Selenium\testes\loading_page.py", line 32, in      test2 = wait_element_not_present(driver, ".loadingoverlay")   File "D:\Dropbox\Dropbox\Meu Curso de Selenium\testes\loading_page.py", line 22, in wait_element_not_present     expected_conditions.invisibility_of_element_located((By.CSS_SELECTOR, elem))  File "C:\Python35-32\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\support\wait.py", line 71, in until     value = method(self._driver)   File "C:\Python35-32\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\support\expected_conditions.py", line 197, in __call__     return _element_if_visible(_find_element(driver, self.locator), False)   File "C:\Python35-32\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\support\expected_conditions.py", line 99, in _element_if_visible     return element if element.is_displayed() == visibility else False AttributeError: 'str' object has no attribute 'is_displayed'  Process returned 1 (0x1)   execution time : 24.619 s Pressione qualquer tecla para continuar. . . ```  I look the code in selenium this is wrong code in _find_element(driver, self.locator) because exception inside the function is string, exception webdriver not work, return string not one webelement, this not  has no attribute 'is_displayed':      def __init__(self, locator):         self.locator = locator      def __call__(self, driver):         try:             return _element_if_visible(_find_element(driver, self.locator), False)         except (NoSuchElementException, StaleElementReferenceException):             # In the case of NoSuchElement, returns true because the element is             # not present in DOM. The try block checks if the element is present             # but is invisible.             # In the case of StaleElementReference, returns true because stale             # element reference implies that element is no longer visible.             return True      try: >>> Do not give a webdriver exception here         return driver.find_element(*by)     except NoSuchElementException as e:         raise e     except WebDriverException as e:         raise e  Need verified element before to Solve this problem in function _find_element: ```     try:         element  = driver.find_element(*by)         if isinstance(element, str) or isinstance(element, dict):             raise StaleElementReferenceException("Invalid locator")         return element  ```

column3: firefox specified userprofile not being used.
column4: OS:   w10  Selenium Version:   3.0.2 - python 3.6 Browser:   Firefox 50.0 Geckodriver: 0.13  (latest versions as of writing)  ``` from selenium import webdriver profile = webdriver.FirefoxProfile(r'C:\Users\user\AppData\Roaming\Mozilla\Firefox\Profiles\o7nqiq0j.new')  ff = webdriver.Firefox(profile, firefox_binary=r"C:\Program Files (x86)\Mozilla Firefox\firefox.exe") ```  This doesn't load the profile from the directory specified, it will act as if no profile folder has been given. It will act as expected without giving a profile folder, that is, a new userprofile with a random name somewhere in a tmp folder.

column3: Implicitly wait in switching frame
column4: OS:   Ubuntu 16.04 LTS Windows 8  Browser:   firefox --version Mozilla Firefox 51.0.1 Mozilla Firefox 51.0.1(Nigthly windows)  Selenium Version:   geckodriver-v0.14.0-linux32 geckodriver-v0.13.0-linux32 geckodriver-v0.13.0-win32  I got one finding that if we use:  self.driver.implicitly_wait(30)  It works fine when to find and element, can take minimum 0 second to maximum 30 seconds. but in case of switching frame(window) it takes total maximum 30 seconds , means it always wait 30 before switching to frame.  e.g.         self.driver = webdriver.Firefox()         self.driver.implicitly_wait(30)         self.driver.get('https://somedomain.com')         self.driver.switch_to.frame('main')         self.driver.find_element_by_css_selector("[name=id]").send_keys('test')         self.driver.find_element_by_css_selector("[name=password]").send_keys('test')         self.driver.find_element_by_css_selector("[name=submit]").click()         self.driver.switch_to_default_content()   Thanks, Andrey

column3: Cannot shutdown the selenium stand alone server by sending  'shutDownSeleniumServer' command
column4: OS:   Tested only on Windows 7 and Mac 10.10. This issue is not OS specific.  **Selenium Version:**   3.0.0 ## Steps to reproduce - - Start the selenium standalone server  using   java -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.0.0.jar - Now open browser and issue command to shut down the server..     http://localhost:4444/selenium-server/driver/?cmd=shutDownSeleniumServer ## Expected Behavior -  You see OKOK in the browser window and the server shuts down ## Actual Behavior -  Server is not shutdown. The browser page displays the following text.  Whoops! The URL specified routes to this help page. For more information about Selenium Standalone please see the docs and/or visit the wiki. Or perhaps you are looking for the Selenium Standalone console. Happy Testing!  ![selenium](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2200830/19488704/e26ff96a-951c-11e6-95c3-0a237fafcd7f.png)

column3: [MacOS] GridLauncher starts on until.stalenessOf execution
column4: OS:   masOS Sierra 10.12.3 Selenium Version:   selenium-server-standalone-2.48.2, -3.0.1, -3.1.0 selenium-webdriver@2.48.2, @3.0.1, @3.1.0 Browser:   Chrome 54-56  Node.js v7 mocha@2.3.4, @3.1.2, @3.2.0  ## Expected Behavior - No GridLaunchV2 (V3) start.  ## Actual Behavior - GridLauncherV2(V3) starts each time if tests execute until.stalenessOf() Browser loses the focus. Further tests failed.  ## Steps to reproduce -  npm install selenium-webdriver npm install mocha npm install chromedriver download selenium-server-standalone  start selenium server: `java -Dwebdriver.chrome.driver=node_modules/chromedriver/lib/chromedriver/chromedriver -jar .selenium-server-standalone-3.1.0.jar -port 4444 &`  run the following test.js file: ``` let test = require('selenium-webdriver/testing'); let wd = require('selenium-webdriver'); let until = require('selenium-webdriver').until;  let driver = new wd.Builder()     .usingServer('http://localhost:4444/wd/hub')     .withCapabilities(wd.Capabilities.chrome())     .build();  test.describe('StalenessOf test', function () {      test.before(() => driver.manage().timeouts().implicitlyWait(60000)         .then(() => driver.manage().timeouts().pageLoadTimeout(60000))         .then(() => driver.manage().timeouts().setScriptTimeout(60000))         .then(() => driver.get('https://www.google.com/')));      test.it('Test', () => driver.findElement(wd.By.id('gb_70'))         .then(button => button.click()             .then(() => driver.wait(                 until.stalenessOf(button),                 30000,                 'SignIn button still presents'                 )             )             .then(() => driver.sleep(60000))         )     );      test.after(() => driver.quit()); }); ``` [screenshot](https://i.imgur.com/80wapyf.png)

column3: Web driver initialization failed, some tests hangs for 3h with
column4: OS:   LInux Selenium Version:   3.0.1 Browser:   Google Chrome  hey gus we are running selenium tests using selenium official images with hub. here is our compose file:  ``` version: '2' services:   selenium_hub:     image: selenium/hub:3.0.1     container_name: selenium_hub     privileged: true     volumes:       - '/dev/urandom:/dev/random'     ports:       - 4444:4444     environment:       - GRID_TIMEOUT=1800000       - GRID_MAX_SESSION=6       - GRID_BROWSER_TIMEOUT=1800000       - GRID_NODE_POLLING=10000       - GRID_CLEAN_UP_CYCLE=10000       - GRID_UNREGISTER_IF_STILL_DOWN_AFTER=60000       - JAVA_OPTS=-Xmx1024m     ulimits:       nproc: 163840       nofile:         soft: 163840         hard: 163840     restart: always     networks:       - selenium_grid_internal    chromenode:     image: selenium/node-chrome:3.0.1     privileged: true     depends_on:       - selenium_hub     volumes:       - '/dev/shm:/dev/shm'       - '/dev/urandom:/dev/random'     environment:       - NODE_MAX_INSTANCES=1       - NODE_MAX_SESSION=1       - NODE_REGISTER_CYCLE=5000       - NODE_PORT=5555       - HUB_PORT_4444_TCP_ADDR=selenium_hub       - HUB_PORT_4444_TCP_PORT=4444       - DBUS_SESSION_BUS_ADDRESS=/dev/null     ports:       - 5900       - 5555     networks:       - selenium_grid_internal     ulimits:       nproc: 163840       nofile:         soft: 163840         hard: 163840     restart: always  networks:     selenium_grid_internal: ``` we usually run 1 hub and 4 chrome nodes to parallelize our tests.  ``` org.openqa.selenium.remote.UnreachableBrowserException: Error communicating with the remote browser. It may have died. ```  But due to some reasons many of tests just hangs for **3h**  each and fail with this:  ``` 10:07:26 2017-02-18 08:07:26,225[TestNG]           [INFO ] [com.company.BaseTest 148]        - Thread id:23. Running : com.company.ImportRecursiveSubmoduleTest 13:05:48 2017-02-18 11:05:48,335[TestNG]           [ERROR] [c.c.ide.utils.DriverInitUtil 93]     - Web driver initialization failed: Could not start a new session. Possible causes are invalid address of the remote server or browser start-up failure. 13:05:48 Build info: version: '3.0.1', revision: '1969d75', time: '2016-10-18 09:49:13 -0700' 13:05:48 System info: host: 'slave4.company.com', ip: '127.0.0.1', os.name: 'Linux', os.arch: 'amd64', os.version: '3.10.0-327.28.2.el7.x86_64', java.version: '1.8.0_102' 13:05:48 Driver info: driver.version: RemoteWebDriver  ```  we have hundreds of tests and each iteration could take many days due to this huge **3h** hang or timeout.  Please help us to fix or workaround this issue somehow we will be really happy to try anything you may need or provide any info to solve this problem.

column3: selenium in centos is missing certain dependencies.
column4: OS:   centos 6.6 Selenium Version:   webdriver-manager 2.53.1 Browser:   chrome  As chrome doesn't support centos so I had installed it from [here](https://chrome.richardlloyd.org.uk/). My setup is like this. I have a job on remote server jenkins which uses Xvfb & Nodejs plugin(5.12). Selenium jar is ran from node_modules(I've tried running webdriver via cli). On ubuntu everything is perfect but on centos it tries to launch selenium instance but it fails. So after doing some research I found that centos 6.6 was missing new version of glibcxx3.1.14/15 and cxxabi libraries. And most of the threads online recommended to not update them as it might break the OS. If anyone faced this bug, please help.

column3: Can't run firefox in private mode.
column4: OS: w10 Selenium Version: 3.0.2 - python 3.6 Browser: Firefox 50.0 Geckodriver: 0.13  Neither using   ``` profile = webdriver.FirefoxProfile() profile.set_preference("browser.privatebrowsing.autostart", True) dr = webdriver.Firefox(profile) ```  OR  ``` b = FirefoxBinary(r"C:\Program Files (x86)\Mozilla Firefox\firefox.exe") b.add_command_line_options("-private") ff = webdriver.Firefox(profile, firefox_binary=r"C:\Program Files (x86)\Mozilla Firefox\firefox.exe") ```  the browser will be running in private mode.

column3: [ruby] Make service stopping more robust
column4: On Windows we might face random errors when starting/stopping service often. One example is an ephemeral port exhaustion which raises `Errno::ECONNRESET`. The errors are already documented in `SocketPoller` so we can simple rescue them and proceed without raising exception since after that process is stopped anyways.  Similar behavior is implemented in `Selenium::Server#stop`.  The failures have been caught while adding AppVeyor CI to Watir project. There, we have doctests which stop/start browser between every test: [build 6](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/p0deje/watir/build/6/job/04a6wc7uyt2p2887), [build 9](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/p0deje/watir/build/%239/job/9tpf5ed4hxru0xuw) and [build 10](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/p0deje/watir/build/%2310/job/dd984f493076osm6).  @titusfortner Please take a look. If you're ok with the changes, I'll merge it as soon as I test it thoroughly.

column3: Improve support for running large-scale grids
column4: My experience has been that the hub can be a real bottle neck when scaling above 50 nodes.  It appears others have run into scalability issues, too, based on projects like [seleniumkit/gridrouter](https://github.com/seleniumkit/gridrouter).  I can think of a couple potential solutions:  1. **The hub no longer proxies all requests** - Use the hub to request a new session (let it find and choose a node), return the hostname/IP of the node back to the client, then have the client talk directly to the node to run the test.  2. **Use a high performance layer 7 application proxy (like nginx)** - Maybe I am wrong, but I thought this might increase scalability of the hub component.  I feel like this could be a natural fit for layer 7 URL based routing.  The /session requests would get routed to the hub node, which would dynamically inject a URL path based routing rule /session/{session-id}/* which routes only to a single node (where the session was created).  I am sure that I am over-simplifying things, but I am curious what others think.  My goal is to run a grid with 250+ nodes.

column3: Selenium 3.0.0 does not wait for browser navigation with Firefox
column4: Meta - OS:  Windows 8 Selenium Version:  3.0.0 Browser:  Firefox 49.0.1  Expected Behavior - When changing pages the Web Driver should wait until the browser has finished navigation.  Actual Behavior - When changing pages the Web Driver does not wait until the browser has finished navigation.  Steps to Reproduce:  1. Clone the sample repository from https://github.com/FFLSH/Selenium3NoPageLoadWait 2. Uninstall any Firefox instances from your machine 3. Install Firefox 47.0.1 4. In the sample repository, open the SampleProject solution 5. In the Selenium2-53-1Sample project, open the UnitTest1 test class 4. Run the TestMethod1 test. 5. Note that the assertion correctly happens after the browser has navigated i.e. the web driver waits for navigation 6. Uninstall Firefox 47.0.1 7. Install Firefox 49.0.1 4. In the sample repository, open the SampleProject solution 5. In the Selenium-3-Sample project, open the UnitTest1 test class 4. Run the TestMethod1 test. 5. Note that the assertion incorrectly happens before the browser has navigated i.e. the web driver does not wait for navigation  This seems to be a regression between 2.53.1 and 3.0.0.

column3: Ruby Bridge and Capabilities specs
column4: Last time I tried to update Ruby's `Bridge` and `Capabilities` classes to improve Single Responsibility Principle I skipped too many steps. This code is just to document what features are currently supported (and is still in progress). *Right now I'm looking for reviews from requested individuals to make sure this is heading down the right path before I get too far ahead of myself (again)*.  The plan is to flesh out spec updates to each browser, do remote specs, and squash/commit. Then we can refactor the code to separate the concerns in the Bridge classes to handle service, capabilities and http client generation details in their correct classes. This will include pulling in @lmtierney's browser specific options code & getting things ready for Selenium 4.0  I removed a lot of the mocking here because we should isolate the parts that are getting tested, and what was there was combining both serialization & deserialization tests which don't seem necessary and were overly complicated. Deserialization tests especially don't really have real-world value because it *has to test only expectations of what is returned, which isn't useful if those values change.  1. To be tested in `browser/bridge_spec.rb` files: user inputs to `Bridge` are getting properly serialized to the driver calls (we can't readily isolate the `Capabilities` class creation from the `Capabilities` serialization because checking that `Capabilities` instances are the same uses `Capabilities#as_json` serialization.   2. To be tested in `browser/service_spec.rb` files: parameter inputs to `Service` that are specific to the browsers.  3. To be tested in `remote/capabilities_spec.rb` file: how `Capabilities` deserializes JSON from the driver / server are not browser specific so shouldn't need to be tested for each browser.   --- This change isâ€‚[](https://reviewable.io/reviews/seleniumhq/selenium/3729)

column3: Feature request - Show browser versions installed on nodes in grid console
column4: It would be useful to be able to see the browser versions installed on the nodes from the grid console.  We're tracking the latest Chrome releases and automatically installing them as they are released but sticking to ESR Firefox releases (due to not being ready to move to GeckoDriver just yet) and are regularly asked by developers about what versions of browsers we have installed on the nodes.

column3: Improve takeScreenshot performance in ie driver.
column4: IsSameColor method could take a lot of time, especially for pages with solid background (like login or search forms, where only several elements exists on the page). This becomes even worse if IEDriverServer runs several sessions in parallel. This happens beacause of GetPixel method calls winapi each time it is called. So we get rid of it and use already captured bytes to check screenshot.  - [X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: fix bug in proxy constructor that some properties are not proper set
column4: in the __init__ method of ```Proxy``` class,  ```socksProxy```, ```socksUsername```, ```socksPassword``` are set without go though their property setter, thus could cause potential problem.   The fix is simply set those properties with already defined setters :)

column3: C#: FirefoxDriver in legacy mode demands geckodriver to be in the PATH
column4: In C# binding, FirefoxDriver in legacy mode demands geckodriver to be in the PATH. It does not use it to drive the browser, but it fails if geckodriver is not available.  ``` FirefoxOptions options = new FirefoxOptions(); options.UseLegacyImplementation = true; driver = new FirefoxDriver(options); ```

column3: [java] Fix submitting form containing input with name or id "submit" (#3398)
column4: If form contains control with ID or NAME `submit`, it covers the `form.submit()` method, causing an error "form.submit is not a function".   This basically makes the submit() method on form element not working in this case.  See https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLFormElement/submit.  The original prototype call could be used instead as a workaround. See https://trackjs.com/blog/when-form-submit-is-not-a-function/ .  - [x] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: Running out of Java heap space during test
column4: I've got a test that gets run via Selenium Grid on Linux to a Windows node. In this test, I use a Selenium file_detector to send a large file (about 1.6GB) from the running machine to the node: ```     $browser.file_detector = lambda do |args|       str = args.first.to_s       str if File.exist?(str)     end ``` I  can perform this test with small files no problem. But when I send this larger file, my heap runs out of space.  ``` [remote server] org.openqa.grid.web.servlet.handler.RequestHandler(RequestHandler.java):138:in `process': cannot forward the request Java heap space (org.openqa.grid.common.exception.GridException) (Selenium::WebDriver::Error::UnknownError) 	from [remote server] org.openqa.grid.web.servlet.DriverServlet(DriverServlet.java):83:in `process' 	from [remote server] org.openqa.grid.web.servlet.DriverServlet(DriverServlet.java):67:in `doPost' ```  On both the node and hub machines, I'm running Grid with an increased heap size:  `/usr/bin/java -d64 -Xms512m -Xmx24g blahblahblah`  While a 1.6GB file is large, I don't understand why with a 24GB heap space I'm still running out. It shouldn't need this much memory to base64 decode a file.  Please help!  OS:   - Grid Hub: Ubuntu 16.04 - Grid Node: Windows 10 Selenium Version: 2.53 Browser: Chrome

column3: Java: Refactor page factory to be more extensible
column4: I've been using selenium for a few years and one thing that's always been at the back of my mind is the PageFactory. Whenever I need to write custom annotations for someone to use instead of the FindBy variants, I find that the process is somewhat difficult to make extensible in a manor that chains annotation rules.  So say, I want to use the default built-in decorators, my own decorators, and then a third party's (EG: Selenide as an example) the code becomes soupy and I find that for whatever given project I'm re-inventing or outright copying the original code to get some sort of builder-pattern to enable chaining all of these decorators so PageObjects can have all annotations work as you'd expect them to.  Would SeleniumHQ be open to such a refactor? What would be an acceptable approach and what requirements would be needed? Some obvious ones I can thing of might be  - Keep the original PageFactory available for back-wards compatibility - The new extendable page factory must be static like the original one (not a personal fan of this)  - The new extendable page factory may be an instance so it can act within dependency injection frameworks (as an alternative to being static)  etc.  I'm more than willing to do the work on it, but I wanted to run this by people first before doing something that would result in a rejected pull-request.

column3: Cannot stop nodejs/express server
column4: I'm trying to use selenium to test my express application. I've noticed one strange behaviour. It seems like I cannot stop my express server it just stalls. I'm using selenium-webdriver in nodejs and to communicates with a docker container hosting selenium https://github.com/elgalu/docker-selenium. ```ts const server = express(); nodeServer = server.listen(port);  // Run some selenium test  function close(): Promise {     return new Promise((resolve) => {          nodeServer.close(resolve); // It never gets resolved     }); } ```  My test cases are written so that each test case needs to restart the server.   Though, a workaround I use, even though it solves the problem it creates an another, is to force close the server by emitting a close event:  ```ts return new Promise((resolve) => {     nodeServer.close(resolve); // It never gets resolved     nodeServer.emit('close'); }); ``` Though, this doesn't work since it remembers the state or all the routes that was in the previous session and it doesn't apply the new routes.  I can close the server if I call `driver.quit()` before, though there seems to be some timing issues with the `driver.quit()`, that I'm always experiencing. I tried https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/webdriver/IgZWFgDIGzw this as well. Though I think there is some issues with selenium. I have very long sleeping times. And they don't seem to take effect.

column3: How can I detect a GeoLocation Permission Request when using Selenium
column4: I'd like to be able to tell when a given website I'm accessing through a Selenium-enabled browser is asking permission for my geolocation, like this [one](https://wtfsigfd.com/).  I'm aware that a number of issues have to do with how to handle the popups that are related to permissions requests, since they're not WebElements per se and so cannot be interacted with using Selenium, but I'm only interested in knowing whether a geolocation request was made to my browser as runtime - no need to clear the popup associated with that request.  ![screen shot 2016-11-01 at 12 08 23 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6109621/19896809/f42c9efa-a02b-11e6-9efd-18b4472689b3.png)  OS:  macOS Sierra 10.12 Selenium Version:  2.53.1 w. ChromeDriver 2.25 Browser:  Chrome 54.0.2840.71 (64-bit)

column3: Improvement at interface in WebElement and SearchContext
column4: I was wondering if is possible to change the return the generic type for this method below of the interfaces SearchContext and WebElement:  > List< WebElement> findElements(By by)   to   > List findElements(By by);  ```java import java.util.Arrays; import java.util.List;  import org.openqa.selenium.By; import org.openqa.selenium.StaleElementReferenceException; import org.openqa.selenium.Dimension; import org.openqa.selenium.OutputType; import org.openqa.selenium.Point; import org.openqa.selenium.Rectangle; import org.openqa.selenium.WebDriver; import org.openqa.selenium.WebDriverException; import org.openqa.selenium.WebElement; import org.openqa.selenium.internal.WrapsDriver; import org.openqa.selenium.internal.WrapsElement;  public class NewWebElement implements WebElement, WrapsDriver, WrapsElement {  	private WebElement wrappedElement;  	public NewWebElement(WebElement wrappedElement) { 		this.wrappedElement = wrappedElement; 	} 	 	public boolean isPresent() { 		try { 			this.getWrappedElement().isEnabled(); 			 			return true; 		} catch (StaleElementReferenceException e) { 			return false; 		} 	}  	/** 	 * I want to created a class to extends the functionality of WebElement	 	 * Today because of the interface the code List will not compile although the NewWebElement implements WebElement. 	 * If the return chenged to List will be possible create new custom functionalities.  	 */ 	@Override 	public List findElements(By by) { 		List webElements = this.getWrappedElement().findElements(by); 		NewWebElement[] newWebElements = new NewWebElement[webElements.size()]; 		 		for (int i = 0; i < newWebElements.length; i++) 			newWebElements[i] = new NewWebElement(webElements.get(i)); 		 		return Arrays.asList(newWebElements); 	} 	 	// Add unimplemented methods  } ```  ```java import org.openqa.selenium.By; import org.openqa.selenium.WebDriver; import org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver;  public class Sample {  	public static void main(String[] args) { 		WebDriver driver = new FirefoxDriver(); 		driver.get("https://www.google.com"); 		 		WebElement body = driver.findElement(By.tagName("body")); 		By search = By.id("lst-ib"); 		 		// I will be able to find within an element and access my custom methods 		 		new newWebElement(body).findElements(search).get(0).isPresent(); 	} 	 } ```

column3: Attach to IE browser not spawned by selenium
column4: I wanted to automate the LoadRunner scripting as the workflows are large and needs changes with every build, my plan is to launch the IE brouswer using vugen and then start a selenium script for the same workflow and attach the webdriver with the running browser of vugen. This will help me record the flow in LoadRunner. I see a post that this is possible with Selenium2 but so far i could not able to do so, I tried with   CODE: for (String handle : driver.getWindowHandles()) { driver.switchTo().window(handle); } but this is returning the connection key of the browser launched by WebDriver and not the browser which is already opened by LoadRunner.  Any help on this will be highly appreciated. Thanks.Rajarshee

column3: missing dependency on geckodriver
column4: I understand the problem is I need to install geckodriver. but my point is your documentation doesn't mention this, and Googling brings up a whole lot of confusing and conflicting information. it wasn't until I tried to open this issue that I got a pointer to the info I needed.  solution? I don't know. I'd say make the `pip install selenium` fail with an appropriate error message, if no suitable drivers are found. or at a minimum, give a hint in the documentation at https://pypi.python.org/pypi/selenium, before example 0, that geckodriver is a requirement, and give a pointer to https://github.com/mozilla/geckodriver and/or https://github.com/mozilla/geckodriver/releases. thanks. ## Meta -  OS:  Debian GNU/Linux    Selenium Version:      Browser:      Browser Version:      jcomeau@aspire:/usr/src$ firefox --version Mozilla Firefox 45.0 ## Expected Behavior -  Example 0 on https://pypi.python.org/pypi/selenium should work. ## Actual Behavior -  fails at `browser = webdriver.Firefox()` ## Steps to reproduce -    (virtualenv) jcomeau@aspire:~/rentacoder/jmol$ (cd molecules && python manage.py shell) Python 3.5.2 (default, Jul  5 2016, 11:33:36)  [GCC 5.4.0 20160609] on linux Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information. (InteractiveConsole)  > > > import selenium > > > selenium.**version** > > > '3.0.1' > > > from selenium import webdriver > > > browser = webdriver.Firefox() > > > Traceback (most recent call last): > > >   File "/home/jcomeau/rentacoder/jmol/virtualenv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/common/service.py", line 64, in start > > >     stdout=self.log_file, stderr=self.log_file) > > >   File "/usr/lib/python3.5/subprocess.py", line 947, in **init** > > >     restore_signals, start_new_session) > > >   File "/usr/lib/python3.5/subprocess.py", line 1551, in _execute_child > > >     raise child_exception_type(errno_num, err_msg) > > > FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'geckodriver'  During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:  Traceback (most recent call last):   File "", line 1, in    File "/home/jcomeau/rentacoder/jmol/virtualenv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/firefox/webdriver.py", line 135, in **init**     self.service.start()   File "/home/jcomeau/rentacoder/jmol/virtualenv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/common/service.py", line 71, in start     os.path.basename(self.path), self.start_error_message) selenium.common.exceptions.WebDriverException: Message: 'geckodriver' executable needs to be in PATH.

column3: ExpectedConditions.presenceOfElementLocated: throws NoSuchElementException
column4: I tried writing a simple test that would first simply wait for the presence of an element on the page but the first check using a `FluentWait` throws `NoSuchElementException` (I expect no such exception to be thrown):  ``` java new FluentWait(webDriver)         .withTimeout(5, TimeUnit.MINUTES)         .until(ExpectedConditions.presenceOfElementLocated(By.name("zipCode"))) ```  I looked in [ExpectedConditionsTest.java](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/92cf77420dbc25a01a66dfe1d3b2572029a5424a/java/client/test/org/openqa/selenium/support/ui/ExpectedConditionsTest.java) but didn't find any tests for `ExpectedConditions.presenceOfElementLocated`. :disappointed:   I then checked in [ExpectedConditions.java](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/92cf77420dbc25a01a66dfe1d3b2572029a5424a/java/client/src/org/openqa/selenium/support/ui/ExpectedConditions.java) and it appears to catch the exception at one point but then re-throw it unlike `ExpectedCondtiions.presenceOfNestedElementLocatedBy`.

column3: WebDriverEventListener beforeScript/afterScript: do not provide args/result
column4: I think the `EventFiringWebDriver` is a nice addition to the support lib but although `beforeScript` and `afterScript` provide the script being executed they do not provide the args or result object being used. Adding these would be very beneficial.

column3: Firefox hangs longtime/forever in page loading state during execution of selenium tests
column4: I have couple of selenium test code written in Java (run from cucumber), When I ran the test in jenkins using the firefox 45.0.1 the build gets through several tests and browser just hangs/stuck forever without timeout. It is widely reproducible in Jenkins and firefox hangs at random pages of a application during execution of testcase. Apparently there are no client-server comm problem and the firefox client has received the response and hangs internally before rendering the response.(We have no clues why firefox stays there longtime/forever as log, jstack, ps, server health has no weird behavior).  Issue persists even after changing selenium & firefox versions to avoid compatibility issues.  Jenkins version : 1.629 Selenium version: 2.53.1 OS: Cent-OS 6.5 Browser: Firefox Browser version: 45.0.1

column3: WebDriver Error Cannot use 'in' operator to search for 'String' in false
column4:
I have been using selenium webdriver with protractor for more than a year now and recently after updating to the newest versions of both protractor(5.0.0) and selenium-webdriver(3.0.1), i got an error that i have never encountered before. As stated in the title my error is - "WebDriver Error Cannot use 'in' operator to search for 'String' in false". I am doing everything in the code as always, but even my old tests which were working correctly and were used everyday, don't work now. The tests starts and navigate to the page correctly(which is the first step in the test), but everything after that fails no matter if it is only clicking, or typing. I have tried re-installing both selenium webdriver and protractor, tried different version of Node too, but no success.  I tried searching everywhere, but did not find someone having the same problem as me, submitted a question on stackoverflow too, but no answer for more than 3 days now.I have all my tests at work failing for more than a week now. Please help.  Here is my code  The spec.ts file:  describe('102001 - External Payments - own portfolio; recurring - no end date', function () {      var LoginPage = require('./Page/Login_Page/Login_page.js');     var OverviewPage = require('./Page/Overview_Page/Overview_page.js');     var BeleggenPage = require('./Page/Beleggen_Page/Beleggen_Page.js');     var BepaalJeKennisprofielPage = require('./Page/BepaalJeKennisprofiel_Page/BepaalJeKennisprofiel_Page.js');     var AcepteerDeVoorwaardenPage = require('./Page/AcepteerDeVoorwaarden_Page/AcepteerDeVoorwaarden_Page.js');     var column3: Selenium GRID | Nodes with the same name cannot connect on the HUB
column4: I have a very big problem with selenium grid after updating to selenium 3. I have 70+ win10 nodes created from one template (using VMware ESXi) and each of them has the same name   ![screen shot 2017-01-19 at 11 28 25 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8803779/22103559/e832c504-de3b-11e6-9af5-917cc3eeecc3.png)  they are trying to connect on the HUB, but only ONE is able to connect on the HUB, all others are refused (500 Internal Server Error). I suppose because all have the same ID (computer name)  ![screen shot 2017-01-19 at 11 31 07 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8803779/22103786/c6f42a30-de3c-11e6-9693-d647714a248e.png)  before updating, with selenium 2.53.1, my nodes were able to connect successfully. they are connected with different IDs (IP+port)  ![screen shot 2017-01-19 at 11 32 07 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8803779/22103985/862a594c-de3d-11e6-9142-be1e835e2de5.png)  Please help.

column3: Exception on IE11 when move mouse on canvas with protractor
column4: I have a code to draw on canvas on IE11:  ```         public drawAnnotation(points) {         let canvas = element(by.id(`canvas`).getWebElement();         browser.actions()           .mouseMove(canvas, points[0])           .mouseDown()           .mouseMove(canvas, points[1])           .mouseUp()           .perform();       }; ```  And config:  ```       {         'browserName': 'internet explorer',         'platform': 'ANY',         'version': 11,         'nativeEvents': false,         'unexpectedAlertBehaviour': 'accept',         'ignoreProtectedModeSettings': true,         'enablePersistentHover': true,         'disable-popup-blocking': true       }, ```  I tested on Chrome and Edge it run ok, but IE11 it also draw ok but have expection occurred:   ```         - Failed:  (WARNING: The server did not provide any stacktrace information)     Command duration or timeout: 94 milliseconds     Build info: version: '3.1.0', revision: '86a5d70', time: '2017-02-16 07:57:44 -0800'     System info: host: 'os.name: 'Windows 10', os.arch: 'amd64', os.version: '10.0', java.version: '1.8.0_66'     Driver info: org.openqa.selenium.ie.InternetExplorerDriver     Capabilities [{browserAttachTimeout=0, ie.enableFullPageScreenshot=true, enablePersistentHover=false, ie.forceCreateProcessApi=false, ie.forceShellWindowsApi=false, pageLoadStrategy=normal, ignoreZoomSetting=false, ie.fileUploadDialogTimeout=3000, version=11, platform=WINDOWS, nativeEvents=false, ie.ensureCleanSession=false, elementScrollBehavior=0, ie.browserCommandLineSwitches=, requireWindowFocus=false, browserName=internet explorer, initialBrowserUrl=http://localhost:18534/, javascriptEnabled=true, ignoreProtectedModeSettings=true, enableElementCacheCleanup=true, unexpectedAlertBehaviour=accept}]     Session ID: 8266a897-5284-41dc-bbdf-73dc565fa053     *** Element info: {Using=css selector, value=*[id="canvas"]} ```  How can I fix it?

column3: Set firefox profile from pre-existing browser profile or set extension protractor
column4: I have 2 ways set firefox profile:  > var makeFirefoxProfile = function (preferenceMap) { >   var profile = new firefox.Profile("./ozbzfc4i.automation"); >   for (var key in preferenceMap) { >     profile.setPreference(key, preferenceMap[key]); >   } >    >   return q.resolve({ >     browserName: 'firefox', >     marionette: true, >     firefox_profile: profile >   }); > };  and code load web extension:  > var makeFirefoxProfile = function (preferenceMap) { >   var profile = new firefox.Profile(); >   for (var key in preferenceMap) { >     profile.setPreference(key, preferenceMap[key]); >   } >   profile.addExtension('./firebug.xpi'); >    >   return q.resolve({ >     browserName: 'firefox', >     marionette: true, >     firefox_profile: profile >   }); > }; **But it cannot set profile and browser opens multiple tabs when run, not single tab.** I follow this article: http://seleniumhq.github.io/selenium/docs/api/javascript/module/selenium-webdriver/firefox/index.html I don't know how wrong???

column3: Wrong description of Ruby Binding Wiki article
column4: I found the following samlpe script in the [Ruby Binding Wiki](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/wiki/Ruby-Bindings).  ```ruby driver.switch_to.frame "some-frame" # name or id ```  But frame method for Ruby binding accepts only "id" arugment according to [the API document](http://www.rubydoc.info/gems/selenium-webdriver/0.0.28/Selenium%2FWebDriver%2FTargetLocator%3Aframe), and the sample script should be like the following:  ```ruby driver.switch_to.frame "some-frame" # id ```

column3: Typo in documentation for python api for "save_screenshot" method. Want to fix it.
column4: I found a typo here: https://seleniumhq.github.io/selenium/docs/api/py/webdriver_remote/selenium.webdriver.remote.webdriver.html#selenium.webdriver.remote.webdriver.WebDriver.save_screenshot  The method is `save_screenshot` and but it's usage is using `get_screenshot_as_file` as can be seen here ![screen shot 2017-03-14 at 2 46 33 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3696327/23893798/cd2b31a6-08c5-11e7-8a53-48d674dd2592.png)  I wanted to fix it by modifying the docs for `save_screenshot` method but `save_screenshot` is just an alias to `get_screenshot_as_file`. Therefore I could not change the docs for it.  How can I fix this typo?  Thanks

column3: selenium-webdriver stuck when init session
column4: I don't know is capybara bug or selenium-webdriver bug  ## Meta - OS:   ``` roroco@roroco ~/Dropbox/rbs/ro_wemedia $ lsb_release -a No LSB modules are available. Distributor ID:	LinuxMint Description:	Linux Mint 18 Sarah Release:	18 Codename:	sarah ```  Selenium Version:   ruby selenium-webdriver ``` roroco@roroco ~/Dropbox/rbs/ro_wemedia $ bundle show selenium /home/roroco/.rbenv/versions/2.3.3/lib/ruby/gems/2.3.0/gems/selenium-webdriver-3.0.2 ```   Browser:     Browser Version:    ``` roroco@roroco ~/Dropbox/rbs/ro_wemedia $ google-chrome -version Google Chrome 55.0.2883.87  ```  ## Expected Behavior -  show chrome window  ## Actual Behavior -  stuck when init session  ## Steps to reproduce -   ``` #!/usr/bin/env ruby require 'capybara'  Capybara.register_driver :crm do |app|   Capybara::Selenium::Driver.new(app, browser: :chrome) end  se = Capybara::Session.new(:crm) se.visit("google.com") ```

column3: Compilation error after update Function/Predicate imports from Guava to Java 8
column4: I could not use the 3.1.0 and 3.2.0 versions. It breaks the compilation of this code from my tests (in Scala):      def explicitWait[T](condition: ExpectedCondition[T], duration: Duration = Configuration.TIMEOUT_SHORT)(implicit driver: WebDriver): Unit = {         val wait = new WebDriverWait(driver, duration.getSeconds)         wait.until(condition)     }  The error is:      DomService.scala:100: type mismatch;         found   : com.google.common.base.Function[org.openqa.selenium.WebDriver,T]         required: java.util.function.Function[_ >: org.openqa.selenium.WebDriver, ?]                 wait.until(condition)  As far as I could see, recently there was a change in `FluentWait` class where the `Function`, `Predicate` and `Supplier` imports were changed to use Java 8, instead of Guava.  It seems that the `ExpectedCondition` class didn't have its imports updated for the class `Function`, which is still using Guava.  Once `WebDriverWait`extends `FluentWait`, this should be the reason I'm getting the error.  The change for `FluentWait` is [here](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/commit/b2aa9fd534f7afbcba319231bb4bce85f825ef09#diff-84f235517bcdcf4ccd574208e8d02c9e).

column3: FirefoxProfile fails remotely

(RemoteWebDriver.java:116) at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver. (FirefoxDriver.java:259) at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver. (FirefoxDriver.java:247) at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver. (FirefoxDriver.java:242) at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver. (FirefoxDriver.java:135) at sun.reflect.GeneratedConstructorAccessor12.newInstance (None:-1) at sun.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance (DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45) at java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance (Constructor.java:423) at org.openqa.selenium.remote.server.FirefoxDriverProvider.callConstructor (FirefoxDriverProvider.java:86) at org.openqa.selenium.remote.server.FirefoxDriverProvider.newInstance (FirefoxDriverProvider.java:64) at org.openqa.selenium.remote.server.DefaultDriverFactory.newInstance (DefaultDriverFactory.java:60) at org.openqa.selenium.remote.server.DefaultSession$BrowserCreator.call (DefaultSession.java:222) at org.openqa.selenium.remote.server.DefaultSession$BrowserCreator.call (DefaultSession.java:209) at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run (FutureTask.java:266) at org.openqa.selenium.remote.server.DefaultSession$1.run (DefaultSession.java:176) at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker (ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1142) at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run (ThreadPoolExecutor.java:617) at java.lang.Thread.run (Thread.java:745)  **Notes:** Without specifying a profile, the error is not happening caps = webdriver.DesiredCapabilities.FIREFOX caps["marionette"] = False driver_ = webdriver.Remote(desired_capabilities=caps, command_executor=hub_ip) set_browser_size(driver_, 1920, 1080)  With the same exact configuration (browser and selenium server versions), but running on MacOS (OS X El Capitan) is also not happening. column3: Executing window.scrollTo may not be firing JS Events.
column4: I apologize in advance if this is not a Selenium issue. I tried with several browsers to be sure it was not a browser-specific issue, and tried the exact same script that I am executing ("window.scrollTo(0,0);") directly through the browser's js consoles to ensure it was not a problem with the site I am trying this out with.  I have googled far and wide, and cannot find a solution. Any help is great!  ## Meta - OS:  Windows 10 - 64 Bit Selenium Version:  2.53.1, JS SDK Browser:  Edge, Chrome Browser Version:  Edge 14/38.14393.0.0, Chrome 55.0.2883.75  ## Expected Behavior - Executing window.scrollTo(0,0); should fire javascript scroll events. Example:  1. Browse to http://www.infinitiusa.com/suv/qx80/models-specs.html  2. Scroll near the bottom of the page, so that the header looks as such: ![screen shot 2017-01-25 at 4 45 07 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7744158/22314208/aa91e34c-e31d-11e6-8611-ec1fbe190f5b.png) 3. Open the devtools console in your browser 4. Submit the command: window.scrollTo(0,0); 5. Notice you are returned to the top of the page, and it looks as it did when you were originally at the top:    The same behaviour is expected when running the following in webdriver: `driver.executeScript("window.scrollTo(0,0);");`  ## Actual Behavior - Executing window.scrollTo(0,0); may not be firing javascript events. The expected behaviour works when testing directly in the browser (tested on a few browsers), but does not work as expected when running the same tasks through WebDriver.  ## Steps to reproduce - 1. Browse to http://www.infinitiusa.com/suv/qx80/models-specs.html  2. Scroll near the bottom of the page, so that the header looks as such: ![screen shot 2017-01-25 at 4 45 07 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7744158/22314208/aa91e34c-e31d-11e6-8611-ec1fbe190f5b.png) 3. Run the folllowing webdriver command: `driver.executeScript("window.scrollTo(0,0);");` 4. Notice you are returned to the top of the page, and the floating elements look funky:

column3: [Question] How to kill many geckodriver.exe processes?
column4: I am using Windows 10 pro x64, Firefox 50.x, Java 8, Selenium 3.0.1.  ``` public RemoteWebDriver remoteWebDriver; //... System.setProperty("webdriver.gecko.driver", browserWebDriverFilePath); DesiredCapabilities capabilities = DesiredCapabilities.firefox(); capabilities.setCapability("marionette", true); remoteWebDriver = new FirefoxDriver(capabilities); remoteWebDriver.manage().timeouts().implicitlyWait(30, TimeUnit.SECONDS); remoteWebDriver.manage().window().maximize(); //... remoteWebDriver.quit(); ```  ![gecko](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1328316/20461847/7b013cc2-af3d-11e6-8fae-993b4bb80d4b.PNG)  How to kill process of **geckodriver.exe** processes?

Possible causes are invalid address of the remote server or browser start-up failure." as error message.  following is the piece of code i have added in my selenium scripts:  System.setProperty("webdriver.gecko.driver", "src\\test\\resources\\geckodriver.exe"); driver=new RemoteWebDriver(new URL("http://localhost:4444/wd/hub"),DesiredCapabilities.firefox());

column3: JRuby compatibility
column4: I am using selenium 2.53.4 on JRuby 9.1.5.0 with Capybara 2.9.2. I get test failures for some tests. Although the failing tests are always the same, the exception is different each time. It's usually one of these: - NoMethodError: undefined method `+' for nil:NilClass - IOError: closed stream - Net::HTTPBadResponse: wrong status line: "Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8"  The stack trace is always:  ```      ....... [some jruby stack frames that rspec refuses to display] ........      # ./features/build/tmp/jrubyExec/gems/selenium-webdriver-2.53.4/lib/selenium/webdriver/remote/http/default.rb:111:in `response_for'      # ./features/build/tmp/jrubyExec/gems/selenium-webdriver-2.53.4/lib/selenium/webdriver/remote/http/default.rb:60:in `request'      # ./features/build/tmp/jrubyExec/gems/selenium-webdriver-2.53.4/lib/selenium/webdriver/remote/http/common.rb:59:in `call'      # ./features/build/tmp/jrubyExec/gems/selenium-webdriver-2.53.4/lib/selenium/webdriver/remote/bridge.rb:649:in `raw_execute'      # ./features/build/tmp/jrubyExec/gems/selenium-webdriver-2.53.4/lib/selenium/webdriver/remote/bridge.rb:627:in `execute'      # ./features/build/tmp/jrubyExec/gems/selenium-webdriver-2.53.4/lib/selenium/webdriver/remote/bridge.rb:604:in `find_elements_by'      # ./features/build/tmp/jrubyExec/gems/selenium-webdriver-2.53.4/lib/selenium/webdriver/common/search_context.rb:84:in `find_elements'      # ./features/build/tmp/jrubyExec/gems/capybara-2.9.2/lib/capybara/selenium/node.rb:155:in `find_css'      # ./features/build/tmp/jrubyExec/gems/capybara-2.9.2/lib/capybara/node/base.rb:103:in `find_css'      # ./features/build/tmp/jrubyExec/gems/capybara-2.9.2/lib/capybara/queries/selector_query.rb:116:in `block in resolve_for'      # ./features/build/tmp/jrubyExec/gems/capybara-2.9.2/lib/capybara/node/base.rb:81:in `synchronize'      # ./features/build/tmp/jrubyExec/gems/capybara-2.9.2/lib/capybara/queries/selector_query.rb:114:in `resolve_for'      # ./features/build/tmp/jrubyExec/gems/capybara-2.9.2/lib/capybara/node/finders.rb:38:in `block in find'      # ./features/build/tmp/jrubyExec/gems/capybara-2.9.2/lib/capybara/node/base.rb:85:in `synchronize'      # ./features/build/tmp/jrubyExec/gems/capybara-2.9.2/lib/capybara/node/finders.rb:33:in `find'      # ./features/build/tmp/jrubyExec/gems/capybara-2.9.2/lib/capybara/session.rb:735:in `block in find'      # ./features/build/tmp/jrubyExec/gems/capybara-2.9.2/lib/capybara/dsl.rb:52:in `block in find'      ......... [some irrelevant user stack frames] ...... ```  Note that the line numbers in `default.rb` might not be correct since I had added some debug output. More specifically I changed this:  ``` rb def response_for(request)   http.request request end ```  ... to this...  ``` rb def response_for(request)   begin     print 'doing... '     result = http.request request     puts 'done.'     return result   rescue Exception => e     puts 'exception'   end end ```  Part of the output was:  ``` doing... done. doing... done. doing... done. doing... doing... done. exception ```  I would assume this is something that does not happen in MRI. But being GIL-free JRuby is affected. The code in this PR resolves the problem for me.  I am not sure if this isn't something that should be fixed in Capybara. However, as far as I can see, the code in this class is not meant to be used with HTTP pipelining (I believe the `persistent.rb` class is meant for that). So it could make some sense to have the monitor synchronized block there. - [x] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: Getting connection refused exception with MarionetteDriver and selenium
column4: I am trying to use Firefox with selenium where the I get the GeckoDriver something like this :       String Xport = System.getProperty("lmportal.xvfb.id", ":1");         final File firefoxPath = new File(System.getProperty("lmportal.deploy.firefox.path", firefoxBinaryPath));         FirefoxBinary firefoxBinary = new FirefoxBinary();         firefoxBinary.setEnvironmentProperty("DISPLAY", Xport);         final int marionettePort = PortProber.findFreePort();         final int webDriverPort = PortProber.findFreePort();         GeckoDriverService.Builder builder = new GeckoDriverService.Builder() {             @Override             protected ImmutableList createArgs() {                 ImmutableList.Builder argsBuilder = ImmutableList.builder();                 argsBuilder.addAll(super.createArgs());                 argsBuilder.add(String.format("--marionette-port=%d", marionettePort));                 return argsBuilder.build();             }         };         builder.usingPort(webDriverPort);         builder.usingDriverExecutable(new File(geckoDriverPath));         GeckoDriverService driverService = builder.build();         try {             driverService.start();         } catch (IOException e) {             logger.error(e);         }         waitUntilReady(webDriverPort, marionettePort, DEFAULT_GECKODRIVER_TIMEOUT);  But when I try to get RemoteWebDriver instance like this :      try{         RemoteWebDriver webDriver = new MarionetteDriver(driverService, desiredCapabilities);     }catch (Exception ex) {             logger.error("[MOZILLA BROWSER] Killing webdriver port:" + driverService.getWebDriverPort(), ex);             releasePort(webDriverPort);         }    Then column3: Potential bug with catch() for promises (JavaScript)
column4: I am on Node.js v6.9.5, using "selenium-webdriver": "^3.3.0",   with `promise.USE_PROMISE_MANAGER` set to `true` =>  I have this sequence:  ```js   before('upload file', {timeout: 30000}, h => {       driver.get(cdthost + '/#!/home');       let acq = acqs[0].companyName === 'DUMMY_ACQ' ? acqs[1] : acqs[0];       let acqId = acq._id;       assert(acqId, 'acqId is not defined.');       console.log(' => Acquisition name => ', acq.companyName);       // on the next line we wait to ensure that the page is loaded       driver.wait(until.elementLocated(By.id(`open-editing-acqId-${acqId}`)), 5000).then(function(){         console.log(`XXX open-editing-acqId-${acqId} has been located.`);       });       driver.findElement(By.id(`open-editing-acqId-${acqId}`)).click();       let file = path.resolve($root + '/csv-data/IT-DE-Jasper.csv');       console.log(' => file to be loaded => ', file);       let el = driver.findElement(By.id(`import-file-acqId-${acqId}`));       driver.wait(until.elementIsVisible(el), 2000).then(function(){         console.log(`XXX import-file-acqId-${acqId} is now visible`);       });       el.sendKeys(file);       driver.findElement(By.id(`submit-file-acqId-${acqId}`)).click();       return Promise.delay(1000)       .catch(function (err) {         console.error('\n\n', ' => Caught promise rejection => ', err.stack || err);         return Promise.reject(err);       });     }); ```  **what's very strange is that  XXX is does not get logged, why would that be?** everything else gets logged fine, it's not an issue with template literals as I am on node v6.9.5.

column3: Selenium Webdriver java with ( . ) getting replaced

The program works well but there is a problem with Computers with Hebrew Language installed.  for example on :  sendKeys("blabla@gmail.com"); the "." gets replaced with a Hebrew letter "×¥" which is the same place of the "." on the keyboard.  Did someone face this problem before ?

column3: selenium-webdriver 3.3 broken with the latest release of geckodriver (0.14)
column4: https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/commit/ccc442ea1ecaacfdd71e5110cdd81976b76cacbe broke the use of selenium-webdriver with geckodriver 0.14 (latest current release) since the sessionId returned is not wrapped in `value` when creating a new session.

column3: Latest selenium-webdriver package requires Node.js 6.9.0, but Node.js 4 is still in its active LTS period
column4: https://github.com/nodejs/LTS/#lts-schedule  Node.js 4 will still be an active LTS release for some time.

column3: [js] Documentation: broken link to isElementPresent() that was removed in 3.0.0-beta1

column3: Testng maven dependency for selenium-leg-rc ... but should there be?
column4: http://central.maven.org/maven2/org/seleniumhq/selenium/selenium-leg-rc/3.3.1/selenium-leg-rc-3.3.1.pom  Downstream Projects that pull this in have a problem in that some test-runners subsequently see the testing classes and invoke test-suite collection logic looking for testing annotated classes. Spoiler: those downstream maven projects might be using JUnit not TestNG (and a few fine grained permutations of problem).

column3: Should selenium-api be a dependency in selenium-java (jars, maven poms) ?
column4: http://central.maven.org/maven2/org/seleniumhq/selenium/selenium-java/3.3.1/selenium-java-3.3.1.pom doesn't cite selenium-api as a dependency, and it should perhaps.

column3: WebDriver Error Cannot use 'in' operator to search for 'String' in false
column4:
Hi,  I am posting my problem for the second time. Sorry for that, but i have a lot more information about the problem. I have been using selenium webdriver with protractor for more than a year now and recently after updating to Selenium 3, i got an error that i have never encountered before. As stated in the title my error is - "WebDriver Error Cannot use 'in' operator to search for 'String' in false". I am doing everything in the code as always, but even my old tests which were working correctly and were used everyday, don't work now. The tests starts and navigate to the page correctly(which is the first step in the test), but everything after that fails no matter if it is only clicking, or typing. I found out that this problem only occurs on the web sites that were developed by the company i am working at. I did not have any problems running tests on any other sites. We tried disabling the Javascript of one of our web sites and the tests started working correctly, so the problem is in the javascript of the site. Here is link for one of out sites that is live and working as expected, but the tests started to fail after update to Selenium 3 - https://www.arubabank.com/ .  ```     import org.apache.commons.lang.SystemUtils;     import org.openqa.selenium.Proxy;     import org.openqa.selenium.WebDriver;     import org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxBinary;     import org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver;     import org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxProfile;     import org.openqa.selenium.firefox.GeckoDriverService;     import org.openqa.selenium.remote.CapabilityType;     import org.openqa.selenium.remote.DesiredCapabilities;      import com.google.common.collect.ImmutableMap;      public class TestProxy     {       public static void main(String[] args)       {          if (args.length == 0)         {           System.out.println("usage: IP port");           System.exit(-1);         }          String proxyServer = args[0];         int proxyPort = Integer.parseInt(args[1]);          try         {           TestProxy test = new TestProxy();           test.TestDriver(proxyServer, proxyPort);         } catch (IOException e)         {           e.printStackTrace();         }           }        private void TestDriver(String aHost, int aPort) throws IOException       {         FirefoxProfile firefoxProfile = new FirefoxProfile();          firefoxProfile.setEnableNativeEvents(true);          WebDriver driver = null;         GeckoDriverService service = null;          if (SystemUtils.IS_OS_LINUX)         {           FirefoxBinary firefoxBinary = new FirefoxBinary(new File("/home/ubuntu/firefox/firefox"));            service = new GeckoDriverService.Builder(firefoxBinary)               .usingDriverExecutable(new File("/usr/bin/geckodriver"))               .usingAnyFreePort()               .usingAnyFreePort()               .withEnvironment(ImmutableMap.of("DISPLAY",":20"))               .build();           service.start();               }         else if (SystemUtils.IS_OS_WINDOWS)         {           FirefoxBinary firefoxBinary = new FirefoxBinary(new File("C:\\Program Files\\Mozilla Firefox\\firefox.exe"));            service = new GeckoDriverService.Builder(firefoxBinary)               .usingDriverExecutable(new File("C:\\Windows\\geckodriver.exe"))               .usingAnyFreePort()               .usingAnyFreePort()               .build();           service.start();               }         else         {           System.out.println("Unknown operation system");           System.exit(-1);         }          DesiredCapabilities cap = new DesiredCapabilities();          Proxy proxy = new Proxy();          String proxyServer = aHost + ":" + aPort;         proxy.setHttpProxy(proxyServer)              .setFtpProxy(proxyServer)              .setSslProxy(proxyServer);                    proxy.setProxyType(ProxyType.MANUAL);          cap.setCapability(CapabilityType.PROXY, proxy);              driver = new FirefoxDriver(service, cap, null);          driver.navigate().to("https://api.ipify.org/?format=text");          System.out.println(driver.getPageSource());       }     } ```  ` Here are the environment details, on both windows and linux:  > Selenium version: client-combined-3.0.0-beta4-nodeps.jar > Firefox version: Mozilla Firefox 49.0.1 (both on Windows and Linux) > Windows version: 8.1 > Linux version: Ubuntu 15.04 > geckodriver version: 0.11.1 (on both Windows and Linux) > java version: build 1.8.0_102-b14 on 64 bits (on both Windows and Linux)  The output on Windows is:  > ``` >   1476874782195   geckodriver INFO    Listening on 127.0.0.1:14369 >     Oct 19, 2016 1:59:42 PM org.openqa.selenium.remote.ProtocolHandshake createSession >     INFO: Attempting bi-dialect session, assuming Postel's Law holds true on the remote end >     log4j:WARN No appenders could be found for logger (org.apache.http.client.protocol.RequestAddCookies). >     log4j:WARN Please initialize the log4j system properly. >     1476874783017   mozprofile::profile INFO    Using profile path C:\Users\Stefan\AppData\Local\Temp\rust_mozprofile.j9tzNXSwtgD6 >     1476874783019   geckodriver::marionette INFO    Starting browser C:\Program Files\Mozilla Firefox\firefox.exe >     1476874783021   geckodriver::marionette INFO    Connecting to Marionette on localhost:60470 >     1476874783502   Marionette  INFO    Listening on port 60470 >     1476874784363   Marionette  INFO    startBrowser 09aa9da8-d090-42af-be6d-3eec1ec1d4a2 >     Oct 19, 2016 1:59:44 PM org.openqa.selenium.remote.ProtocolHandshake createSession >     INFO: Detected dialect: W3C >     8x.7x.22x.14x > ```  Where 8x.7x.22x.14x is my local ip, not proxy IP.  Similar output on Linux:  > ``` >   1476875492936   geckodriver     INFO    Listening on 127.0.0.1:22032 >     Oct 19, 2016 11:11:33 AM org.openqa.selenium.remote.ProtocolHandshake createSession >     INFO: Attempting bi-dialect session, assuming Postel's Law holds true on the remote end >     log4j:WARN No appenders could be found for logger (org.apache.http.client.protocol.RequestAddCookies). > geckodriver::marionette INFO    Starting browser /home/ubuntu/firefox/firefox >     1476875493389   geckodriver::marionette INFO    Connecting to Marionette on localhost:38328 >     (firefox:25100): GLib-GObject-CRITICAL **: g_object_ref: assertion 'object->ref_count > 0' failed >     (firefox:25100): GLib-GObject-CRITICAL **: g_object_unref: assertion 'object->ref_count > 0' failed >     (firefox:25100): GLib-GObject-CRITICAL **: g_object_ref: assertion 'object->ref_count > 0' failed >     (firefox:25100): GLib-GObject-CRITICAL **: g_object_unref: assertion 'object->ref_count > 0' failed >     1476875494041   Marionette      INFO    Listening on port 38328 >     1476875495209   Marionette      INFO    startBrowser 1d7fe1dd-c381-4287-852d-1a2d87dc324e >     Oct 19, 2016 11:11:35 AM org.openqa.selenium.remote.ProtocolHandshake createSession >     INFO: Detected dialect: W3C >     (/home/ubuntu/firefox/plugin-container:25163): GLib-GObject-CRITICAL **: g_object_ref: assertion GLib-GObject-CRITICAL **: g_object_unref: assertion 'object->ref_count > 0' failed >     5x.14x.2x.2xx > ```  Where 5x.14x.2x.2xx is the ip of the Linux machine not the proxy.  Where is the problem? If I open the firefox "Connection Settings", the proxy option is "Use System Proxy Settings", not manual.   I have also tried a version with FirefoxProfile preferences, but no luck either.  `firefoxProfile.setPreference("network.proxy.type", 1);         firefoxProfile.setPreference("network.proxy.http", proxyServer);         firefoxProfile.setPreference("network.proxy.http_port", proxyPort);         firefoxProfile.setPreference("network.proxy.ssl", proxyServer);         firefoxProfile.setPreference("network.proxy.ssl_port", proxyPort);         firefoxProfile.setPreference("network.proxy.ftp", proxyServer);         firefoxProfile.setPreference("network.proxy.ftp_port", proxyPort);         firefoxProfile.setPreference("network.proxy.socks", proxyServer);         firefoxProfile.setPreference("network.proxy.socks_port", proxyPort);         firefoxProfile.setPreference("network.proxy.share_proxy_settings", true);         firefoxProfile.setPreference("network.proxy.no_proxies_on", "localhost, 127.0.0.1");`

column3: Java HtmlUnitDriver, the method get() does not load the page
column4: Hi! I'm having some problems using the driver in a java application, the method get the second time i use it, does not load the page. I'm working on a linux 3.10 machine with java 1.8 and i have the latest distribution of selenium 3.3.1. Here's some the code which im having problems:  `DesiredCapabilities cap = new DesiredCapabilities(); cap.setCapability(CapabilityType.PROXY, proxy); cap.setJavascriptEnabled(true); driver = new HtmlUnitDriver(cap); driver.get("http://data.theice.com/MyAccount/Login.aspx?ReturnUrl=~\\ViewData\\Default.aspx");` (... Use some elements...) Here i simulate a log in process filling the info. and submit the info.   `driver.get("http://data.theice.com/ViewData/EndOfDay/FuturesReport.aspx");` <-- Here does not load and remain in the first page. `System.out.println(driver.getTitle());` I tested this solution on a windows machine and it worked normally, however in the linux machine it doesnt load.  I hope you can help me with this problem, Thank you.

I found following code on internet but it doesnt work too. column3: Force BrowserMobProxy and Selenium Chrome Driver to use QUIC
column4: Hi all,          I am working on downloading HAR from Chrome for YouTube through Selenium Python Script. Code Snippet:   ```             chrome_options = webdriver.ChromeOptions()         chrome_options.add_argument("--proxy-server={0}".format(url))     chrome_options.add_argument("--enable-quic")          self.driver = webdriver.Chrome(chromedriver,chrome_options = chrome_options)             self.proxy.new_har(args['url'], options={'captureHeaders': True})   // BrowserMobProxy        self.driver.get(args['url'])            result = json.dumps(self.proxy.har, ensure_ascii=False) ```  I want QUIC to be used whenever I download HAR but when I look at the packets through Wireshark Selenium driver is using TCP only . Is there a way to force BrowserMobProxy and  Chrome Driver to use QUIC?

column3: AlertsTest case expects AssertionError
column4: Hi all,  In the test suite, AlertsTest.[testShouldNotHandleAlertInAnotherWindow()](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/java/client/test/org/openqa/selenium/AlertsTest.java#L372), there is an [expectation](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/java/client/test/org/openqa/selenium/AlertsTest.java#L383) of `AssertionError`, and the test case is ignored for all browsers.  During implementation of HtmlUnitDriver, I was able to throw WebDriverException, but I didn't see in [ErrorCodes](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/java/client/src/org/openqa/selenium/remote/ErrorCodes.java) any chance to throw `AssertionError`.  I believe either the test expectation is wrong, or ErrorCodes should be changed to handle `AssertionError`.  Appreciate your feedback.

column3: InvalidOperationException when setting timeouts using geckodriver
column4: Hi all,  Attempting to upgrade our solution's Selenium bits and switch over to Geckodriver, but it seems I've hit a snag. Wanted to check here to see if this is to be expected at this point.  I'm cross-posting this in both places ( [geckodriver github issue here](https://github.com/mozilla/geckodriver/issues/486) ) as I am not certain how to narrow down what might be the cause (I have a feeling it may be on the geckodriver side given it's in early days):  ## Meta - * **OS:**  Windows 7 Enterprise * **Platform:** .NET * **Selenium Version:** 3.1.0 * **Browser:** Firefox v51.0.1 (32-bit) * **Driver:** geckodriver 0.14  ## Steps to reproduce Access timeout values via `Instance.Manage().Timeouts()` and try to set those values   * E.g. `Instance.Manage().Timeouts().ImplicitlyWait(TimeSpan.FromSeconds(seconds));`  * I saw this was deprecated and so also tried `Instance.Manage().Timeouts().ImplicitWait = TimeSpan.FromSeconds(seconds);`  This problem appears when setting any of the timeout settings  ## Expected Behavior This code would not need to change and things would keep working.   ## Actual Behavior Receive an `InvalidOperationException` error.   Stack trace (project name redacted): ``` SetUp : System.InvalidOperationException : Missing 'type' parameter (IndexOutOfBounds)    at OpenQA.Selenium.Remote.RemoteWebDriver.UnpackAndThrowOnError(Response errorResponse)    at OpenQA.Selenium.Remote.RemoteWebDriver.Execute(String driverCommandToExecute, Dictionary`2 parameters)    at OpenQA.Selenium.Remote.RemoteTimeouts.ExecuteSetTimeout(String timeoutType, TimeSpan timeToWait)    at OpenQA.Selenium.Remote.RemoteTimeouts.set_ImplicitWait(TimeSpan value)    at REDACTED.UIAutomationFramework.Selenium.Driver.SetImplicitWait(Int32 seconds) in C:\dev\REDACTED\Src\Tests\AAT\REDACTED.UIAutomationFramework\Selenium\Driver.cs:line 484    at REDACTED.UIAutomationFramework.Selenium.Driver.TurnOnWait() in C:\dev\REDACTED\Src\Tests\AAT\REDACTED.UIAutomationFramework\Selenium\Driver.cs:line 672    at REDACTED.UIAutomationFramework.Selenium.Driver.Initialize(String baseUrl) in C:\dev\REDACTED\Src\Tests\AAT\REDACTED.UIAutomationFramework\Selenium\Driver.cs:line 84    at REDACTED.AutomatedAcceptanceTestSetUpFixture.SetUpBeforeAllTests() in C:\dev\REDACTED\Src\Tests\AAT\REDACTED\AutomatedAcceptanceTestSetUpFixture.cs:line 20 ```

column3: WebDriverException: Message: Can't load the profile.
column4: Hey guys, Trying to figure this one out and I can't seem to come up with a solution based on the research I have done. Any help would greatly be appreciated.   Thanks! - Cyb3rdude ## Meta  **OS:** OSX 10.10.5 **Selenium Version:** 2.53.6 **Browser:** Firefox **Browser Version:** 48.0.2 64bit ## Expected Behavior -  Mozilla Firefox opens with specified url, takes screenshot, saves, and closes browser. ## Actual Behavior -  Mozilla Firefox times out. This issue has been tested on Linux Mint and OSX, both with identical versions of software, and the issue only presents itself on OSX. ## Steps to reproduce  Following appropriate software and version numbers above:  ``` from selenium import webdriver import os, time, datetime  twitLink = "https://www.google.com" user = "Google"  imageName = str('image.png') browser = webdriver.Firefox() browser.get(url) #wait for page to load time.sleep(5)  browser.save_screenshot(imageName) browser.quit() ```  **The resulting error:**  ``` Traceback (most recent call last):   File "screenGrab.py", line 14, in      browser = webdriver.Firefox()   File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/firefox/webdriver.py", line 80, in __init__     self.binary, timeout)   File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/firefox/extension_connection.py", line 52, in __init__     self.binary.launch_browser(self.profile, timeout=timeout)   File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/firefox/firefox_binary.py", line 68, in launch_browser     self._wait_until_connectable(timeout=timeout)   File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/firefox/firefox_binary.py", line 108, in _wait_until_connectable     % (self.profile.path)) selenium.common.exceptions.WebDriverException: Message: Can't load the profile. column3: selenium-webdriver/testing example for node does not work.
column4: Here is the example I tried to run. http://seleniumhq.github.io/selenium/docs/api/javascript/module/selenium-webdriver/testing/index.html  It failed with  ``` TypeError: Cannot read property 'execute' of undefined ```  After I changed the examples code as below it worked fine:  ```js var webdriver = require('selenium-webdriver') // Added line var By = require('selenium-webdriver').By,   until = require('selenium-webdriver').until,   chrome = require('selenium-webdriver/chrome'),   test = require('selenium-webdriver/testing');  test.describe('Google Search', function() {   var driver;    test.before(function() {     driver = new webdriver.Builder().forBrowser('chrome').build() // Changed line   });    test.after(function() {     driver.quit();   });    test.it('should append query to title', function() {     driver.get('http://www.google.com/ncr');     driver.findElement(By.name('q')).sendKeys('webdriver');     driver.findElement(By.name('btnG')).click();     driver.wait(until.titleIs('webdriver - Google Search'), 1000);   }); }); ```  Maybe the docs are outdated? Took me a while to figure this one out...
