column3: Support W3C WebDriver Set Timeouts format
column4: From what I can tell, all Selenium client bindings apart from C# use an incorrect data structure as a body when setting timeout durations:  ```js {   type: "implicit",   ms: 42, } ```  * Node.js: https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/javascript/node/selenium-webdriver/lib/webdriver.js#L1469 * Ruby: https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/rb/lib/selenium/webdriver/remote/w3c_bridge.rb#L138 * Java: https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/java/client/src/org/openqa/selenium/remote/RemoteWebDriver.java#L834 * Python: https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/py/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py#L676  The [Set Timeouts](https://w3c.github.io/webdriver/webdriver-spec.html#dfn-set-timeouts) command expects a data format like this:  ```js {   implicit: 42, } ```  New in W3C WebDriver is that multiple timeout durations can be set at the same time:  ``` {   implicit: 123,   pageLoad: 456,   script: 789, } ```  Note that driver implementations will enumerate the own properties of the dictionary, so an unknown field is likely to error. For example, if a client passes `{foo: 1, implicit: 2}`, this is considered an error scenario by the driver.  See https://github.com/mozilla/geckodriver/issues/511 filed on geckodriver.

column3: Creating FirefoxDriver fails if log_path is not specified
column4: From https://github.com/mozilla/geckodriver/issues/349.  Found on selenium v.3.0.1 for python.  Code which fails: `driver = webdriver.Firefox(log_path = "")` I've just wanted to run FF driver and do not have some trash logs I didn't expected.  Crash in Selenium occurs in `selenium/webdriver/firefox/service.py` on line 48. Snippet of code (doc ommited): `class Service(service.Service):      def __init__(self, executable_path, port=0, service_args=None,             log_path="geckodriver.log", env=None):          if log_path:             log_file = open(log_path, "a+")          service.Service.__init__(             self, executable_path, port=port, log_file=log_file, env=env)         self.service_args = service_args or []`  In my case variable log_path is empty string and variable log_file doesn't exist. Using this variable emits crash.  **Workaround:** use `webdriver.Firefox(log_path = os.devnull)`

column3: Allow Java options when starting a standalone selenium server in Ruby
column4: Existing server allows additional args to be passed in, but they are only placed at the end of the constructed command line. For any options to the `java` command, they need to be placed before the `-jar` switch.   This pulls out any additional args that start with `-D` and put them in the right place.   Also includes a change to the gemspec checking that the __FILE__ location is the same as the pwd. This will probably be unnecessary form most people, but was failing on my jenkins server, due to mounted directories.   - [x ] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

However, after appium exits the for loop in the code below, it does not click on the login button, but it returns success to eclipse. see code below.  ``` import org.testng.annotations.Test;  import java.io.IOException; import java.net.URL;  import io.appium.java_client.AppiumDriver; import io.appium.java_client.android.AndroidDriver; import io.appium.java_client.remote.MobileCapabilityType;  import org.openqa.selenium.WebElement; import org.openqa.selenium.remote.DesiredCapabilities; import org.testng.annotations.BeforeClass;  public class NewTest {   AppiumDriver dr;  @BeforeClass public void setup() throws IOException{     DesiredCapabilities first = new DesiredCapabilities();     first.setCapability(MobileCapabilityType.DEVICE_NAME, "donatello");     first.setCapability(MobileCapabilityType.APP_ACTIVITY,"com.myapplication.MainActivity");     first.setCapability(MobileCapabilityType.APP_PACKAGE,"com.myapplication");     dr=new AndroidDriver(new URL("http://127.0.0.1:4723/wd/hub"),first); }      @Test   public void launchapp() throws Throwable {     Thread.sleep(9000);     //insert pin     for (int i =0; i<5; i ++){     dr.findElementByXPath("//android.view.View[@content-desc='1']").click();     System.out.println("I clicked" + i );     Thread.sleep(1000);     }     //click login     Thread.sleep(4000);     dr.findElementByXPath("//android.view.View[@index='2']").click();     System.out.println("I clicked Login");     Thread.sleep(9000);   } } ```  Kindly assist

column3: PhantomJS no longer works with standalone (on master)
column4: Commit 3856302 removed a deprecated function that the PhantomJS bindings (stored in https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/tree/master/third_party/java/phantomjs-driver) rely on ([seen here](https://github.com/codeborne/ghostdriver/blob/master/binding/java/src/main/java/org/openqa/selenium/phantomjs/PhantomJSDriverService.java#L232)).  I know this would probably be an issue for the ghostdriver project to handle themselves (now https://github.com/codeborne/ghostdriver), but I wanted to raise this issue since the binding are actually stored in the project

column3: Selenium Standalone: how to specify args to pass to underlying driver?
column4: ChromeDriver allows to specify a few command line flags. Among others there is "--adb-port" that allows to run tests against a browser on Android when adb server is not running on a default port. I don't see a way, though, to tell Selenium to pass the appropriate value with that flag when starting a ChromeDriver service. Is there such a way? I see that some of the flags can be controlled with system properties ([ChromeDriverService.java](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/c10e8a955883f004452cdde18096d70738397788/java/client/src/org/openqa/selenium/chrome/ChromeDriverService.java)) but there is nothing to control that particular flag nor any more generic way that would allow to pass any flag. Without that it is basically impossible to run anything against a browser on Android when adb is not running on default port. Am I missing something, or there is really no way to do this?

column3: [rb] prevent SocketError when default port not free
column4: By happenstance the default port for Chromedriver isn't working on my machine.  [This block](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/rb/lib/selenium/webdriver/common/service.rb#L71-L75) executes the `SocketLock#locked` method before it executes the `Service#find_free_port` method. But the `SocketLock#lock` method, when it calls `TCPServer#new` on a locked port, ends up throwing a `SocketError` which causes `SocketLock#lock` to timeout with `Error::WebDriverError`.  Removing the `lock` call here seems to fix it. I've spent the past hour trying to write a spec that replicates what I'm seeing without success.  @p0deje - can you take a look at this and let me know if this is the correct fix, and help me figure out how to write a spec for it?

column3: Set browser.process.leader to true
column4: By default, the child process does not create a new process group. This means there's no guarantee that the entire process tree will die when the child process is killed. To solve this: process = ChildProcess.build(*args) process.leader = true process.start  - [x] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: Update W3C codec to use new Capabilities format for New Session
column4: At the W3C TPAC, a new format for the request to the `New Session` end point was agreed upon. The handshake needs to be updated to use this format, and a mechanism put in place for local end bindings to use this.

column3: Ruby bindings set matching capabilities to "any" when spealing to WebDriver conforming remotes
column4: As can be seen from https://github.com/mozilla/geckodriver/issues/420#issuecomment-271284607, the Ruby bindings appear to set the capabilities that are _matched upon_, `browserName`, `browserVersion`, `platformName`, and `platformVersion` to "any". This is not conforming to the WebDriver specification and will as of https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1326534 fail to create a session when speaking to Firefox.  The matching capabilities should either be _left out completely_ (not defined), set to null, "*" (match anything), or the exact value the driver is providing.  Cc @titusfortner

column3: [rb] update what gets logged at what level
column4: Any objections to changing these (less important) commands to `:debug`? This leaves `:info` as just what commands are sent to & from driver/server. I think that this is what is most useful when troubleshooting someone's issue. Unless you think there is anything else that is essential for basic troubleshooting?   Also this adds details about what `ChildProcess` is doing.  Another thought. Does it make sense to change our `Kernel#warn` instances to `WebDriver.logger.warn`, since by default `Logger` displays warnings to `STDOUT`?

column3: [rb] Update driver creation and capability processing
column4: Addresses #2478  Existing code does extra processing for desired capabilities when run locally that doesn't get applied when running via remote/server. This code standardizes what is allowed to be passed in with driver initialization and makes deprecation notices for things that will no longer be supported.  Much of existing code in the Bridge subclasses is duplicated in all of the subclasses, or in need of being moved to Capabilities class. This code initializes in the superclass using methods describing the 3 things it is responsible for: `#process_capabilities`,  `#create_http_client` and `#create_session`. The only things needing to be relegated to the subclasses are processing service arguments and referencing the applicable Service and Capabilities.  It is definitely more DRY, hopefully it is also easier to understand what it is doing.  @lmtierney & @twalpole let me know if you have any feedback on this approach or implementation.   --- This change isâ€‚[](https://reviewable.io/reviews/seleniumhq/selenium/3490)

column3: [dotnet] Added ability to take array of iframe names for switching
column4: Added support for sending in a string array of iframe names to `ITargetLocator` implementations to have the webdriver loop through and switch into as ordered in the parameter.  This makes it easier to switch into nested iframes.  - [x] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: Added bindings for custom ChromeDriver commands
column4: Added Java bindings for GET_NETWORK_CONDITIONS, SET_NETWORK_CONDITIONS and DELETE_NETWORK_CONDITIONS.  These commands allows user to get/set/remove throttling conditions to its debug connection. As a result performance testing became available in Chrome. This functionality was added to ChromeDriver [here](https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src.git/+/12a55ff7369b35adb29cd28f5e3dd4ef923e3e6c) and [here](https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src.git/+/b234648cb7ab94b8c2830b566f03dfd02ebab191) in March 2015 but wan't introduced in Selenium, so clients was forced to use self-developed/third party proxies that provide desired functionality.  New binding could be used via RemoteWebDriver's method execute: chromeDriver.execute(ChromeDriverCommand.SET_NETWORK_CONDITIONS, %MAP_OF_YOUR_PARAMETERS%);  List of available parameters for these commands could be found [here](https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src.git/+/41f6892aa7564234093ebbcea765990febf495e8/chrome/test/chromedriver/client/chromedriver.py) in implementation of SetNetworkConditions methods  - [x] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)   --- This change isâ€‚[](https://reviewable.io/reviews/seleniumhq/selenium/3479)

column3: Add AttributeError handling when stopping.
column4: Add AttributeError handling when calling Service.stop. I noticed that this issue occurs after attempting to initialize a webdriver.Chrome instance while 'chromedriver' is not in PATH.  Here is the aforementioned error:  `Message: 'chromedriver' executable needs to be in PATH. Please see https://sites.google.com/a/chromium.org/chromedriver/home`  And here is the aforementioned stacktrace:  ``` Exception ignored in: > Traceback (most recent call last):   File "/home/sean/.../lib/python3.6/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/common/service.py", line 176, in __del__     self.stop()   File "/home/sean/.../lib/python3.6/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/common/service.py", line 146, in stop     if self.process is None: AttributeError: 'Service' object has no attribute 'process' ```  The proposed changes should not introduce any adverse effects as it will handle similarly to a situation where `self.process` does exist.  - [x] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)

column3: action.keyDown(Keys.CONTROL) is not working with IE11
column4: Action class operation keyDown(Keys.CONTROL) is not working with IE11.  I have a scenario in our Test Case, Where I need to select the multiple rows in our UI Grid. So I am trying to do this by using Selenium Action Class. Code is below -  List empolyeeList = new ArrayList; for (String employeeName : employeeNames) { empolyeeList.add(driver.findElement(By.xpath("Xpath of employeename"))) }  Actions action = new Actions(driver); action.keyDown(Keys.CONTROL); for (String employee : empolyeeList ) { employee.click(); } action.keyUp(Keys.CONTROL).build().perform();  Above code is working fine with chrome and firefox but it's not selecting multiple elements on IE11.  Although it starts work if I add the IE driver capability "requireWindowFocus" true. But it will break if browser is minimized or OS is locked.  Browser(s): IE11 Operating System and Version: Window 7 Selenium: 2.53 IEDriverServer: IEDriverServer_Win32_3.1.0

column3: IE specific capabilities causing issues on Remote Browsers
column4: A Variety of OS' all on Selenium Grid (All Windows 7/8 based) Selenium Version:  2.53.4 Browser:  Grid IE Browser Version:   Variety of IE versions, from 10->11 not Edge  When assigning capabilities in the following way I get timeouts where I shouldn't.  ``` capabilities = Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities.internet_explorer(       platform: platform,       javascript_enabled: true,       enable_persistent_hover: true,       require_window_focus: true,     ) ```  It seems this way works fine though:  ``` capabilities = Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities.internet_explorer(       platform: platform,       javascript_enabled: true,     )     capabilities['ie.ensureCleanSession'] = true # Wipe all history and cookies     capabilities['enablePersistentHover'] = true # Constantly fire mouseOver events     capabilities['requireWindowFocus'] = true # Forces you to be focused for each interaction (Increases Accuracy) ```  The first way would be preferable and I believe is lighter at run-time  Thoughts?? I've searched the docs tirelessly for these values, and been told by previous workers setting these could speed up IE. I've also searched on the google-groups and not found much info on this (A secretive area so to speak)  Luke

column3: Unclear directions for building Selenium's Python package
column4: A few issues:  On https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/wiki/Python-Bindings: - The wiki references `./go py_prep_for_install_release`. Does this still do the right thing after the pytest refactor? - An alternative that I have been told is to run `python setup.py sdist`. This creates a tarball, but is missing the atoms 'isDisplayed.js' and 'getAttribute.js'. I believe these need to be specifically built using `go`.  With the above in mind, it might be worth updating the instructions.

column3: Support W3C implementation of IE driver
column4: @titusfortner @lmtierney @jimevans That's a simple and bad implementation of W3C dialect for IEDriver. For now, this adds a single option:  ```ruby Selenium::WebDriver.for(:ie) # wire protocol Selenium::WebDriver.for(:ie, w3c: false) # wire protocol Selenium::WebDriver.for(:ie, w3c: true) # W3C protocol ```  ```ruby # wire protocol caps = Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities.ie Selenium::WebDriver.for(:remote, desired_capabilities: caps)  # W3C protocol caps = Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities.ie(w3c: true) Selenium::WebDriver.for(:remote, desired_capabilities: caps) ```  I still can't make specs pass for W3C (but I also can't make them pass for wire) and I don't quite like the code, but assuming we want to rewrite bridge/caps into a single implementation which understands what dialect it needs to talk to a driver, we can use this code for now and get rid of it once refactoring is done. The remote is also not working yet - I'll fix that tomorrow. I just wanted to get your thoughts on this.

column3: ruby - Unable to alter log level for capturing remote chrome browser console logs
column4: @relates to https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/pull/3474#issuecomment-290826192   ## Meta - Client OS:  OSX Docker image: `selenium/standalone-chrome:3.1.0` Selenium Version:  v3.3.0 ruby  ## Context I'm trying to capture the `console.debug` and `console.info` from chrome with v3.3.0, but [`Selenium::WebDriver.logger.level = :debug` from the docs](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/wiki/Ruby-Bindings#logging) seems to only affect selenium logging itself.  The docs section doesn't mention altering specific loggers.  How would I adjust the `level` of logs from remote chrome (only)?  I tried the following with no luck:  ```ruby  Capybara.register_driver $default_driver do |app|   Capybara::Selenium::Driver.new(app, {     browser: :remote,     url: 'http://127.0.0.1:4444/wd/hub',     desired_capabilities: Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Capabilities.chrome   }) end  Selenium::WebDriver::Driver.for(:remote).logger.level = :debug ```  [The javascript module](https://seleniumhq.github.io/selenium/docs/api/javascript/module/selenium-webdriver/lib/logging.html) appears to use capabilities but I see no such equivalent when [browsing the ruby code equivalent](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/rb/lib/selenium/webdriver/remote/capabilities.rb).  ## Expected Behavior - I can set the browser console log level for retrieving logs (perhaps like the [javascript module](https://seleniumhq.github.io/selenium/docs/api/javascript/module/selenium-webdriver/lib/logging.html) using capabilities).  ## Actual Behavior - I cannot set the browser log level via ruby.  ## Steps to reproduce - No code exists to allow this behavior.

column3: FirefoxDriver Java binding does not pick up binary or profile in W3C mode
column4: @krmahadevan pointed out in https://github.com/mozilla/geckodriver/issues/236 that the reason why people are having problems using Firefox profiles with geckodriver is that the profile passed to the Java bindingsâ€™ ctor is not being used when creating a _DriverCommandExecutor_ in https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/java/client/src/org/openqa/selenium/firefox/FirefoxDriver.java#L236-L245:  ``` java private static final CommandExecutor createCommandExecutor(Capabilities desiredCapabilities,                                                            FirefoxBinary binary,                                                            FirefoxProfile profile) {   if (isLegacy(desiredCapabilities)) {     return new LazyCommandExecutor(binary, profile);   }   GeckoDriverService.Builder builder = new GeckoDriverService.Builder();   builder.usingPort(0);   return new DriverCommandExecutor(builder.build()); } ```  As far as I can tell, we need to: 1. Change _GeckoDriverService.Builder_ to accept the passed `profile` and `binary` arguments. 2. Create a method in _GeckoDriverService_ that accepts the capabilities and feeds in the `firefox_profile` and `firefox_binary` with a Base64-encoded version of _FirefoxProfile_ and a the full path to the browser binary, and which returns the modified set of capabilities. 3. Update _FirefoxDriver#createCommandExecutor_ to pass `binary` and `profile` to the _GeckoDriverService.Builder_. 4. Make [this ctor](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/java/client/src/org/openqa/selenium/firefox/FirefoxDriver.java#L217) modify the capabilities so that it takes the updated capabilities.  I suspect the _ChromeDriver_ class uses a similar approach, and it can be used for inspiration.

column3: Anticipated the reset of 'delayedRecorder' variable
column4: 1) is detected a click on an element and the handler is saved in 'delayedRecorder' variable while checking if the click is meaningful (callIfMeaningfulEvent function). 2) a DOM change event identify the 'click' as meaningful and the 'domModified' function execute the handler to record the command. 3) if during this execution in the recording code itself or in an delayed code execution on the same element is fired a DOM change event, the handler stored in 'delayedRecorder' will be executed another time because the variable is still valorized. This will record a doubleClick instead of single one.

column3: Variable names can include broader set of chars
column4: - [X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)  When storing variables, any name can be used - but when variables are replaced, there is a regexp preventing variable replacement if it doesn't pass \w modifier in regexp.  For example:  * store | myValue | myData.foo <--- works, and value is present in storedVars  * assertValue | id=myInput | ${myData.foo} <-- will compare input value to ${myData.foo}, not to myValue  Also see https://github.com/FDIM/selenium/tree/FDIM-patch-1 for default value /other variable support.  Example: * assertValue | id=myInput | ${myData.foo || 'test'} <-- will compare input value to 'test' if myData.foo is not present in storedVars. * assertValue | id=myInput | ${myData.foo || myData.bar} <-- will compare input value to storedVar['myData.bar'] if myData.foo is not present in storedVars. * assertValue | id=myInput | ${myData.foo || 5} <-- will compare input value to 5 if myData.foo is not present in storedVars. * assertValue | id=myInput | ${myData.foo || true} <-- will compare input value to true (bool) if myData.foo is not present in storedVars.

column3: Increase service shutdown timeout in ruby bindings
column4: - [X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)  We've been getting intermittent `Net::ReadTimeout` exceptions with builds on our hosted CI provider. Since increasing `STOP_TIMEOUT` to 20, these exceptions have stopped (so far). This ends up increasing `http.read_timeout` from 2 to 10 (`STOP_TIMEOUT / 2`).  This timeout appears to have been initially defined for Chrome on Apr 2011 (bb25ecfb6ece8edbc5034182d41a91ed2116b561), but increased Chrome memory usage since then may cause shutdown to take longer, and the increased use of hosted CI providers (with potential load issues due to noisy neighbors) may also call for a longer timeout. Also note the python bindings appear to have 30 seconds as a timeout: https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/a1b3b478/py/selenium/webdriver/common/service.py#L120  There's more background on the read timeout issue at https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/pull/1684.

column3: Introduction of abstraction around @FindBy annotations and PageFactory
column4: - [X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)  See the discussion of dev list "Extending @FindBy" (Mar 4th)  Talking through the diff:  1. AbstractFindByBuilder.java is new. It is really just the migration of methods from AbstractAnnotations.java though.   2. @Annotations are not allowed to have parent annotations, interfaces or classes. That could change in Java10, as it seems arbitrary.  Thus there's a new @PageFactoryFinder annotation that each implements now, and that one names a helper class that does the factory business.  Of the pre-existing FindBys, each now has such a helper class (as a static inner class for no reason other than co-locating associated code).  3. Previous tests still pass, plus there's a test for a simulated/contrived alien @Findby annotation.  In my opinion, this is OK to slot into a point revision of Selenium as it doesn't break backwards compatibility.

column3: Add support for net-http-persistent v3
column4: - [x] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)  Context -------  When we did a routine `bundle update`, net-http-persistent jumped from v2.9.4 to v3.0.0. This major version change comes with a new initializer with keyword arguments: https://github.com/drbrain/net-http-persistent/commit/5d4b76c22dd38d29b6fbc1ed700a2a1c78c5abc4#diff-9da42550715aa09be7174a0babadcad3R512  This results in errors like so:  ```      ArgumentError:        wrong number of arguments (2 for 0)      # ./vendor/bundle/ruby/2.2.0/gems/net-http-persistent-3.0.0/lib/net/http/persistent.rb:505:in `initialize'      # ./vendor/bundle/ruby/2.2.0/gems/selenium-webdriver-3.0.3/lib/selenium/webdriver/remote/http/persistent.rb:45:in `new'      # ./vendor/bundle/ruby/2.2.0/gems/selenium-webdriver-3.0.3/lib/selenium/webdriver/remote/http/persistent.rb:45:in `new_http_client'      # ./spec/support/selenium_custom_http_persisted_client.rb:37:in `new_http_client'      # ./vendor/bundle/ruby/2.2.0/gems/selenium-webdriver-3.0.3/lib/selenium/webdriver/remote/http/default.rb:35:in `http'      # ./vendor/bundle/ruby/2.2.0/gems/selenium-webdriver-3.0.3/lib/selenium/webdriver/remote/http/persistent.rb:49:in `response_for'      # ./vendor/bundle/ruby/2.2.0/gems/selenium-webdriver-3.0.3/lib/selenium/webdriver/remote/http/default.rb:57:in `request'      # ./spec/support/selenium_custom_http_persisted_client.rb:30:in `block in request' ```  Change ------  Detect the library version and choose the required initializer.

column3: ignore me
column4: - [X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)  As pointed out at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40202798/is-setting-stdout-stderr-of-subprocess-popen-to-pipe-when-not-using-output-a-goo a pipe is opened and is written to but never read from,which is not the best behavior. Therefore I changed the default from `PIPE` to `DEVNULL` (see https://docs.python.org/3/library/subprocess.html#subprocess.DEVNULL) with a Python 2 fallback.

column3: [py] Don't write to unused pipe when no log_file
column4: - [X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)  As pointed out at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40202798/is-setting-stdout-stderr-of-subprocess-popen-to-pipe-when-not-using-output-a-goo a pipe is opened and is written to but never read from per default (no log file). This is not the optimal behavior. Therefore I changed the default from `PIPE` to `DEVNULL` (see https://docs.python.org/3/library/subprocess.html#subprocess.DEVNULL) with a Python 2 fallback. (3rd attempt)

This is not the optimal behavior. Therefore I changed the default from `PIPE` to `DEVNULL` (see https://docs.python.org/3/library/subprocess.html#subprocess.DEVNULL) with a Python 2 fallback.

column3: Fix Selenium 3.0.1 java script api - passing arguments for jar
column4: - [X ] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)  This commit is fixing error when we want use the new version of selenium  Because now the command is build to this form: ``` java -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1.jar -Dwebdriver.ie.driver=IEDriverServer_Win32_2.53.1.exe ```  and for old `selenium-server-standalone-2.53.1.jar` is working but for new version command should look like this:   ``` java -Dwebdriver.ie.driver=IEDriverServer_Win32_2.53.1.exe -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1.jar  ```

column3: Fixed handling of  outside a Shadow DOM
column4: - [ X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)  It turns out that some folks are putting stuff inside a content tag and expecting it to be displayed if the tag is outside a shadow DOM (and replaced if it's inside a shadow DOM).  While investigating this, I discovered that we need to support Shadow DOM v1 as well the (deprecated) Shadow DOM v0 API that we currently use. Expect further patches...

column3: Core compat
column4: - [ X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)  I've extended pull request #2269 in order to make WebDriver.Support work for my current .Net core projects. This pull request is somewhat more invasive than #2269 as I had to get rid of System.Runtime.Remoting which is not (and probably will never be) supported by .NET core. I opted for Castle.DynamicProxy as replacement. I also opted to target .NET Standard 1.3 instead of 1.5 as this was easily possible. Besides that it is a pretty raw port and I didn'd bother to optimise existing code. I guess there's still a lot of work left for someone who really knows what she's doing but it probably is a good start.

column3: Replace HashBiMap with thread-safe and lighter-weight ConcurrentHashMap
column4: - [ X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)  HashBiMap is not thread safe. And its ability to map back from value to key is used in a single place and can be easily replaced.

column3: Fixed java client's implementation of NetworkConnection.
column4: - [ X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)  Changed java client's RemoteNetworkConnection to send just the integer bitmask for the network connection, not the full object. This will bring the java client in line with  - the python client (see https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/py/selenium/webdriver/remote/mobile.py#L60 )  - what the spec expects (see https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/mobile-spec/blob/master/spec-draft.md#device-modes )  - and what chromedriver expects. prior to this change I saw      [18.564][INFO]: COMMAND SetNetworkConnection {        "parameters": {           "type": {              "airplaneMode": true,              "class": "org.openqa.selenium.mobile.NetworkConnection$ConnectionType",              "dataEnabled": false,              "hCode": 1,              "wifiEnabled": false           }        }     } being sent, which resulted in a RESPONSE SetNetworkConnection unknown error: invalid connection_type error.

column3: Allow a Ruby Driver class to be instantiated with an existing session id
column4: - [ X] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)  Before I get hit for raising this PR, I will try and explain our use case which while possibly unique, I still believe is valid.  We have an implementation in which we have a bespoke orchestration layer which creates a Selenium  docker container (including Browsermob) and passes the dynamic url as a connection string to the test. NB. For various reasons, the orchestration layer is NodeJS while the test is Ruby.  This is an alternative to Selenium Grid which we feel is more stable and maintainable especially when supporting HAR file generation.  Our uses cases are;  1) The orchestration layer provides the session id to the test rather than the current approach of the orchestration layer querying Selenium API after the test has created the session  2) The orchestration layer can choose Selenium bindings it feels are must suitable during a test run;  e.g. Pass session id to Ruby, do some processing that Ruby is good at, pass session to Javascript binding to perform other processing.  My personal feeling is that this PR is within the remit of the the W3C standard as it is not breaking or abusing any of the defined methods. I don't believe therre is anything say that all request must be made from the same client?  I am more than happy to discuss  this further at anytime zone in case of clarification/discussion   --- This change isâ€‚[](https://reviewable.io/reviews/seleniumhq/selenium/3101)

So it was possible to use /Application/Firefox50 but not /Application/Firefox50.app, which is not logical. Now both versions are possible.

column3: Make security.csp.enabled mutable (but still default it to false)
column4: - [ X ] By placing an `X` in the preceding checkbox, I verify that I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#step-6-sign-the-cla)  With the advent of marionette/geckodriver we want to be able to run our selenium test with CSP enabled. At the moment, we have to studiously override the 'onlyOverrideThisIfYouKnowWhatYouAreDoing' function in the java firefox driver in order to do so; this is a claim that makes us nervous.  We understand the motivation for this previously being frozen; we are hoping that we can leave the default to false, but unfreeze the property. You may disagree of course - we'd love to know why :-)

column3: [SafariDriver] Driver do not switch to window dafault content if a frame in which it was focused closes
column4: **The issue**: After clicking a link / button in a frame using SafariDriver, it appears there is no switch to parent default content if this frame is closed. As a result those listeners on a click-event fail with NoSuchFrameException.   **The Solution**: I'd like to have SafariDriver behavior similar to ChromeDriver in where switch to parent default content is performed and onclick-events can use driver in updated state.  OS:  macOS 10.12 Selenium Version:  2.48.0  Browser:  Safari Browser Version:  10.0  ## Steps to reproduce - driver.switchTo().frame(frame); WebElement element = frame.findElements(...).get(0); // clickable element in a frame element.click(); // click button inside a frame that leads to frame disappearance driver.getCurrentUrl(); // this can be inside a listener actions  **SafariDriver log**: Executing: [click: 28 [[SafariDriver: safari on MAC (null)] -> xpath: .//*[normalize-space(@class)='button button-yes']]]) 03:58:48.422 INFO - Done: [click: 28 [[SafariDriver: safari on MAC (null)] -> xpath: .//*[normalize-space(@class)='button button-yes']]] INFO - Executing: [get current url]) WARN - Exception thrown org.openqa.selenium.NoSuchFrameException: The currently selected frame has been removed from the DOM; you must select another frame/window before continuing (WARNING: The server did not provide any stacktrace information) Command duration or timeout: 9 milliseconds Build info: version: '2.48.0', revision: 'b7b081a', time: '2015-10-07 15:48:56' Driver info: org.openqa.selenium.safari.SafariDriver Capabilities [{browserName=safari, takesScreenshot=true, javascriptEnabled=true, version=10.0.1, cssSelectorsEnabled=true, platform=MAC, secureSsl=true}]  **ChromeDriver log**: [INFO]: Waiting for pending navigations... [INFO]: Done waiting for pending navigations. Status: ok [INFO]: Waiting for pending navigations... [INFO]: Done waiting for pending navigations. Status: ok [INFO]: RESPONSE FindElements [  ] [INFO]: COMMAND ClickElement {"id": "0.5348571425056579-1"} [INFO]: Waiting for pending navigations... [INFO]: Done waiting for pending navigations. Status: ok [INFO]: Waiting for pending navigations... [INFO]: Done waiting for pending navigations. Status: ok [INFO]: RESPONSE ClickElement [INFO]: COMMAND GetUrl {} [INFO]: Waiting for pending navigations... [INFO]: Done waiting for pending navigations. Status: ok [INFO]: Waiting for pending navigations... [INFO]: Done waiting for pending navigations. Status: ok [INFO]: RESPONSE GetUrl "http://example.com"

column3: Geckodriver fails to establish connection with selenium server if the test has failed for the first time
column4: **OS:**   **MAC (El Capitan) Version 10.11.6** **Browser:  Firefox**  Selenium Server Version: 2.52 Selenium python bindings version: 2.53.6  Browser Version:   Version :49.0.1 ## Expected Behavior -  Tests must run any number of times ## Actual Behavior -  After the first run (after it failed for the first time) any subsequent run the test fails to connect to the remote webdriver . The only way to reestablish the connection is by restarting the selenium server.  You can find the stacktrace here: https://gist.github.com/sri85/c80fb114f790f8d2ee933b0569ed579b ## Steps to reproduce - 1. Start the selenium standalone server. 2. Run the test ðŸ‘‰  https://gist.github.com/sri85/e69bd55b6d981c23d1043431c2bab821 3. The test fails on purpose for the first time. 4. Run the same test again.

column3: Failed to launch multiple firefox instances
column4: **Meta -** OS:  Windows 10, OSX Selenium Version:   3.0.\* IDE Browser:   Firefox 47+  Java 1.8 + TestNg 6.9.13.6  Starting from Selenium 3.0 I'm getting the 'IllegalStateException' when trying to run multiple instances of firefox in different threads.   **Expected Behavior -** Two instances of firefox browser are started  **Actual Behavior -** Driver in thread 1 starts normally but Driver in thread 2 faile to starts with the error:  java.lang.IllegalStateException: Profile passed to options is different from existing profile that has been set. at com.google.common.base.Preconditions.checkState(Preconditions.java:444) at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxOptions.setProfileSafely(FirefoxOptions.java:84) at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver.populateProfile(FirefoxDriver.java:211) at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver.(FirefoxDriver.java:242)  **Steps to reproduce** 1. Create driver using the following code String pathToBinary = "validPathToGekcoDriverExecutable"; Preconditions.checkNotNull(pathToBinary); System.setProperty(GeckoDriverService.GECKO_DRIVER_EXE_PROPERTY, pathToBinary); FirefoxProfile profile = new ProfilesIni().getProfile("validFirefoxProfileName"); FirefoxDriver firefoxWebDriver = new FirefoxDriver(new FirefoxBinary(), firefoxProfile, capabilities); 2. Run TestNg suite with the following example: [smoke.txt](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/files/555457/smoke.txt)

column3: Use `Nimbus Screenshot` Firefox plugin in a selenium test
column4: ## Usecase/Why It doesn't have to be this special plugin.  I'm more interested about  the general idea of using test cases for creating documentation screenshots.   I know taking simple screenshots is possible via selenese too, but (currently) selenese lacks the features to:     * mark elements on the page via circles,arrows etc.   * crop to special ranges of the page, based on the position of elements   * crop arbitrarily selected rectangles  Additionally doing this "inline" with an existing screenshot plugin does reuse existing functionality and gives a noob-friendly way for doing this.  I suppose using "external" plugins doesn't work because selenium interacts with web elements and they are not web elements but "firefox-elements".  ## Some questions - I know it doesn't work with with firefox 45 and the "old" selenium driver.    - Does it work with a new firefox and Marionette? - Will interaction with other plugins be developed some day in medium or long term? - Is this "via screenshot plugin way (=A)" a good idea at all?    - or would it be better to implement such functionality directly into Selenium (IDE) (=B) - Is something like this possible in chrome, or will it become possible with servo? - If I wanted to implement A or B, how much effort would it take? Would A or B be realistic/sensible. (Since I get paid to create a auto-documentation tool, this could happen. And an OpenSource Project would benefit.)

column3: Selenium IDE for Firefox does not record values in autoNumeric-managed inputs
column4: ## System Info OS:  Linux Selenium Version:  IDE v2.9.1.1 Browser:  Firefox Browser Version:  45.6.0 (64-bit)  ## Expected Behavior - Some users have reported that Selenium IDE does not record any inputs when keys are entered into an input managed by autoNumeric.  In the few last comments on this issue https://github.com/BobKnothe/autoNumeric/issues/199, there is a test webpage that shows that bug.  I'm currently running Firefox 45.6.0 and 52.0a2 with Selenium IDE v2.9.1.1, but the bug appears in both version.  ## Actual Behavior - Input values are recorded for plain input, but not when those are managed with autoNumeric.  ## Steps to reproduce - 1. Go to http://www.antoniob.com/easyedit/userfiles/autonumeric/index.html 2. Open Selenium IDE 3. Input some text into the *plain* input ; Selenium IDE record the values on `blur` 4. Input some numbers into the *autoNumeric* input ; Selenium IDE does not record the values on `blur`  Since autoNumeric change the `input.value` on-the-fly, how come Selenium does not pick up any value on blur? The `change` event is sent correctly too.

column3: When executeScript popping up javascript alerts, test hangs on InternetExplorer
column4: ## Steps to reproduce -  Execute the following java code ```  public static void main(String a[]) {         System.setProperty("webdriver.ie.driver", "\\IEDriverServer.exe");         WebDriver driver = null;         try {             driver = new InternetExplorerDriver();             driver.manage().timeouts().setScriptTimeout(30, TimeUnit.SECONDS);             driver.manage().timeouts().implicitlyWait(30, TimeUnit.SECONDS);             driver.manage().timeouts().pageLoadTimeout(30, TimeUnit.SECONDS);             driver.get("https://www.w3schools.com/jsref/tryit.asp?filename=tryjsref_alert");              // Hangs here for InternetExplorerDriver             Object hello = ((JavascriptExecutor) driver)                     .executeScript("document.getElementById('iframeResult').contentDocument.getElementsByTagName('button')[0].click(); return 'hello';");             System.out.println("return from javascript : " + hello);              Thread.sleep(2000);             WebDriverWait wait = new WebDriverWait(driver, 10);             wait.until(ExpectedConditions.alertIsPresent());             Alert alert = driver.switchTo().alert();             alert.dismiss();             driver.switchTo().defaultContent();         } catch (Throwable e) {             e.printStackTrace();         } finally {             if (driver != null) {                 driver.close();                 driver.quit();             }         }     } ```    ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7  Selenium Version:   3.0.1  Browser:  Internet Explorer   Browser Version:  Internet Explorer 11   ## Expected Behavior - The program should navigate to the specified URL, click on the button, alert popup, Print "hello" in the console, accept the alert and exit. ## Actual Behavior - The program hangs at the line where the javascript is being executed. The driver instance is blocked for some reason.

column3: Cannot run browser with WebDriver 3.0.0, Safari 10 and ElCaptain 10.11.6
column4: ## OS:  Mac OS El Captain 10.11.6 ## Selenium Version:  3.0.0,  ## Driver:  SafariDriver 2.48 ## Browser:  Safari 10 ## Browser Version:  11602.1.50.0.10 ## Expected Behavior -  When starting driver, browser is starting and performing commands  ## Actual Behavior -  Browser is starting, but nothing happens or browser is not starting at all - depending on previous commands:  if process listed by this command (launchctl list | grep webdriverd) is running, browser is not starting at all. If I kill the process, browser is starting, but nothing happens ## Steps to reproduce -  Write a test working with Se3.0.0 and Chrome or Se2.53.1 and any browser, change settings and try to run in on Safari using Se3.0.0.  Capabilities:  ```     SafariOptions safariOpts = new SafariOptions();     DesiredCapabilities cap = DesiredCapabilities.safari();      safariOpts.setUseCleanSession(true);     cap.setCapability(CapabilityType.ACCEPT_SSL_CERTS, true);     cap.setCapability(CapabilityType.UNEXPECTED_ALERT_BEHAVIOUR, "dismiss");     cap.setCapability(SafariOptions.CAPABILITY, safariOpts);     cap.setBrowserName("safari");     cap.setPlatform(Platform.MAC); ```  AND - I guess - the most helpful information here - whole setup and tests are working with previous version of webdriver (2.53.1) and SafariDriver 2.48 ## Stacktrace  ```     Unable to start the server: another safaridriver is already running (@ localhost:28142).     paÅº 19, 2016 5:06:53 PM org.openqa.selenium.remote.ProtocolHandshake createSession     INFO: Attempting bi-dialect session, assuming Postel's Law holds true on the remote end     Unable to start the server: another safaridriver is already running (@ localhost:28142).     paÅº 19, 2016 5:07:15 PM org.openqa.selenium.remote.ProtocolHandshake createSession     INFO: Attempting bi-dialect session, assuming Postel's Law holds true on the remote end      org.openqa.selenium.WebDriverException: The driver server has unexpectedly died! column3: Selenium IDE intermittently throwing unhandled exception "Component returned failure code: 0x8052000e (NS_ERROR_FILE_IS_LOCKED)"
column4: ## Meta: OS: Windows 10 Enterprise (version 1607 - build 14393.693) Selenium Version: Selenium IDE 2.9.1.1 (signed) Browser: Firefox 50.1.0  Additional add-ons: Selenium IDE - Button 1.2.0.1-signed.1-signed Selenium IDE - SelBlocks 2.1.1-signed Highlight Elements 1.22.1-signed.1-signed Modify Headers 0.7.1.1.1-signed.1-signed Power Debugger 1.21.1-signed.1-signed ScreenShot on Fail 1.14.1-signed.1-signed File Logging 3.0.1-signed   ## Description: There is an intermittent issue with Selenium IDE, where it throws the following unhandled exception: Exception... "Component returned failure code: 0x8052000e (NS_ERROR_FILE_IS_LOCKED)  [nsIFileOutputStream.init]"  nsresult: "0x8052000e (NS_ERROR_FILE_IS_LOCKED)".  I'm not sure what triggers the error - the error code NS_ERROR_FILE_IS_LOCKED (0x8052000E) indicates that "a file cannot be accessed because it is locked, typically because the file is already being used by another application" (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Errors). It looks like log files are responsible for this but the only thing that accesses the logs is a scheduled task that makes a copy of those files but I doubt it's causing the issue as the task runs every 2 minutes but the issue occurs only a few times a day.   ## Steps to reproduce: Unfortunately, the issue is hard to reproduce as it does not occur most of the time (most of the time Selenium IDE works fine, this issue may occur only a few times per day). It's not clear what triggers it as it occurs at random times. Reinstalling the browser and all add-ons did not fix the issue.   ## Full error message: Unexpected Exception:  [Exception... "Component returned failure code: 0x8052000e (NS_ERROR_FILE_IS_LOCKED) [nsIFileOutputStream.init]"    nsresult: "0x8052000e (NS_ERROR_FILE_IS_LOCKED)" location: "JS frame :: chrome://sidefilelogger/content/logic/FileLogger.js?1484332139619 :: FileLogger.prototype.writeToLog :: line 101"  data: no]. toString -> function toString() { [native code] }, message -> Component returned failure code: 0x8052000e (NS_ERROR_FILE_IS_LOCKED) [nsIFileOutputStream.init], result -> 2152857614, name -> NS_ERROR_FILE_IS_LOCKED, filename -> chrome://sidefilelogger/content/logic/FileLogger.js?1484332139619, lineNumber -> 101, columnNumber -> 0, data -> null, stack -> FileLogger.prototype.writeToLog@chrome://sidefilelogger/content/logic/FileLogger.js?1484332139619:101:7 FileLogger.prototype.onAppendEntry@chrome://sidefilelogger/content/logic/FileLogger.js?1484332139619:128:7 Logger/this.log/<@chrome://selenium-ide/content/selenium-runner.js:348:7 Logger/this.log@chrome://selenium-ide/content/selenium-runner.js:347:5 Logger/ JS frame :: chrome://sidefilelogger/content/logic/FileLogger.js?1484332139619 :: FileLogger.prototype.writeToLog :: line 101   Attached please diag information.

column3: OSS Capabilities not Respected in latest Firefox
column4: ## Meta - Server 3.0.1  Firefox 54 Geckodriver 0.13.0  ## Expected Behavior - Passing in OSS Desired Capabilities should be translated as necessary into W3C Capabilities to pass to geckodriver  ## Actual Behavior - In Ruby, OSS specific values are being ignored, while W3C values are being passed along correctly In Java, OSS specific values prevent creating session  ## Steps to reproduce - Ruby & Java: https://gist.github.com/titusfortner/2d1406aec842260bdd63dc8244b86d06

column3: Capability Mismatch when given Command Line Argument (Version becomes Long, Instead of String)
column4: ## Meta - Selenium Version: 3.0.1 Browser:  Any    ## Expected Behavior - Registering a Node with the argument "-browser browserName=firefox,version=50,applicationName=win-10-64-firefox-50" should register a node with said capabilities. When requesting those capabilities in a test, one would expect that selenium is able to match capabilities and be able to get a Browser.  ## Actual Behavior - The test fails with exception: "Message: Error forwarding the new session cannot find : Capabilities [{browserName=firefox, version=50, applicationName=win-10-64-firefox-50}]"  ## Steps to reproduce -  1. Setup a hub, register a node with "-browser browserName=firefox,version=50,applicationName=win-10-64-firefox-50" 2. Request the exact same capabilities as above in a test(I used python) 3. The test will fail with "Message: Error forwarding the new session cannot find : Capabilities [{browserName=firefox, version=50, applicationName=win-10-64-firefox-50}]"  ## Additional Info I debugged selenium and looked where the matching failed. Using InteliJ Debugger, i was able to trace the Error to the matches Method of DefaultCapabilityMatcher.java. Looking at the Variables, the nodeCapability in the case above matched the "version" key to a Long with value 50. On the other Hand requestedCapability matches the "version" key to a String with value 50. This becomes problematic in the following check: ` if (!requestedCapability.get(key).equals(nodeCapability.get(key).toString())) {                 return false;               }`  Since requestedCapability for the key version is a String, the equals Method is not able to compare the String "50" with the Long Value 50 (Default Implementation of equals for String always returns false, if the other object is not a String). Thus this would always evaluate to true and hence return false. Obviously there is some mismatch. My guess is, that when registering a Node, somehow the parser Converts 50 into a Long instead of a String.   Trying the same with version=50.0 in the commandline argument will lead to a String in nodeCapability, which would match correctly later on in the check.   I also used a older Selenium Version (2.53) as node to verify my assumption. Indeed, when using version=50 in the commandline, the nodeCapability correctly matches version to a String with value 50, thus it could match later on in the Code above.  Unfortunately I am unsure how to fix this, because to me, there are several possible fixes. Thus I would leave this to a experienced selenium developer.

column3: Selenium sometimes fails to load the first page (IE issue)
column4: ## Meta - Selenium Version:  2.53.4 Browser:  IE11 Win10 *Selenium Grid*  ## Behavior When running the `.load` command, issues sometimes arise (Can vary from not at all to a few times). The problematic command is when we load up the main website. I've raised an issue on siteprism as it's their command I'm loading and they've told me it's not a SitePrism / Capybara issue.  ## Steps to reproduce I don't really have much to reproduce it outside of the Browser / Selenium Info given. This only seems to happen on the grid (Although we run 10* more testing there, so perhaps just not seen locally). The issue seems to occur 1/2 scenarios in the 9 when we notice it, and it always seems to be on this one node (Mentioned above).  https://github.com/natritmeyer/site_prism/issues/173

column3: Java bindings: Make FirefoxOptions Serializable
column4: ## Meta - Selenium Version:   3.2.0 Browser:   Firefox Browser Version:   51  ## Expected Behavior - Caused by: java.io.NotSerializableException: org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxOptions  ## Actual Behavior - File is saved  ## Steps to reproduce - ``` import java.io.FileOutputStream; import java.io.IOException; import java.io.ObjectOutputStream; import java.util.logging.Level;  import org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxOptions; import org.openqa.selenium.remote.DesiredCapabilities;  public class ab {      public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {         FirefoxOptions options = new FirefoxOptions();         options.setLogLevel(Level.FINER);          DesiredCapabilities ffCapabilities = DesiredCapabilities.firefox();         ffCapabilities.setCapability(FirefoxOptions.FIREFOX_OPTIONS, options);          FileOutputStream fout = new FileOutputStream("./ff.cap");         ObjectOutputStream oos = new ObjectOutputStream(fout);         oos.writeObject(ffCapabilities);     }  }

column3: wait until not waiting for ExpectedConditions.presenceOfNestedElementsLocatedBy
column4: ## Meta - OS: Windows 7 Professional Selenium Version: 2.53.0 Browser: Chrome 54.0.2840.99 m  I have the following Java code:  ``` // wait is an instance of WebDriverWait already declared elsewhere final List colMatches = wait.until(ExpectedConditions.presenceOfNestedElementsLocatedBy(By.name("Person Results"), By.xpath(".//td[contains(@class, 'dgrid-column-1') and @role='gridcell' and @data-label='Person Name']"))); final WebElement firstRowPersonName = colMatches.get(0); ```  ## Expected Behavior - The first lines should wait until it finds elements within the element located by name("Person Results") that match the xpath condition, or the wait timeout is reached.  The elements that will match are loaded into the results table dynamically by the test.  ## Actual Behavior - The wait returns straight away before the matching elements have appeared. The 2nd line therefore gives:  > java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException: Index: 0, Size: 0  This seems to show that the wait until is not actually waiting as it should. If I set a breakpoint on the 2nd line, wait a few seconds, then re-evaluate the first line it finds the expected elements and prevents the error which confirms my locators are correct, it's just not finding anything matching yet when it is run so my understanding is it should be waiting until it does.  ## Steps to reproduce - I'm not sure how to provided a SSCCE for this as the system I'm testing is not available externally. Are there any existing examples on https://jsfiddle.net/ that do something similar that I could modify: load some results with a delay before trying to locate them with an ExpectedConditions.presenceOfNestedElementsLocatedBy?

column3: Selenium Ruby (Grid), has a huge delay after calling driver.quit on IE11 when encountering Net::ReadTimeout
column4: ## Meta - OS: Windows 7 / 8.1 Selenium Version:  At least 10 different ruby bindings from `2.53.4` through to `3.5.2` Browser: IE11 on Grid  ## Preface to our usage -  We increase our timeouts in the bindings to `120s` using the following syntax  ``` Capybara.register_driver :selenium do |app|     client = Selenium::WebDriver::Remote::Http::Default.new     client.timeout = 120     Capybara::Selenium::Driver.new(       app,       browser: :remote,       url: ENV['hub_url'],       desired_capabilities: caps,       http_client: client,     )   end ```  ## Expected Behavior - When we timeout we expect the timestamps between running the last command and then receiving a timeout to be 120s +/- 0.25s (Based off the default interrogation / polling rate). This *works*  Then we run our after hook. Which is contained in the code below (Steps to reproduce). This should run in a couple of seconds.  ## Actual Behavior - This however has a "huge" delay between the first and second log statements. Circa **150s**  ## Steps to reproduce - ``` After do |scenario|   $LOG.info("Attempting to quit session.driver for #{scenario.name}") #This log is the penultimate   Capybara.current_session.driver.quit   $LOG.info('Quit driver for this scenario') #This log is the last and it takes 150s end ```

column3: _cookie_temp_file being closed and removed twice
column4: ## Meta - OS: Windows 7 (Cygwin) Selenium Version: 3.0.2 Browser: PhantomJS Browser Version: 2.1.1 Language: Python Language Version: 3.4.5  ## Expected Behavior - When quitting the driver with `WebDriver.quit()`, `Service.send_remote_shutdown_command()` which closes and removes `_cookie_temp_file` should be called only once.  ## Actual Behavior - Whenever the Python GC runs and executes `Service.__del__()`, `Service.send_remote_shutdown_command()` is called again and attempts to close and delete `_cookie_temp_file` a second time causing a `FileNotFoundError` and an `OSError: [Errno 9] Bad file descriptor`. ## Steps to reproduce - ```python import gc from selenium import webdriver driver=webdriver.PhantomJS() driver.get('https://google.com') driver.quit() driver=1 gc.collect() ```  ## More info - The problem seems to occur when the PhantomJS process is not terminated and the garbage collector runs. There is often a delay between sending the `quit` command to PhantomJS and the process actually ending and if the garbage collector happens to run during that time and `self.process` is [not `none`](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/cdebe0e55f8dfaa2294f18f73aeb513fa76e0aef/py/selenium/webdriver/common/service.py#L145), then `send_remote_shutdown_command()` is run a second time. Also, this issue will most likely happen to users experiencing #767.

column3: IE Driver Beta: sendKeys doesn't work when using Selenium Server
column4: ## Meta - OS: Windows 7 Selenium Version: a little after 3.3 (commit e9a906a) Browser: Internet Explorer Browser Version: 11, but I don't think the version is important for this one  IE Driver Beta Version: 3.3.99.1  ## Expected Behavior - Things should be typed into the input field.  ## Actual Behavior - Nothing is typed. There's an error message in the [IEDriver log](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/files/869678/iedriver.log.txt): ``` W 2017-03-24 21:17:47:067 response.cc(92) Error response has status code 400 and message 'Missing parameter: text' message ```  ## Steps to reproduce -  I'm pretty sure this is the Selenium Server's fault. The client is speaking OSS dialect to the Selenium Server, which is not correctly translating that to W3C when speaking to IEDriver.  #### send_keys.py ```py import sys  from selenium import webdriver  driver = webdriver.Remote(     command_executor=sys.argv[1],     desired_capabilities={'browserName': 'internet explorer'})  driver.get('http://localhost/form.html') elem = driver.find_element_by_id('t') elem.send_keys('abc') print '%s [%s]' % (elem.text == 'abc', elem.text) ```  #### form.html  ```html  ```

column3: [Selenium Grid] "geo.wifi.uri" adds extra delimiters when run on Grid
column4: ## Meta - OS: Windows 10 Pro 64-bit Selenium Version:  2.53.1 Browser: Firefox 45.1.1 ESR Browser Version: 45.1.1 ESR  ## Expected Behavior - "geo.wifi.uri" should be `data:application/json,{"status":"OK","accuracy":10.0,"location":{"lat":45.0,"lng":-122.0}}`  ## Actual Behavior - "geo.wifi.uri" is actually `data:application/json,{\"status\":\"OK\",\"accuracy\":10.0,\"location\":{\"lat\":45.0,\"lng\":-122.0}}`  ## Steps to reproduce - 1. Setup a Selenium Grid    1. Download http://selenium-release.storage.googleapis.com/2.53/selenium-server-standalone-2.53.1.jar    2. java -jar selenium-server-standalone-2.53.1.jar -role hub    3. java -jar selenium-server-standalone-2.53.1.jar -role node -hub http://127.0.0.1:4444/grid/register -nodeConfig node.json  node.json ```json {    "capabilities":[       {          "browserName":"firefox",          "version":"45.1.1",          "platform":"LINUX",          "maxInstances":5       }    ],    "configuration":{       "nodeTimeout":120,       "port":5555,       "hubPort":4444,       "hubHost":"127.0.0.1",       "nodePolling":2000,       "registerCycle":10000,       "register":true,       "cleanUpCycle":2000,       "timeout":90000,       "maxSession":5    } } ```  2. Run through these simple tests ```java import java.io.File; import java.net.URL;  import org.junit.Test; import org.openqa.selenium.WebDriver; import org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxBinary; import org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver; import org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxProfile; import org.openqa.selenium.remote.DesiredCapabilities; import org.openqa.selenium.remote.RemoteWebDriver;  public class BrokenTest {     private static final String FIREFOX_LOCATION = "F:\\Program Files\\Firefox\\45\\firefox.exe";          private FirefoxProfile getProfile() {         FirefoxProfile profile = new FirefoxProfile();         profile.setPreference("geo.enabled", true);         profile.setPreference("geo.provider.use_corelocation", false);         profile.setPreference("geo.provider.ms-windows-location", false);         profile.setPreference("geo.prompt.testing", true);         profile.setPreference("geo.prompt.testing.allow", true);         profile.setPreference("geo.wifi.uri", "data:application/json,{\"status\":\"OK\",\"accuracy\":10.0,\"location\":{\"lat\":45.0,\"lng\":-122.0}}");         return profile;     }      private DesiredCapabilities getCapabilities() {         DesiredCapabilities capabilities = DesiredCapabilities.firefox();         capabilities.setCapability(FirefoxDriver.PROFILE, getProfile());         capabilities.setCapability("firefox_binary", FIREFOX_LOCATION);         return capabilities;     }          @Test     public void brokenTest() throws Exception {         WebDriver driver = new RemoteWebDriver(new URL("http://127.0.0.1:4444/wd/hub"), getCapabilities());         driver.get("about:config");         Thread.sleep(10000);     }          @Test     public void workingTest() throws Exception {         WebDriver driver = new FirefoxDriver(new FirefoxBinary(new File(FIREFOX_LOCATION)), getProfile());         driver.get("about:config");         Thread.sleep(10000);     }      @Test     public void workingTest2() throws Exception {         WebDriver driver = new FirefoxDriver(getCapabilities());         driver.get("about:config");         Thread.sleep(10000);     }      @Test     public void brokenTest2() throws Exception {         assertEquals(getProfile().getStringPreference("geo.wifi.uri", ""),FirefoxProfile.fromJson(getProfile().toJson()).getStringPreference("geo.wifi.uri", ""));     } } ```  3. When the firefox instances starts up goto about:config    * Look at "geo.wifi.uri"  Notes: * This works when I run this with a FirefoxDriver, but once I try to put it in a Grid Node, it adds extra delimiters and fails to work correctly. * If I manually go into about:config while the test is running, and remove the delimiters. The test will pass. * I upgrade to Firefox 45.3.0 ESR and that still did not help. * This is very easily reproducible with brokenTest2() * If I put a break point in the toJson() just before `return new Zip().zip(generatedProfile);` and manually go to the user.js file and change the line `user_pref("geo.wifi.uri", "data:application/json,{\"status\":\"OK\",\"accuracy\":10.0,\"location\":{\"lat\":45.0,\"lng\":-122.0}}");` to `user_pref("geo.wifi.uri", "data:application/json,{"status":"OK","accuracy":10.0,"location":{"lat":45.0,"lng":-122.0}}");` everything passes.

column3: WebElement.getText() does not return the correct value in case of comma separated numbers.
column4: ## Meta - OS: Windows 10 64-Bit Selenium Version:   selenium-remote-driver-3.0.1 Browser:   Chrome   Browser Version:   Version 55.0.2883.87 m (64-bit)   ## Expected Behavior - We have an td html element containing the text 0,29. After finding it via driver.findElement(By.xpath("xpath")) the call of the method  WebElement.getText() should return 0,29 as string.  ## Actual Behavior -  The method WebElement.getText() returns 0.29 as string.  ## Steps to reproduce -  Try to find any html element containing a number as string (e.g 0,45) with the selenium remote driver. The call of WebElement.getText() will return a number as string separated with dots. Probably because of the internal framework conversion from json to  webElement

column3: Cannot pick up folder in the test
column4: ## Meta - OS: Windows Selenium Version:  Selenium.WebDriver.3.0.1 Browser:  Chrome  ## Expected Behavior - Selenium can support to identify folder in non-local machine.  ## Actual Behavior - It doesn't regconize the folder  ## Steps to reproduce - It seems "IAllowsFileDetection" only supports for file. Do we have any interface which supports for folder?   ## Test code  var js = (IJavaScriptExecutor)Browser.WebDriver; 			var folderToUpload = string.Join("\n", path); 			Console.WriteLine("DragAndDropWithJQuery: " + folderToUpload); 			WaitForJquery(); 			js.ExecuteScript( 				"$('body').append('')"); 			var element = Browser.WebDriver.FindElement(By.Id("dropInput")); 			var allowsDetection = Browser.WebDriver as IAllowsFileDetection; 			if (allowsDetection != null) 				allowsDetection.FileDetector = new LocalFileDetector(); 			element.SendKeys(Path.Combine(Settings.SmokeTestAssetsLocation, @"BulkUploadTestData\DnDEmtyZipFileBulkUpload")); 			js.ExecuteScript( 				"(function() {" + 				"e = $.Event('drop'); " + 				"e.originalEvent = {dataTransfer : { files : $('#dropInput')[0].files } }; " + 				"$('body').trigger(e); console.log('file: ' + $('#dropInput')[0].files.length + ' name: ' + $('#dropInput')[0].files[0]);" + 				"})()");

column3: ElementSendKeys command sending 'value' property rather than 'text'
column4: ## Meta - OS: OSX El Capitan  Selenium Version: 3.3.0, Selenium-Webdriver for NodeJS  Browser: Chrome    Browser Version: 56.0.2924.87 (64-bit)   ## Expected Behavior -  Based on the current W3C specs the text passed to WebElement.sendKeys() should send to the remote end as a property named 'text':  https://www.w3.org/TR/webdriver/#element-send-keys  "The remote end steps for Element Send Keys are:  If the current browsing context is no longer open, return error with error code no such window.  ...  Let text be the result of getting a property text from the parameters argument"    ## Actual Behavior -  The current selenium-webdriver implementation sends the text as a property called 'value'  ## Steps to reproduce -  This is being tested in a custom WebDriver server implementation.

column3: Node Firefox Profile - Sample Code does not run,
column4: ## Meta - OS: OSX   Selenium Version:   Latest Browser:  Firefox - latest  ## Expected Behavior - I expect to see http://www.google.com to be loaded in a firefox window with the firefox profile having the property security.ssl.enable_ocsp_stapling set to false.  ## Actual Behavior - Errors when running  node index.js  /Users/chris/src/seleniumAPIC/node_modules/selenium-webdriver/lib/promise.js:2517         throw error;         ^  TypeError: Cannot read property 'execute' of undefined     at /Users/chris/src/seleniumAPIC/node_modules/selenium-webdriver/lib/webdriver.js:822:24 From: Task: WebDriver.navigate().to(http://google.com)     at Driver.schedule (/Users/chris/src/seleniumAPIC/node_modules/selenium-webdriver/lib/webdriver.js:816:17)     at Navigation.to (/Users/chris/src/seleniumAPIC/node_modules/selenium-webdriver/lib/webdriver.js:1140:25)     at Driver.get (/Users/chris/src/seleniumAPIC/node_modules/selenium-webdriver/lib/webdriver.js:997:28)     at Object. (/Users/chris/src/seleniumAPIC/index.js:44:9)     at Module._compile (module.js:571:32)     at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:580:10)     at Module.load (module.js:488:32)     at tryModuleLoad (module.js:447:12)     at Function.Module._load (module.js:439:3)     at Module.runMain (module.js:605:10) ## Steps to reproduce - Run this code based on the sample.  var firefox = require('selenium-webdriver/firefox');  var profile = new firefox.Profile(); profile.setPreference('security.ssl.enable_ocsp_stapling', false);  var options = new firefox.Options().setProfile(profile); var driver = new firefox.Driver(options);   driver.get('http://google.com');

column3: [Bug-Ruby]W3C Command handled incorrect
column4: ## Meta - OS: OS X 10.12   Selenium Version:   3.0.4 / 3.2.2 Browser:   Chrome  Related W3C command:  > POST	/session/:sessionId/execute	 Inject a snippet of JavaScript into the page for execution in the context of the currently selected frame.  Related source code : Selenium use /session/:sessionId/execute/sync https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/rb/lib/selenium/webdriver/remote/w3c_commands.rb#L88  Related W3C definition: But you defined that we should use /session/:sessionId/execute https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/wiki/JsonWireProtocol  Chrome driver 2.24 - 2.27's implementation use : POST /session/:sessionId/execute  Related java impl: https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/b2aa9fd534f7afbcba319231bb4bce85f825ef09/java/client/src/org/openqa/selenium/remote/http/JsonHttpCommandCodec.java#L86  ## Expected Behavior - Execute given script  ## Actual Behavior - return status 404  ## Steps to reproduce - driver.execute_script()

column3: Form submit action not working on Python client with GeckoDriver
column4: ## Meta - OS: Linux Debian 8.7 Selenium Version: Python API 3.0.2 Browser: Firefox   Browser Version:  50.1.0 (64-bit) Python Version:  3.5.2  ## Expected Behavior - Submit action from a input field to actually submit a form  ## Actual Behavior - Exception thrown:  > Traceback (most recent call last): >   ... >   File ".../selenium/lib/python3.5/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webelement.py", line 86, in submit >     "if (arguments[0].dispatchEvent(e)) { arguments[0].submit() }", form) >   File ".../selenium/lib/python3.5/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 465, in execute_script >     'args': converted_args})['value'] >   File ".../selenium/lib/python3.5/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 236, in execute >     self.error_handler.check_response(response) >   File ".../selenium/lib/python3.5/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/errorhandler.py", line 192, in check_response >     raise exception_class(message, screen, stacktrace) > selenium.common.exceptions.WebDriverException: Message: TypeError: Argument 1 of EventTarget.dispatchEvent does not implement interface Event.  ## Steps to reproduce - Create a virtual environment, pip install selenium on it, add the following file as form.html: ```                                                      Foo                ``` Then create the following python file:  ``` import os   from selenium import webdriver  from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import Select from selenium.common.exceptions import NoSuchElementException, WebDriverException  baseurl = "file://"+os.getcwd()+"/form.html"  credentials = { 'user': 'foo', 'pass': 'bar' }  for driver in (webdriver.Firefox(), webdriver.Chrome()):     driver.get(baseurl)     driver.maximize_window()     driver.find_element_by_name('login').send_keys(credentials['user'])     driver.find_element_by_name('password').send_keys(credentials['pass'])     try:         driver.find_element_by_name('login').submit()     except WebDriverException:         driver.find_element_by_name('submit').click()         print(driver.name+' failed :(')     else:         print(driver.name+' succeeded!')     driver.quit()   ``` It prints:  > firefox failed :( > chrome succeeded!

column3: Selenium Webdriver would not open some urls
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows10 Selenium Version:  2.45.0, IDE : IntelliJIdea Browser:   Firefox   Browser Version:  33.0  ## Expected Behavior -  I am trying to execute a simple test case                 driver = new FirefoxDriver();         driver.manage().window().maximize();         driver.manage().timeouts().implicitlyWait(30, TimeUnit.SECONDS);         driver.get("https://www.linkedin.com");  Firefix Should launch linkedin.com  ## Actual Behavior -  Firefox is launched but linkedin.com website doesnt open, I dont even see url being passed to the firefox.  All other websites like: Google.com, CNN.com etc can be launched except linkedin.com  ## Steps to reproduce - Not sure how to reproduce the issue as it affects one website only

column3: Failed to create instance of FirefoxProfile
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows Server 2012 RT x64  Selenium Version:  Nuget Package Selenium.WebDriver 3.0.1  Browser:  Firefox   Browser Version:  49.0.2 (64-bit)   ## Expected Behavior -  Create a instance of FirefoxProfile to edit preferences with C# in embeded project  ## Actual Behavior -  When execute `var profile = new FirefoxProfile();` this give a exception "The path is not of a legal form", this exception is because my project is embeded in other project. So when execute the command `FileUtilities.GetCurrentDirectory()` in [line 161](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/selenium-3.1.0/dotnet/src/webdriver/Internal/FileUtilities.cs#L161) `string currentDirectory = Path.GetDirectoryName(executingAssembly.Location);` this throw exception because Location is null. Because my project is embeded. Here need get Entries Assembly.  ## Steps to reproduce -  Create a project, install nuget package Selenium.WebDriver and embed this a other project and try to Instantiate `new FirefoxProfile()` in C#
