java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)]   ## Steps to reproduce - Try launching the IE browser using the following code and using the above ## Meta  def serviceIE = new InternetExplorerDriverService.Builder().usingPort(9516).usingDriverExecutable(new File("IEDriverServer.exe")).build() serviceIE.start() DesiredCapabilities d = DesiredCapabilities.internetExplorer() d.setCapability("nativeEvents", false) d.setCapability(InternetExplorerDriver.INTRODUCE_FLAKINESS_BY_IGNORING_SECURITY_DOMAINS,true) d.setCapability(InternetExplorerDriver.FORCE_CREATE_PROCESS, true); d.setCapability(InternetExplorerDriver.IE_ENSURE_CLEAN_SESSION, true); Driver = new RemoteWebDriver(serviceIE.getUrl(),d)  **Note:** The following changes were made on a machine 1.	IE-ESC was disabled 2.	Enhanced Protected Mode was disabled i.e. Enable Enhanced Protected Mode was not ticked 3.	Protected Mode Security setting were same for all the Zones(Disabled) 4.	Created DWORD value for the key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Microsoft\Internet Explorer\Main\FeatureControl\FEATURE_BFCACHE for a 64-bit machine  Please let me know if you require any other information.  Thanks!

column3: window.focus() fails with 'JavaScript Error' on IE 11 under Jenkins
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows Server 2008 R2 Datacenter Selenium Version:   2.53.0, Browser:  Internet Explorer Browser Version:  11.0.9600.18524 (32-bit) -->  ## Background In order to avoid loss of focus problems on IE, we include a line:      **driver.execute_script("window.focus()")**  in our test code. This works fine on all browsers when run in an interactive session. However, when we run the test code from Jenkins the call fails with:       **selenium.common.exceptions.WebDriverException: Message: JavaScript error** on IE11 (only).   The code works fine on Chrome and Firefox and on IE9. The Jenkins job runs as the same user as  the interactive session. The iedriver.log doesn't seem to give anything helpful.  Please find attached two iedriver.log files. One file was generated when running code in an interactive session and the second one when running code under Jenkins. See the difference on line 349 in iedriver.jenkins.log : **Specified element is not the active element. Keystrokes may go to an unexpected DOM element.**. And then in line 403 it crashes. [iedriver.cmd_line.log.txt](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/files/640093/iedriver.cmd_line.log.txt) [iedriver.jenkins.log.txt](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/files/640095/iedriver.jenkins.log.txt)       We're pretty stumped on this. Is there anything we can enable that would give more information on what is going wrong?

column3: WebDriver doesn't work properly with C# LINQ
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 8.1 x64 Selenium Version: 3.0.1, C# nuget package   Browser:  Chrome Browser Version:  56.0.2924.87  ## Steps to reproduce - 1. Open web-page with element located by some XPath which contains Text 2. Run one of the following functions for waiting For Example: Waiter(driver, 2000, "//button[@id='test_button']", "BUTTON");   1.  ``` public static void Waiter(IWebDriver driver, int millisec, string xpath, string text) { try { (new WebDriverWait(driver, TimeSpan.FromMilliseconds(millisec))).Until(     d => d.FindElements(By.XPath(xpath)).Any(         element => element.Displayed && element.Enabled && element.Text.Equals(text))); } catch (WebDriverTimeoutException ex) { // do smth } } ```  2.   ``` public static void Waiter(IWebDriver driver, int millisec, string xpath, string text) { try { (new WebDriverWait(driver, TimeSpan.FromMilliseconds(millisec))).Until(             d =>     {         var elements = d.FindElements(By.XPath(xpath));         return elements.Any(element => element.Displayed && element.Enabled && element.Text.Equals(text));     }); catch (WebDriverTimeoutException ex) { // do smth } } ```  3.  ``` public static void Waiter(IWebDriver driver, int millisec, string xpath, string text) { try { (new WebDriverWait(driver, TimeSpan.FromMilliseconds(millisec))).Until(     d =>     {         var elements = d.FindElements(By.XPath(xpath));         foreach (var element in elements)         {             if (element.Displayed && element.Enabled && element.Text.Equals(text))             {                 return true;             }         }              return false;     }); catch (WebDriverTimeoutException ex) { // do smth } } ```  ## Expected Behavior - all examples should work identically  ## Actual Behavior - 1st example causes StaleElementReferenceException 2nd and 3rd works properly without errors/exceptions

column3: Cannot find a file named '...\bin\Debug\getAttribute.js' or an embedded resource with the id 'getAttribute.js'.
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 8.1 Professional Selenium Version:  3.0.0 (for .NET 4.0) Browser:  Firefox Browser Version:  50  ## Expected Behavior - `selenium-dotnet-strongnamed-3.0.0.zip` should contain the same files as `selenium-dotnet-3.0.0.zip`, but with a cryptographic signature.  ## Actual Behavior - `selenium-dotnet-strongnamed-3.0.0.zip` is missing two resources that `selenium-dotnet-3.0.0.zip` contains, `getAttribute.js` and `isDisplayed.js`.  Trying to call `element.GetAttribute("id")`, for example, will throw:  ``` OpenQA.Selenium.WebDriverException Cannot find a file named '...\bin\Debug\getAttribute.js' or an embedded resource with the id 'getAttribute.js'. ```  ## Steps to reproduce - Open the DLLs inside [`selenium-dotnet-strongnamed-3.0.0.zip`](http://selenium-release.storage.googleapis.com/3.0/selenium-dotnet-strongnamed-3.0.0.zip) and [`selenium-dotnet-strongnamed-3.0.0.zip`](http://selenium-release.storage.googleapis.com/3.0/selenium-dotnet-3.0.0.zip) using ILSpy. Expand the Resources for `WebDriver (3.0.0.0)` in each.

Execute the following code:  ` public class Main {   public static void main(String[] args) throws MalformedURLException {     DesiredCapabilities cap = DesiredCapabilities.firefox();     cap.setCapability(FirefoxDriver.MARIONETTE, false);     cap.setCapability(FirefoxDriver.PROFILE, new FirefoxProfile());     RemoteWebDriver driver = new RemoteWebDriver(new URL("..."), cap);   } } ` Without the FirefoxProfile line Firefox starts normally.  The exception mentioned above says something about /org/openqa/selenium/firefox/amd64/x_ignore_nofocus.so that is not found. And that is correct since there is no such path in the selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1.jar. But I found that folder inside the previously used selenium-server-standalone-2.53.1.jar. I tried to copy the amd64 (and the also missing x86 folder) from the 2.53.1 jar to the 3.0.1 jar and got Firefox work again.

column3: C# Protractor IEDriverServer Click() Exception â€œTimed out waiting for page to loadâ€ Javascript SignalR
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 8.1 Selenium Version:  3.0.1 Browser:  Internet Explorer Browser Version:  11.0.9600.18525  ## Expected Behavior -  element.Click() method should work  ## Actual Behavior -  element.Click() results in exception "Timed out waiting for page to load" regardless of how long the wait time is.  ## Steps to reproduce -  Unfortunately the particular pages I'm encountering this problem require a login, so I need management permissions to create an account that can be posted publicly. However, I hope my description of the issue can suffice.  I only run into this issue with some pages where Javascript SignalR is implemented. And this only happens with Selenium IE Driver. Chrome Driver works fine (have not tested with Firefox).  InterneExplorerOptions is defined as follows:      var ieOptions = new InternetExplorerOptions     {         BrowserCommandLineArguments = "-private",         EnableNativeEvents = false,         IgnoreZoomLevel = true,         IntroduceInstabilityByIgnoringProtectedModeSettings = false     };      browser.IgnoreSynchronization = true.

column3: Methods in actions class are not working. Ex: doubleclick
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 8.1  Selenium Version:  3.0.0 C#  Browser:  Firefox                closed                rajckumar38                2016-11-04T07:58:59Z               2019-08-19T07:09:39Z                                             3057               HTTP Basic Authentication with Selenium Remote Webdriver Issue in Linux with Firefox and Python               To bypass the basic http authentication dialog, I am construction URL as mentioned in the previous posts i.e.  http://username:pwd@domain.com/ or http://username:pwd@domain.com  Here is the configuration I am using:  Selenium Server:            v2.53.1 O/S Linux Node 1:                          Linux Mint / Firefox v48 Node 2:                          Linux Mint / Firefox v45.4 Node 3:                          Windows 7 / Firefox v49.0.1 Python 2.7  **At no time, I am running more than 1 node.**  From the above configurations, **Only Windows 7 is working**; the **Firefox on Linux mint is not bypassing the authentication dialog**.  I understand that the website under test is using basic http auth but still I have tried the following options in the Firefox PROFILE too:  self.fp.set_preference("signon.autologin.proxy", True) self.fp.set_preference("network.automatic-ntlm-auth.trusted-uris", "http://%s.domainname.com" %(self.applicationName)) self.fp.set_preference("network.automatic-ntlm-auth.allow-non-fqdn", True) self.fp.set_preference("network.negotiate-auth.delegation-uris", "http://%s.domainname.com" %(self.applicationName)) self.fp.set_preference("network.negotiate-auth.trusted-uris", "http://%s.domainname.com" %(self.applicationName)) self.fp.set_preference("network.http.phishy-userpass-length", 255) self.fp.set_preference("security.csp.enable", False)  Just wanted to understand if this is a known issue or I need to do some settings on my Linux mint and Firefox.  Another thing I want to mention here. Once the URL is opened and auth dialog is displayed, I am not able to type anything in the user name or password field but I am able to click on the Login / Cancel buttons.  Please note: This is working fine with Standalone and Webdriver.               closed                umeshchhabra                2016-11-03T20:21:21Z               2019-08-19T07:09:44Z                                             3056               Allow structurally valid locators to be valid.                ## Meta - OS:  All  Selenium Version:  2.53.2  Browser:  All   For nodejs version.  In by.js we check for a valid locator:  https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/javascript/node/selenium-webdriver/lib/by.js#L258  The check fails if the locator instance argument is created from a copy of the By class located in a different instance of the selenium-webdriver module.  Given nodejs node_modules layout, if anyone writes code that wraps selenium-webdriver, two instance of selenium-webdriver is relatively easy to occur  For example, protractor setups can easily result in two modules.  Since the vast majority of the selenium-webdriver feature set consists of function calls, tolerating two module instance -- however distasteful aesthetically -- is not difficult practically.   The only exception I've found so far is in by.js, where an instanceof check is used. The instanceof is not essential to the logic, and a structural check would also work, eg  ```js function check(locator) {   if (locator instanceof By || typeof locator === 'function') {     return locator;   }   // Allow structurally equivalent locators, in case the argument   // comes from an instance of By in another node module.   if (typeof locator.using === 'string' && typeof locator.value === 'string') {     return locator;   }   for (let key in locator) {     if (locator.hasOwnProperty(key) && By.hasOwnProperty(key)) {       return By[key](locator[key]);     }   }   throw new TypeError('Invalid locator in by.js'); } ```

column3: remoteWebDriver improperly escaping escape characters in Firefox profile preference
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7, Windows 10  Selenium Version:  2.53.1  Browser:  Firefox   Browser Version:  42.0, 47 (32-bit)   ## Expected Behavior - set the firefox preference for browser.uiCustomization.state in my code should match the preference ending up in the "user.js" file for the firefox profile.  the value should look like this: user_pref("browser.uiCustomization.state", "{\"placements\":{\"PanelUI-contents\":[\"edit-controls\",\"zoom-controls\",\"new-window-button\",\"privatebrowsing-button\",\"save-page-button\",\"print-button\",\"history-panelmenu\",\"fullscreen-button\",\"find-button\",\"preferences-button\",\"add-ons-button\",\"developer-button\",\"downloads-button\"],\"addon-bar\":[\"addonbar-closebutton\",\"status-bar\"],\"PersonalToolbar\":[\"personal-bookmarks\"],\"nav-bar\":[\"urlbar-container\",\"search-container\",\"bookmarks-menu-button\",\"pocket-button\",\"home-button\",\"loop-button\"],\"TabsToolbar\":[\"tabbrowser-tabs\",\"new-tab-button\",\"alltabs-button\"],\"toolbar-menubar\":[\"menubar-items\"]},\"seen\":[],\"dirtyAreaCache\":[\"PersonalToolbar\",\"nav-bar\",\"TabsToolbar\",\"toolbar-menubar\",\"PanelUI-contents\",\"addon-bar\"],\"currentVersion\":4,\"newElementCount\":0}");  Note that the local firefox webdriver works fine, it's just remoteWebDriver that's doing this.  ## Actual Behavior - the escape characters used in my Java string are further escaped in the preference in user.js, so that the value is ignored by firefox.   it comes out as: user_pref("browser.uiCustomization.state", "{\"placements\":{\\\"PanelUI-contents\\\":[\\\"edit-controls\\\",\\\"zoom-controls\\\",\\\"new-window-button\\\",\\\"privatebrowsing-button\\\",\\\"save-page-button\\\",\\\"print-button\\\",\\\"history-panelmenu\\\",\\\"fullscreen-button\\\",\\\"find-button\\\",\\\"preferences-button\\\",\\\"add-ons-button\\\",\\\"developer-button\\\",\\\"downloads-button\\\"],\\\"addon-bar\\\":[\\\"addonbar-closebutton\\\",\\\"status-bar\\\"],\\\"PersonalToolbar\\\":[\\\"personal-bookmarks\\\"],\\\"nav-bar\\\":[\\\"urlbar-container\\\",\\\"search-container\\\",\\\"bookmarks-menu-button\\\",\\\"pocket-button\\\",\\\"home-button\\\",\\\"loop-button\\\"],\\\"TabsToolbar\":[\\\"tabbrowser-tabs\\\",\\\"new-tab-button\\\",\\\"alltabs-button\\\"],\\\"toolbar-menubar\\\":[\\\"menubar-items\\\"]},\\\"seen\\\":[],\\\"dirtyAreaCache\\\":[\\\"PersonalToolbar\\\",\\\"nav-bar\\\",\\\"TabsToolbar\\\",\\\"toolbar-menubar\\\",\\\"PanelUI-contents\\\",\\\"addon-bar\\\"],\\\"currentVersion\\\":4,\\\"newElementCount\\\":0}");  ## Steps to reproduce -  FirefoxProfile firefoxProfile = new FirefoxProfile();  firefoxProfile.setPreference("browser.download.animateNotifications", false); // move the downloads-button from the nav-bar to PanelUI-contents in order to // avoid the download progress pop up from blocking the ZoomInfo nav bar buttons firefoxProfile.setPreference("browser.uiCustomization.state", 		"{\"placements\":{\"PanelUI-contents\":[\"edit-controls\",\"zoom-controls\",\"new-window-button\"," 		+ "\"privatebrowsing-button\",\"save-page-button\",\"print-button\",\"history-panelmenu\"," 		+ "\"fullscreen-button\",\"find-button\",\"preferences-button\",\"add-ons-button\",\"developer-button\",\"downloads-button\"]," 		+ "\"addon-bar\":[\"addonbar-closebutton\",\"status-bar\"]," 		+ "\"PersonalToolbar\":[\"personal-bookmarks\"]," 		+ "\"nav-bar\":[\"urlbar-container\",\"search-container\",\"bookmarks-menu-button\",\"home-button\",\"loop-button\",\"pocket-button\"]}," 		+ "\"seen\":[]," 		+ "\"dirtyAreaCache\":[\"PersonalToolbar\",\"nav-bar\"]," 		+ "\"currentVersion\":4,\"newElementCount\":0}");  desiredCapabilities.setCapability(FirefoxDriver.PROFILE, firefoxProfile); driver = new RemoteWebDriver(new URL("http://selenium-grid:4444/wd/hub"), desiredCapabilities);

column3: if (webElement.isDisplayed) {} is not working as expected
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7 x64  Selenium Version: 3.3.1  Browser:  Firefox   Browser Version:  49.0.2 x64   ## Expected Behavior -  while using isDisplayed() method as condition in IF-statement, it has return true or false depending on whether element is present in the DOM, then if it's false, to go to ELSE-statement  ## Actual Behavior - if the element is not displayed, code gives NoSuchElementException instead of going into ELSE statement  ## Steps to reproduce -  ``` public class TestClass extends AbstractTest {      public static boolean main(String[] args ) {          Boolean conditional = true;          WebElement webElement = driver.findElement(By.id(""));          if (webElement.isDisplayed()) {             System.out.println("Element is displayed");             return conditional;         } else {             System.out.println("Element is not displayed");             conditional = false;         }          return conditional;      } } ```  Here if the element is not displayed it should print "Element is not displayed" from the 'else' statement. However, selenium is not going into 'else' if the element is not present in the 'if' condition.

The only option that I've found to be working with my setup: ` element.getAttribute("textContent")` Which is fine, but still using getText() is a bit faster.

column3: JavaScript manipulation of an element causes it to throw NoSuchElementExceptions and or InvalidOperationExceptions.
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7 Professional  Selenium Version:  2.53.1  Browser:  Chrome 56.0.2924.87 (64-bit), Firefox 46.0.1, IE 11.0.9600.18537   ## Expected Behavior -  Both tests pass  ## Actual Behavior -  When ran independently both tests pass, when ran together in the same test run the second test case fails. I can interchange the order and regardless the second case fails.   ## Steps to reproduce - Here are the tests I have stripped out much of the other setup that I do and got just to the meat and bones that are giving the issue. It seems related the the JS scripts being executed.   ``` using NUnit.Framework; using OpenQA.Selenium; using OpenQA.Selenium.Chrome; using OpenQA.Selenium.IE; using OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox; using OpenQA.Selenium.Support.UI; using System;  namespace POMAuctivaTest.TestSuite {     [TestFixture]     [Category("test")]     public class Test     {         public IWebDriver driver { get; set; }         string listingUrl = "http://cgi.sandbox.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewItem&item=110198421383#ht_1209wt_1139";         [OneTimeSetUp]         public void setUp()         {             //driver = new ChromeDriver();             //driver = new InternetExplorerDriver();             driver = new FirefoxDriver();             driver.Manage().Window.Maximize();         }          [Test]         public void test_CounterTest()         {             driver.Navigate().GoToUrl(listingUrl);             WaitForElementVisible(By.CssSelector("#but_v4-28binLnk"));  //  Buy it now button selector             driver.FindElement(By.CssSelector("#ngvi_desc_div > div > div > div.aucCounter"));             Assert.IsTrue(IsElementPresent(By.CssSelector("#ngvi_desc_div > div > div > div.aucCounter")), "Counter was not found on page");         }          [Test]         public void test_ScrollingGallery()         {             driver.Navigate().GoToUrl("https://google.com");             var listingTitleUsed = "Test Listing Do Not Bid Or Buy";             driver.Navigate().GoToUrl(listingUrl);             WaitForElementVisible(By.CssSelector("#but_v4-28binLnk"));  //  Buy it now button selector             IJavaScriptExecutor js = (IJavaScriptExecutor)driver;             var script = "document.getElementById('csgGallery').style.display='block';";             js.ExecuteScript(script);             WaitForElementVisible(By.CssSelector("div[class=csgTitle]"));             var listingName = getSudoElementContent("div[class=csgTitle]", ":after");             listingName = listingName.Replace("/", "");             listingName = listingName.Replace("\"", "");             Assert.AreEqual(listingTitleUsed, listingName);         }          [OneTimeTearDown]         public void tearDown()         {             driver.Quit();         }          public string getSudoElementContent(string selector, string cssEvent)         {             IJavaScriptExecutor js = (IJavaScriptExecutor)driver;             string script = String.Format("return window.getComputedStyle(document.querySelector('{0}'),'{1}').getPropertyValue('content')", selector, cssEvent);             string content = (String)js.ExecuteScript(script);             return content;         }          public void WaitForElementVisible(By element)         {             var attempts = 0;             while (attempts < 2)             {                 try                 {                     WebDriverWait wait = new WebDriverWait(driver, TimeSpan.FromSeconds(90));                     wait.Until(ExpectedConditions.ElementIsVisible(element));                     break;                 }                 catch (WebDriverException)                 {                     attempts++;                 }                 catch (InvalidOperationException)                 {                     attempts++;                 }             }             if (attempts >= 2)             {                 throw new NoSuchElementException("Cannot locate " + element.ToString());             }         }          public bool IsElementPresent(By by)         {             try             {                 driver.FindElement(by);                 return true;             }             catch (WebDriverTimeoutException)             {                 return false;             }             catch (NoSuchElementException)             {                 return false;             }             catch (WebDriverException)             {                 return false;             }         }     } } ```

column3: Selenium binds too many sockets
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7 Pro, Windows 10 Pro  Selenium Version: 3.3.1(python)  Browser:  Chrome 57.0.2987.133 (64-bit) (Chrome driver 2.29)   Browser Version:     ## Expected Behavior -  I tried to test with multiple proxies; therefore, I had to run multiple chrome drivers.  ## Actual Behavior -  It binds socket more than 3,000(per chrome driver) and raises errors such as no buffer space available, address already in use and other network errors related with socket.  ## Steps to reproduce -  run multiple chrome drivers with multiprocessing   sample code:  ``` from selenium import webdriver from multiprocessing import Process, freeze_support import time  def run_selenium(driver_path, proxy):     chrome_options = webdriver.ChromeOptions()     chrome_options.add_argument("--incognito")     chrome_options.add_argument("--proxy-server={}".format(proxy))      driver = webdriver.Chrome(driver_path, chrome_options=chrome_options)     driver.get('www.youtubue.com')     driver.quit()   if __name__ == '__main__':     freeze_support()     proxy_list = open('proxy_list.txt').readlines()     for proxy in proxy_list:         p = Process(target=run_selenium, args=('./chromedriver.exe', proxy))         p.start()         time.sleep(5) ```

column3: Moving from 3.0.0-beta2 to 3.0.1 breaks ability to run tests in parallel.
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7 Enterprise 64-bit Selenium Version: 3.0.1 Browser:  Chrome Browser Version:  54.0.2840.71 m  ## Expected Behavior - Ability to run tests in parallel as I have in the past using versions up to and including Selenium version 3.0.0 beta2  ## Actual Behavior - Unable to run tests in parallel. I can point our test suite at an instance of Grid 3.0.0-beta-2 and tests run in parallel without issue, when I point the exact same test suite to Grid 3.0.1 the tests run one at a time and not in parallel as expected. The configuration is exactly the same for both Grids and both Grids show 10 Chrome instances available as confirmed in the Grid Console. I'm using MSTest which I've been using with Grid for years without issue.  ## Steps to reproduce - ----Start a Grid using Selenium 3.0.0-beta2 ----  java -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.0.0-beta2.jar -role hub -port 4444 java -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.0.0-beta2.jar -role node -hub http://localhost:4444/grid/register -browser "browserName=chrome,version=ANY,maxInstances=10,platform=WINDOWS"  ---Start another grid using Selenium 3.0.1 --- ava -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1 -role hub -port 4445 java -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1 -role node -hub http://localhost:4445/grid/register -browser "browserName=chrome,version=ANY,maxInstances=10,platform=WINDOWS"  ---Point tests to Grid 3.0.0-beta2 and tests run in parallel--- var hubUri = new Uri("http://localhost:4444/wd/hub");  ---Point exact same test suite to Grid 3.0.1 and tests do not run in parallel. They run, but they only run one at a time, not in parallel--- var hubUri = new Uri("http://localhost:4445/wd/hub");

column3: Webdriver opens thousands of connections
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7 64-Bit  Selenium Version:   Name: selenium Version: 3.0.2 Summary: Python bindings for Selenium Home-page: https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/ Author: UNKNOWN Author-email: UNKNOWN License: UNKNOWN Location: c:\python27\lib\site-packages  Browser:  Chrome driver   Browser Version:  55.0.2883.87 m (64-bit)   ## Expected Behavior - Webdriver creates one connection and reuses it to send commands to the driver  ## Actual Behavior - There is a new connection being created every time webdriver is doing something in the browser. The browser object does not get recreated, it just creates a new connection and carries on but eventually there are no more free ports available to create new connection and the program dies ## Steps to reproduce - Summary: Driver object gets created and then being mapped to a thread that will run the tests. after that the thread is started and tests start running. As tests run and I do netstat -a -n | find /c "" the count of open connection on the port that webdriver started on is rapidly increasing and can go up into 16k range and then shortly after everything crashes.  This is the function that returns a driver object: ```python @staticmethod     def get_driver(browser_id):         """         This method will return new instance of a webdriver depending on the browser_id that was passed to it         @id browser_id         """         if browser_id == 0:             return webdriver.PhantomJS()         elif browser_id == 1:             return webdriver.Chrome()         elif browser_id == 2:             return webdriver.Firefox()         elif browser_id == 3:             return webdriver.Opera()         elif browser_id == 4:             return webdriver.Ie()         else:             raise Exception("There is no support for browser_id: {}".format(browser_id)) ``` This is the method that maps the thread to the driver: ```python @staticmethod     def map(thread, driver, driver_id):         """         This method explicitly maps thread to driver object         :param thread: thread object ex. threading.current_thread()         :param driver: WebDriver instance of the object ex. webdriver.Chrome()         :param driver_id: int from 0 to 4 (See @Runner#get_driver() for more documentation of browser/driver IDs)         :return: None         """         Browser.__driver_map[thread] = {"driver": driver, "driver_id": driver_id}         MyLogger.log.info("Mapped thread: {} to driver: {}.\n\tNew Map Object: {}".format(thread, driver,                                                                                           Browser.__driver_map)) ``` And finally this is the method that gets called to get the driver object in order to do stuff in the browser: ```python  @staticmethod     def get_driver():         """         This method can be called from any thread without any arguments, as long as the thread was mapped to the driver         during the initialization of the test cycle, the caller will receive proper driver object depending on the         thread that it was called from         :return:         """         thread = threading.current_thread()         Browser.CALLS += 1         MyLogger.log.debug(">>> Calls: {}".format(Browser.CALLS))         return Browser.__driver_map[thread]["driver"]  ```

column3: Grid: Node not registering successfully to the hub in v3.3

It works in 3.2.  ## Actual Behavior - The node never seems to be successfully registered at all. According to the log it is registered and then unregistered after just a few seconds. column3: Context Menu Selenium selection Issue
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7 (64bit)  Selenium Version:  2.9.1, IDE  Browser:  Firefox    Browser Version:  51.0.1   ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25435108/22432390/9bd5fe1a-e6c9-11e6-8d67-e6ce08dd51d9.png)  ## Expected Behavior - Right clicking on page should display context menu with selenium options for assert/verify commands and the "Show All Command" sub-menu option.  ## Actual Behavior - Context menu is displayed but there are no selenium commands or sub-menu option:  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25435108/22431204/908c81ae-e6c5-11e6-9375-cdd0184dfd80.png)    ## Steps to reproduce - 1.) Go to: https:/act.ucsd.edu/breathofhopewalk 2.) With the IDE not running or running (recording or not) right click on "Sponsorship Level" dropdown list (or any other field) 3.) Context menu displayed without Selenium selection     I've uninstalled/reinstalled the Selenium plugin several times but the problem still persist. This was originally working without issue. When the problem started I noticed that the context menu seemed to work on correctly on some sites and not on others. Currently, it has stopped working altogether. I've searched the web and this site for possible related issue but could find nothing that help.  I'm stuck at this point. Any help would be highly appreciated.  Thanks in advance.

column3: IE Driver Beta: initialBrowserUrl capability is ignored, and its default value has changed
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7 Selenium Version: a little after 3.3 (commit e9a906a347dcdb9991c7705fa4a291152982c5be), though it doesn't much matter Browser:  Internet Exporer Browser Version:  9.0.8112.16421  IE Driver Beta Version: 3.3.99.1  ## Expected Behavior - The `initialBrowserUrl` capability should be set to the value specified in the New Session request.  Also, the default value when it is not specified used to be `"http://localhost:5555/"`, which is the "This is the initial start page for the WebDriver server" page.   ## Actual Behavior - The default value of `initialBrowserUrl` (inside the `se:ieOptions` object) is now empty (`""`), and the browser starts on whatever the default homepage is.  Even if I specify an `initialBrowserUrl` capability in the `alwaysMatch` section, it is disregarded.  I do understand this capability is something of a "best-effort" capability, and I can work around this if need be.  ## Steps to reproduce - I'm using the Selenium Standalone Server and just curling commands to the driver to send a minimal set of capabilities:  `curl -sd'{"desiredCapabilities": {"browserName": "internet explorer", "se:ieOptions": {"initialBrowserUrl": "http://www.example.com/"}}}' http://localhost:26657/wd/hub/session`  The Selenium Standalone Server translates that request into:  ```json {   "desiredCapabilities": {     "se:ieOptions": {       "initialBrowserUrl": "http://www.example.com/"     },     "browserName": "internet explorer"   },   "requiredCapabilities": {},   "capabilities": {     "desiredCapabilities": {       "se:ieOptions": {         "initialBrowserUrl": "http://www.example.com/"       },       "browserName": "internet explorer"     },     "requiredCapabilities": {}   },   "alwaysMatch": {     "se:ieOptions": {       "initialBrowserUrl": "http://www.example.com/"     }   },   "firstMatch": [     {       "browserName": "internet explorer"     }   ] } ```  but the response is (with irrelevant keys omitted):  ```json {     "value": {         "capabilities": {             "se:ieOptions": {                 "initialBrowserUrl": ""             }         },         "sessionId": "a5d84976-e8f1-4bae-b887-9dc2dc3aeca0"     } } ```

column3: IE authentication does not work with Selenium 3.0.1
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7 Selenium Version: 3.0.1 Browser:  IE 11  ## Expected Behavior - When I used Selenium 2.53 with IE 11 the code (see below) did work for IE popup authentication. After upgrade to Selenium 3.0.1 it does not work anymore. I thought I can re-use this code.  ## Actual Behavior - IE popup authentication window does not work with Selenium 3.0.1  ## Steps to reproduce - CODE which worked in Selenium 2.53, but not in Selenium 3.0.1                   String username = "myUserID";         String pwd = "myPWD";         WebDriverWait wait = new WebDriverWait(driver, 10);         Alert alert = wait.until(ExpectedConditions.alertIsPresent());         alert.authenticateUsing(new UserAndPassword(username, pwd));

column3: Cannot get cookies from PDF-only windows when using IE with IEDriverServer
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7 Selenium Version:  3.3.0 Browser:  IE Browser Version:  11.0.9600.18617, Update Version: 11.0.40  ## Expected Behavior - Users should be able to obtain browser cookies from PDF-only browser windows.  This does not work using IEDriver server 3.3.0.0, but does work with ChromeDriver 2.28.455520 and GeckoDriver 0.15.0.  ## Actual Behavior - I get a Net::Timeout exception in Ruby.  ## Steps to reproduce -  Step 1.  Open Internet Explorer Step 2.  Navigate to a pdf (e.g., http://myserver/my_pdf.pdf) Step 3.  Verify that the PDF is displayed in the main browser window. Step 4.  Attempt to read the browser's cookies.  I'm using Ruby so for me, it's something like...  	cookie_string = ""  	# Read the cookie hash... 	$driver.manage.all_cookies.each { |cookie| 		# consolidate the cookie hash to a string                  # (e.g., cookie_name1=cookie_val1;cookie_name2=cookie_val2;etc...) 	    	cookie_string = cookie_string + "#{cookie[:name]}=#{cookie[:value]};"   	}  	puts "COOKIES! -> #{cookie_string}"

column3: Python documentation should include info on drivers
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7 Selenium Version:  3.0.2 Browser:  Firefox/Chrome  My issued is that the following information has only been known to me not through the python documentation where it should be. I eventually found the pypi documentation which suggested you need the webdrivers and then when I go to raise an issue, I finally find all the information I've spent hours looking for. Please just add this text into the documentation:  - here: http://selenium-python.readthedocs.io/ - and why not here: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/selenium   ``` Since Firefox version 48, Mozilla requires all add-ons to be signed. Until recently, Firefox support in Selenium was exclusively provided by an add-on. As this add-on is not currently signed, this solution does not work with the latest Firefox releases. As an alternative, Mozilla are working on a WebDriver specification compliant implementation named GeckoDriver. Please note that the specification is not complete, and that Selenium itself does not comply with the specification at this time. This means that features previously available through Selenium will not be available using GeckoDriver.  Any issue logged here for Firefox 48 or later will be closed as a duplicate of #2559. Our recommendation is to switch to GeckoDriver, or to continue testing on Firefox 45 until GeckoDriver is a viable option for you. If you are interested in helping us to sign the add-on to restore support for later Firefox versions, please see the following comment for what's needed: https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/issues/2942#issuecomment-259717567  If the issue is with Google Chrome consider logging an issue with chromedriver instead: https://sites.google.com/a/chromium.org/chromedriver/help  If the issue is with Microsoft Edge consider logging an issue with Microsoft instead: https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/  If the issue is with Firefox GeckoDriver (aka Marionette) consider logging an issue with Mozilla: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/buglist.cgi?product=Testing&component=Marionette  If the issue is with Safari, only Safari 10+ is supported. Please log any Safari issue with Apple: https://bugreport.apple.com/  If the issue is with PhantomJS consider logging an issue with Ghostdriver: https://github.com/detro/ghostdriver ``` ## Expected Behavior - The documentation has all the relevant information to get started using Selenium. This is my first experience with Selenium and I am severely disheartened and annoyed by the poor documentation. Within the space of around 3-4 hours, I was just about able to get Chrome working and then I finally found this information. This should be in the docs from the get go, I should not have to raise an issue to find what should be in the documentation.  ## Actual Behavior - Documentation has the code quoted bit attached so that no-one else has to go on a wild goose chase.  ## Steps to reproduce - Try to install, setup, and run a basic test as a beginner to Selenium. Good luck to you, might take you a while but I'm sure you'll eventually come to raise a GitHub issue and find the relevant information. Took me around 3 hours of Googling, tinkering, hacking, stack exchanging, reading blogs etc. before I found this information, I don't recommend trying to replicate this issue, I just recommend fixing it. Add the information into the docs and then it won't happen again.

column3: WebElement.FindElement(By.XPath) returns element not relative to parent but to the document
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7 Selenium Version:  3.0.1.0 Browser:  Chrome  When calling WebElement.FindElement(By.XPath('//element') getting wrong results. the result is same as Driver.FindElement(By.XPath('//element') - instead of the element inside that parent.  I have a workaround: WebElement.FindElement(By.XPath('.//element') (add '.') But I think this is unnecessary because I try to find element inside its parent   Page for example: ```html        firstBtn       secondBtn    ``` Code: ```C# // wrongly clicks first button Driver.FindElement(By.Id("second")).FindElement(By.XPath("//button")).Click(); // works correct Driver.FindElement(By.Id("second")).FindElement(By.XPath(".//button")).Click(); ```

column3: HtmlUnitDriver does not evaluate CSS3 pseudo class :target correctly
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7 Selenium Version:  3.0.1 Browser:  HtmlUnit Browser Version:  2.23.2  ## Expected Behavior - When accessing a website with an anchor, CSS styles for a matching :target should apply.  ## Actual Behavior - The styles do not apply.  ## Steps to reproduce - Minimal test site: ```     .tab div {     display: none; }  .tab div:target {     display: block; }     Link       Content     ```  Minimal Java test code: ``` getWebDriver().get(TEST_URL); getWebDriver().findElement(By.id("link")).click(); System.out.println(getWebDriver().findElement(By.id("anchor")).isDisplayed()); getWebDriver().get(TEST_URL + "#anchor"); System.out.println(getWebDriver().findElement(By.id("anchor")).isDisplayed()); ```  Result: Both times 'false' ist printed.

column3: Selenium 3 with Firefox 49 Portable Edition doesn't start
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7 Selenium Version:  3.0.1 Browser:  Firefox 49.0.2 Portable Edition  ## Expected Behavior - Run Firefox Portable Edition and display the text message "test is executed" in my console. ## Actual Behavior - Firefox is launched but nothing else after that. Just the following logs : `1478965841203   geckodriver INFO    Listening on 127.0.0.1:45941 nov. 12, 2016 4:50:41 PM org.openqa.selenium.remote.ProtocolHandshake createSession INFOS: Attempting bi-dialect session, assuming Postel's Law holds true on the remote end 1478965841598   mozprofile::profile INFO    Using profile path d:\Profiles\\AppData\Local\Temp\rust_mozprofile.TisH4gXwlj3K 1478967041359   geckodriver::marionette INFO    Starting browser D:\firefox-portable\FirefoxPortablex64-48.0.2\FirefoxPortable.exe 1478967041388   geckodriver::marionette INFO    Connecting to Marionette on localhost:52702` ## Steps to reproduce - Run the JUnit test.  ` public class SeleniumWithFirefoxPortableEditionTest {   WebDriver webDriver = new FirefoxDriver();   static {     // 1) Work with native Firefox     System.setProperty("webdriver.gecko.driver", ClassLoader.getSystemResource("webdriver/geckodriver_0.11.1.exe").getFile());      // 2) Don't work when I add these 2 properties     //        System.setProperty("webdriver.firefox.marionette", "true");     //        System.setProperty("webdriver.firefox.bin", "D:\\firefox-portable\\FirefoxPortablex64-49.0.2\\FirefoxPortable.exe");`   ` }   @Test   public void test() {     System.out.println("test is executed");    }  }`  I precise I also added the  geckodriver executable path in system environment variable (but it changed nothing) like it mentionned here  : https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/QA/Marionette/WebDriver

column3: does not read custom certificates installed globally in firefox.
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7 Selenium Version:  3.0.1 Browser:  Firefox Browser Version:  50.0.2 (64-bit) Programming Language: Java 7 or 8  ## Expected Behavior - Should start with browser certificates already installed in the browser of that system.  ## Actual Behavior - does not read custom certificates. As a result throws security warning and does not go to destination page.   ## Steps to reproduce - 1. Use a network that require a custom certificate to install in your system to connect to internet.  2. Start Firefox 50.0.2 browser using geckoDriver                                  			System.setProperty("webdriver.gecko.driver",System.getProperty("user.dir")+ "//driver//geckodriver.exe"); 			DesiredCapabilities cap = DesiredCapabilities.firefox(); 	        LoggingPreferences logPrefs = new LoggingPreferences(); 	        logPrefs.enable(LogType.BROWSER, Level.SEVERE); 	        cap.setCapability(CapabilityType.LOGGING_PREFS, logPrefs); 	        cap.setBrowserName("firefox"); 	        cap.setPlatform(Platform.ANY); 	        cap.setCapability(CapabilityType.ACCEPT_SSL_CERTS, true); 	        cap.setCapability(CapabilityType.ENABLE_PROFILING_CAPABILITY, true); 			driver = new FirefoxDriver(cap); 3. Try to go to any URL, for example: "http://www.google.com"                driver.get(url); 4. See the warning that, you would see if the required certificate was not installed in your system.

column3: selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1 can not find firefox binary configured in Json
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7 Selenium Version:  3.0.1 Browser:  Firefox Browser Version:  49.0.2  ## Expected Behavior - Before upgrading to selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1 I was running multiple Firefox ESR versions on my grid node with selenium-server-standalone-2.45.0. The configuration in JSON looks like this   `{           "browserName": "firefox",           "version": "49.0.2",           "platform": "WINDOWS", 		  "firefox_binary": "C:\Program Files (x86)\Mozilla Firefox\ESR\Firefox_49.0.2\firefox.exe",           "maxInstances": 5, 		  "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"         },`  Firefox 49.0.2 is starting and I can use multiple firefox version on my grid node.  ## Actual Behavior -  Exception: Cannot find firefox binary in PATH. Make sure firefox is installed.  When I install Firefox in C:\Program Files (x86)\Mozilla Firefox which is the default location it works fine and firefox is starting.  ## Steps to reproduce - `{           "browserName": "firefox",           "version": "49.0.2",           "platform": "WINDOWS", 		  "firefox_binary": "C:\Program Files (x86)\Mozilla Firefox\ESR\Firefox_49.0.2\firefox.exe",           "maxInstances": 5, 		  "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"         },`

column3: Upgrading From 3.0.0 beta2 to 3.0.1 has broken my tests
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7  Selenium Version:  3.0.1  Browser:  Chrome Firefox   Browser Version:    Chrome Version 54.0.2840.87 m Firefox Version 49.0.2  ## Expected Behavior - After creating a remote webdriver instance the test suite should continue to the test method without error ## Actual Behavior - After creating a remote webdriver instance I receive the following message:  Nov 04, 2016 2:12:46 PM org.openqa.selenium.remote.ProtocolHandshake createSession INFO: Attempting bi-dialect session, assuming Postel's Law holds true on the remote end Nov 04, 2016 2:12:48 PM org.openqa.selenium.remote.ProtocolHandshake createSession INFO: Detected dialect: OSS  The happens every time a new browser is created. The test will continue to run up until a certain point then the browser will fail to be created and all of the remaining tests will be skipped.  ## Steps to reproduce -  This is the part of the before method that seems to give me trouble. @BeforeMethod(alwaysRun = true) 	@Parameters("myBrowser") 	public void beforemethod(String myBrowser, Method method) throws InterruptedException, MalformedURLException{ 		RemoteWebDriver driver = null; 		if(myBrowser.equals("chrome")){ 			new DesiredCapabilities(); 			DesiredCapabilities capabilities = DesiredCapabilities.chrome(); 			capabilities.setBrowserName("chrome"); 			capabilities.setPlatform(Platform.WINDOWS); 		    driver = new RemoteWebDriver(new URL("http://localhost:4444/wd/hub"), capabilities); 			driver.manage().window().maximize(); 		} }  Console prints the info message at the new RemoteWebDriver line.   **chrome_node.json:** {   "capabilities":   [     { 	  "platform": "WINDOWS",  		       "browserName": "chrome",       "maxInstances": 5,       "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"     }   ],   "proxy": "org.openqa.grid.selenium.proxy.DefaultRemoteProxy",   "maxSession": 5,   "port": 5555,   "register": true,   "registerCycle": 5000,   "hub": "http://localhost:4444" }  **start_hub.bat** which is used to start the hub c: cd %userprofile%\automated-testing\src\grid java -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1.jar -role hub -hubConfig %userprofile%\automated-testing\src\grid\grid_hub.json cmd /k  **grid_hub.json** {   "host": null,   "port": 4444,   "newSessionWaitTimeout": -1,   "servlets" : [],   "prioritizer": null,   "capabilityMatcher": "org.openqa.grid.internal.utils.DefaultCapabilityMatcher",   "throwOnCapabilityNotPresent": true,   "nodePolling": 5000,   "cleanUpCycle": 5000,   "browserTimeout": 0,   "jettyMaxThreads":-1,   "maxSessions":10 }   **start_chrome_node.bat** which is used to start the node and connect to the hub c: cd %userprofile%\automated-testing\src\grid java -jar -Dwebdriver.chrome.driver=%userprofile%\automated-testing\src\grid\chromedriver.exe selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1.jar -role node -nodeConfig %userprofile%\automated-testing\src\grid\chrome_node.json  cmd /k   **chrome_node.json** {   "capabilities":   [     {       "platform": "WINDOWS",  		       "browserName": "chrome",       "maxInstances": 5,       "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"     }   ],   "proxy": "org.openqa.grid.selenium.proxy.DefaultRemoteProxy",   "maxSession": 5,   "port": 5555,   "register": true,   "registerCycle": 5000,   "hub": "http://localhost:4444" }

column3: IEDriverServer 2.53.1 crashing on Windows 7 with IE11
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7  Selenium Version:  2.53.1  Browser:  IE   Browser Version:  11   ## Expected Behavior - Code navigates to screen, clicks button. ## Actual Behavior - Code navigates to screen, call to WebDriverWait.until(ExpectedConditions.elementToBeClickable() passes the isEnabled check (I can see it passing when turning on TRACE level logging for IEDriverServer) but fails to click the element. Executing: [take screenshot]) 10:41:16.271 INFO - Executing: [delete session: 68f90fd9-d638-4cbb-8861-939fc5eed09b])  A few lines from the bottom of the log, you can see a call into Element.cpp at line 499. This is where the error is coming from. For some reason, IHTMLElement2::getBoundingClientRect seems to be returning a negative value? As I watch the test case execute, I can see the button the code is trying to click on. It is visible and enabled on the screen.  ## Steps to reproduce -  Unfortunately, I cannot provide exact code to reproduce the issue as the test case is for an internal piece of software. I can, however, explain to you what it is doing. The code navigates to a screen on the UI and then attempts to click a button. The clicking of the button is done in this manner: `WebElement ele = WebDriverWait.until(ExpectedConditions.elementToBeClickable(); ele.click();`  Obviously that is more along the lines of pseudo-code, but you get the idea.

column3: Set WebDriver Binary Path in NodeConfig JSON
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 7  Selenium Version:   3.0.1  Browser:   Chrome   Browser Version:    54.0.2840.71 (64-bit)   ## Expected Behavior - I expect to be able to pass in a path to the webdriver in my node configuration.  ## Actual Behavior - See attached logs files. [hubDebugOutput.txt](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/files/586632/hubDebugOutput.txt) [nodeDebugOutput.txt](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/files/586633/nodeDebugOutput.txt)    ## Steps to reproduce -  node config ``` {   "capabilities":   [     {       "browserName": "firefox",       "maxInstances": 5,       "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"     },     {       "browserName": "chrome",       "maxInstances": 5,       "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"     },     {       "browserName": "internet explorer",       "maxInstances": 1,       "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"     }   ],   "proxy": "org.openqa.grid.selenium.proxy.DefaultRemoteProxy",   "maxSession": 5,   "port": 5555,   "register": true,   "registerCycle": 5000,   "hub": "http://localhost:4444/grid/register",   "Dwebdriver.chrome.driver=drivers/chromedriver_2.25.exe" : "" } ``` ``` also tried "Dwebdriver.chrome.driver=.\\drivers\\chromedriver_2.25.exe" : "" ```  hub config ``` {   "_comment": "Configuration for Hub",   "host": null,   "port": 4444,   "cleanupCycle": 5000,   "nodePolling": 5000,   "timeout": 300000,   "newSessionWaitTimeout": -1,   "servlets": [],   "prioritizer": null,   "capabilityMatcher": "org.openqa.grid.internal.utils.DefaultCapabilityMatcher",   "throwOnCapabilityNotPresent": true,   "platform": "WINDOWS" } ```  start hub cmd ``` echo "Starting Selenium Hub"  java -jar .\selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1.jar -role hub -hubConfig hub_config.json -debug > .\debug\hubDebugOutput.txt 2>&1 ```  start node cmd ``` echo "Starting Selenium Node"  java -jar .\selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1.jar -role node -nodeConfig node_config.json -debug > .\debug\nodeDebugOutput.txt 2>&1 ```

column3: Unable to create Selenium 3 Firefox Profile
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 2012  Selenium Version: 3.3.1    Browser:   Firefox   Browser Version:    51.0, 52.0  ## Expected Behavior - Firefox profile should spin up with Selenium 3  ## Actual Behavior - No Firefox profile is created.  ## Steps to reproduce -  Selenium Version : 3.3.1  I am trying to start up a windows node using the following command  `    java -role node -nodeConfig <%=@selenium_node %> -Dwebdriver.firefox.profile <%=@firefox_profile_directory %> -jar <%=@selenium_jar %>`  I have put the `-D...` command line parameters before the `-jar` prompt as discussed here:  > https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/issues/2566  However, I get the error:  > Unrecognised option: -role Error: Could not create the Java Virtual > Machine. Error: A fatal exception  has occurred.  Program will exit.  If I try the other way around e.g.   `java -role node -Dwebdriver.firefox.profile <%=@firefox_profile_directory %> -nodeConfig <%=@selenium_node %>  -jar <%=@selenium_jar %>`  or  `java -Dwebdriver.firefox.profile <%=@firefox_profile_directory %> -jar <%=@selenium_jar %> -role node -nodeConfig <%=@selenium_node %>`  I get the error:   > Could not find or load main class C:\...\firefox\profile

column3: New Session W3C compliant response erroneously interpreted
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 10, Node 6.3.1 Selenium Version:  3.0.1, Node, JavaScript bindings Browser:  Custom server implementation Browser Version:  N/A  ## Expected Behavior - Based on the current W3C specs the New Session command will return a 500 HTTP status code and a response body with 'error', 'message' and 'stacktrace' fields when a new session cannot be created. That should be handled by the webdriver as a valid error response resulting in the error message 'SessionNotCreatedError: A new session could not be created.' being printed out.  ## Actual Behavior - The Executor class in https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/javascript/node/selenium-webdriver/lib/http.js has the following comment:  'The executor will automatically switch to the W3C wire protocol if the remote end returns a compliant response to a new session command.'  However, when a compliant error message is returned to the New Session command request, the 'execute' function will set the 'w3c' flag only after the response has been parsed and interpreted. This causes the 'parseHttpResponse' not to throw the expected exception. Instead the execute function will move on and look for the 'sessionId' field within the response, resulting in a wrong error 'Unable to parse new session response'  ## Steps to reproduce - Implement a response to the New Session command which returns a 500 HTTP status code and a JSON body with the three fields mentioned above. Debug in Node the http.js file mentioned above and see that the compliant error is not handled as expected by the Executor class, based on the described behaviour.  ## Workaround - Force the Executor to interpret the New Session response in a W3C compliant way, by explicitly setting:  driver.executor_.w3c = true;

column3: Loading default user profile does not work (Selenium 3.0.0)
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 10 and OSX  Selenium Version: Webdriver JS  3.0.0  Browser:  Chrome latest version  Browser Version:  Chrome 54.x.x.x latest   ## Expected Behavior -  Loading the following code should launch chrome with my default profile: ``` var webdriver = require('selenium-webdriver'),     chrome = require('selenium-webdriver/chrome'),     By = webdriver.By,     until = webdriver.until,     button = webdriver.Button,     promise = webdriver.promise;     fs = require('fs');      var o = new chrome.Options();     o.addArguments("user-data-dir=/Users/conquerjs/Library/Application Support/Google/Chrome/");     var driver = new webdriver.Builder().withCapabilities(webdriver.Capabilities.chrome()).setChromeOptions(o).build();  driver.get('http://www.google.com');    driver.sleep(5000);   driver.quit();   ``` ## Actual Behavior -  This actually does launch the browser with my default profile and all extensions loaded, but never navigates to page `driver.get('news.google.com');` it just hangs there. It seems that the "Chrome automation extension" that drives the automation doesn't get loaded, that's the only thing I can see that's different. Is this a bug? column3: [error] Could not connect to Selenium Server. Have you started the Selenium Server yet?
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 10 64bit  Selenium Version:   IDE: 2.9.1 Standalone server: 3.3.1   Browser:  Firefox 52.0.2 64bit   ## Expected Behavior - Run Selenium IDE testscript on Chrome ## Actual Behavior - [error] Could not connect to Selenium Server. Have you started the Selenium Server yet? ## Steps to reproduce - 1. created test script via firefox selenium IDE. 2. Enable webdriver in selenium IDE, change to chrome 3. Run in cmd, **java -Dbwebdriver.chrome.driver=chromedriver.exe -jar selenium-server-standalone- 3.3.1.jar -port 5555** Received following response: =================================== E:\Data\Desktop\Selenium Webdriver\Installer>java -Dbwebdriver.chrome.driver=chromedriver.exe -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.3.1.jar -port 5555 18:58:31.375 INFO - Selenium build info: version: '3.3.1', revision: '5234b32' 18:58:31.376 INFO - Launching a standalone Selenium Server 2017-04-03 18:58:31.394:INFO::main: Logging initialized @227ms to org.seleniumhq.jetty9.util.log.StdErrLog 18:58:31.437 INFO - Driver class not found: com.opera.core.systems.OperaDriver 18:58:31.437 INFO - Driver provider com.opera.core.systems.OperaDriver registration is skipped: Unable to create new instances on this machine. 18:58:31.438 INFO - Driver class not found: com.opera.core.systems.OperaDriver 18:58:31.438 INFO - Driver provider com.opera.core.systems.OperaDriver is not registered 18:58:31.444 INFO - Driver provider org.openqa.selenium.safari.SafariDriver registration is skipped:  registration capabilities Capabilities [{browserName=safari, version=, platform=MAC}] does not match the current platform WIN10 2017-04-03 18:58:31.484:INFO:osjs.Server:main: jetty-9.2.20.v20161216 2017-04-03 18:58:31.513:INFO:osjsh.ContextHandler:main: Started o.s.j.s.ServletContextHandler@685cb137{/,null,AVAILABLE} 2017-04-03 18:58:31.599:INFO:osjs.AbstractConnector:main: Started ServerConnector@49993335{HTTP/1.1,[http/1.1]}{0.0.0.0:5555} 2017-04-03 18:58:31.600:INFO:osjs.Server:main: Started @433ms **18:58:31.600 INFO - Selenium Server is up and running** ===============================================  4. run the testscript (tested working fine in firefox), received [error] Could not connect to Selenium Server. Have you started the Selenium Server yet?  5. this is how my testscript looks like ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/26647918/24606765/512338ce-18a1-11e7-9826-c17e010332ae.png)   Could anyone help with this please?I am doing a self learning on selenium, but encountered some issues with it. I have tried to google this error messageï¼Œ the solution provided is either disabled webdriver or installed selenium server.   Note, I have tested the selenium standalone server 2.53.1/3.1.0/3.2.0,  initially it keep returning error when try to run the selenium server in cmd : - _a. port 4444 in used b.Exception in thread "main" com.beust.jcommander.ParameterException: Was passed main parameter 'chromedriver.exe' but no main parameter was defined_

column3: IE Driver Beta 3.3.99.4- Unable to create new remote session
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 10 - Build 14393 Selenium Version: 3.3.1 (Java Bindings) Browser:  Internet Explorer Browser Version:  11.0.14393 IE Driver Version: 3.3.99.4  ## Expected Behavior - Internet Explorer will be started on the remote node.  ## Actual Behavior - Internet Explorer launches on the node with the start page, and the test immediately fails as Grid is unable to create a new session. [node output](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/files/907563/node.txt) [stack-trace](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/files/907564/stack-trace.txt)  ## Steps to reproduce - [Simple java test to reproduce the issue](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/files/907553/repro.java.txt)  Just starting the connection is enough to trigger the behaviour. Substituting the beta driver for the current release version of 3.3.0 allows me to verify the rest of my configuration is correct.

Click and drag on any of the lines of the test cases or any of the command lines and try to drag it.

column3: Specified number of browsers in a node is disregarded in 3.0.1
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 10 Selenium Version:  3.0.1 Browser:  N.A.  ## Expected Behavior - When I run the following script in version 2.53.1, I get the specified number of browsers ``` start "Hub" java -jar selenium-server-standalone-2.53.1.jar -role hub -maxSession 5  start "5555" java -jar selenium-server-standalone-2.53.1.jar -role node -browser "browserName=firefox, maxInstances=4" -hub http://localhost:4444/grid/register -port 5555 -maxSession 3  start "5556" java -Dwebdriver.chrome.driver=C:\ChromeDriver\chromedriver.exe -jar selenium-server-standalone-2.53.1.jar -role node -browser "browserName=chrome, maxInstances=4" -hub http://localhost:4444/grid/register -port 5556 -maxSession 3  start "5557" java -Dwebdriver.ie.driver=C:\IEDriverServer\IEDriverServer.exe -jar selenium-server-standalone-2.53.1.jar -role node -browser "browserName=internet explorer, version=11, maxInstances=4" -hub http://localhost:4444/grid/register -port 5557 -maxSession 3  ```  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10740806/20057794/7a804c5a-a4e5-11e6-9a1c-935e1520daa7.png)  ## Actual Behavior - But when I run the same script in version 3.0.1, I only get one browser per node. As this behavior changed? Am I missing something? Thanks  ``` start "Hub" java -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1.jar -role hub -maxSession 5  start "5555" java -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1.jar -role node -browser "browserName=firefox, maxInstances=4" -hub http://localhost:4444/grid/register -port 5555 -maxSession 3  start "5556" java -Dwebdriver.chrome.driver=C:\ChromeDriver\chromedriver.exe -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1.jar -role node -browser "browserName=chrome, maxInstances=4" -hub http://localhost:4444/grid/register -port 5556 -maxSession 3  start "5557" java -Dwebdriver.ie.driver=C:\IEDriverServer\IEDriverServer.exe -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1.jar -role node -browser "browserName=internet explorer, version=11, maxInstances=4" -hub http://localhost:4444/grid/register -port 5557 -maxSession 3 ```  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10740806/20057762/4c7b6ede-a4e5-11e6-97a4-aec52bb4a98e.png)  ## Steps to reproduce - Stated above

column3: Login redirection immediately back to login page with Error
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 10 Selenium Version:  3.0.1 Browser:  Chrome Browser Version:  54.0.2840.99 m (64-bit)  ## Expected Behavior - After valid login, redirection to the applications internal Home page should happen  ## Actual Behavior - Intermittently it is throwing back to the login page with error as "Expected condition failed: waiting for visibility of Proxy element for: DefaultElementLocator 'By.xpath: //*[@id='pt1:pgl3']/tbody/tr/td[2]/span' (tried for 20 second(s) with 500 MILLISECONDS interval)"  ## Steps to reproduce - 1. Configuration: Windows 10, Selenium 3.0.1, Chrome 54.0.2840.99 m (64-bit), ChromeDriverwin32 2. Accessed the Application Login page 3. Entered valid login credentials and submitted 4. Redirection to internal home page and within a second its throwing back to the Login page Note: Same script works fine on IE, FF, Safari. ONLY on Chrome the selenium sync is not consistent. Finding of the element is before the page is even getting loaded. Have used Thread.sleep, waitforPagetoLoad, waitforelementvisible logic but nothing works

column3: Firefox / Windows: setting preferences with an empty profile directory on longer works
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 10 Selenium Version:   nodejs [selenium-webdriver](https://www.npmjs.com/package/selenium-webdriver) 3.0.1 Browser:  Firefox  Browser Version:   50.0.2 using marionette with geckodriver 0.11.1  ## Expected Behavior - Creating a Firefox profile with an empty template directory and setting a preference starts Firefox with that preference set.  ## Actual Behavior - The preference is not set.  This works fine on Linux and used to work on Windows "previously".  ## Steps to reproduce - Execute the following script in a directory that contains an empty directory 'someprofile': ``` var os = require('os'); var path = require('path'); var webdriver = require('selenium-webdriver'); var firefox = require('selenium-webdriver/firefox');  var profile = new firefox.Profile(path.join(process.cwd(), 'someprofile')); profile.setPreference('media.navigator.streams.fake', true); var firefoxOptions = new firefox.Options()   .setProfile(profile);  var driver = new webdriver.Builder()     .setFirefoxOptions(firefoxOptions)     .forBrowser('firefox'); driver.getCapabilities().set('marionette', true); driver = driver.build(); ``` Note that this opens the firstrun page which does not happen if the template directory is omitted. Navigate to about:config, search for **media.navigator.streams.fake** which is not there.  ```firefoxOptions``` has preferences_ and template_ set correctly. The template directory created during writeToDisk looks fine as well. Reverting to an earlier version (3.0.0-beta-3) where it used work did not work either. Does that suggest it is a geckodriver issue?

column3: Issue - [error] locator not found: id=Email, error = TypeError: Argument 1 of Window.getComputedStyle does not implement interface Element
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 10 Selenium IDE:  2.9.1 Browser:  Firefox 51.0.1  I am learning Selenium and I am working on identifying web elements using Firebug in Selenium IDE. After entering the web elements in the Table tab of the IDE, I wanted to find them using the 'Find' button. I was trying to find the Email text box but when I click the find button, it displays the following error message "locator not found: id=Email, error = TypeError: Argument 1 of Window.getComputedStyle does not implement interface Element".  But it enters the value  in the email textbox in the Google page that I have stored in the value row in the IDE after displaying the error message. This used to work so I verified the firefox version. it was 51.0.1.  Since I had downgraded the version due to another issue to 50.1.0, I was a little surprised and uninstalled and re-installed 50.1. And I do not get the mentioned error.  Also another issue in 51.0.1 is I do not get the option "Show available Commands" in the context menu. and here i got the temporary solution to downgrade from 51.0 to 50.1  Thanks for the support

column3: EventFiringWebDriver: does not wrap elements in executeScript result
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 10  Selenium Version:  3.0.1  Browser:  n/a   Browser Version:  n/a   ## Expected Behavior -  Executing a script (synchronous or asynchronous) that returns a `WebElement` or an object containing one or more `WebElement` instances should wrap those `WebElement` instances in `EventFiringWebElement` instances and return a result object containing it/them.  ## Actual Behavior -  `executeScript` and `executeAsyncScript` pass their `result` object through without transforming `WebElement` instances to `EventFiringWebElement` instances.  ## Steps to reproduce -   ```kotlin val result = eventFiringWebDriver.executeScript("return [document.head, document.body];") result as List<*> check(result.all { element ->     element as WebElement     element.javaClass.simpleName == "EventFiringWebElement" }) ```

column3: cannot find firefox.exe when ff is not installed at default location.
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 10  Selenium Version:  3.0.1  Browser:  Firefox   Browser Version:  50.1.0   ## Description - i use the selenium-webdriver in nodejs, but it always cannot find the firefox executable file.   i think there are errors in the following file:   file: **node_modules/selenium-webdriver/firefox/binary.js**   line 79 to line 122 ```javascript /**  * Locates the Firefox binary for the current system.  *  * @param {boolean=} opt_dev Whether to find the Developer Edition. This only  *     used on Windows and OSX.  * @return {!Promise} A promise for the located binary. The promise will  *     be rejected if Firefox cannot be located.  */ function findFirefox(opt_dev) {   if (opt_dev && foundDevBinary) {     return foundDevBinary;   }    if (!opt_dev && foundBinary) {     return foundBinary;   }    let found;   if (process.platform === 'darwin') {     let exe = opt_dev         ? '/Applications/FirefoxDeveloperEdition.app/Contents/MacOS/firefox-bin'         : '/Applications/Firefox.app/Contents/MacOS/firefox-bin';     found = io.exists(exe).then(exists => exists ? exe : null);    } else if (process.platform === 'win32') {     found = defaultWindowsLocation(opt_dev);    } else {     found = Promise.resolve(io.findInPath('firefox'));   }    found = found.then(found => {     if (found) {       return found;     }     throw Error('Could not locate Firefox on the current system');   });    if (opt_dev) {     return foundDevBinary = found;   } else {     return foundBinary = found;   } } ```  it would only find the exec file in the default installation directory when `process.platform === 'win32'`.but it is expected to look for the firefox.exe within my windows path.  ```javascript    let found;   if (process.platform === 'darwin') {     let exe = opt_dev         ? '/Applications/FirefoxDeveloperEdition.app/Contents/MacOS/firefox-bin'         : '/Applications/Firefox.app/Contents/MacOS/firefox-bin';     found = io.exists(exe).then(exists => exists ? exe : null);    } else if (process.platform === 'win32') {     found = defaultWindowsLocation(opt_dev);     found = found.then(found => {       if (found) {         return found;       }       return Promise.resolve(io.findInPath('firefox.exe'));     });   } else {     found = Promise.resolve(io.findInPath('firefox'));   } ```

column3: Selenium doesn't open URL
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 10  Selenium Version:  3.0.0  Browser:  Google Chrome  Browser Version:  56.0.2914.3 beta (64-bit)   I'm trying  to open a URL using Selenium and chromedriver with a C# code and instead it opens a new tab in a existing window and the url textbox have only "data;." written in it and the page stays blank. I tried looking for this kind of problem and couldn't find anyone with a fix for it. I want to be able to open a new window with such URL.   This is the error i get on CMD: ``` Starting ChromeDriver 2.25.426923 (0390b88869384d6eb0d5d09729679f934aab9eed) on port 50838 Only local connections are allowed. [14264:2600:1115/190051:ERROR:cache_util_win.cc(20)] Unable to move the cache: 0 [14264:2600:1115/190051:ERROR:cache_util.cc(134)] Unable to move cache folder C:\Users\\AppData\Local\Google\Chrome\User Data\ShaderCache\GPUCache to C:\Users\\AppData\Local\Google\Chrome\User Data\ShaderCache\old_GPUCache_001 [14264:2600:1115/190051:ERROR:cache_creator.cc(134)] Unable to create cache [14264:2600:1115/190051:ERROR:shader_disk_cache.cc(570)] Shader Cache Creation failed: -2 ``` ## Expected Behavior - open a new window with the URL i set it to open with.  ## Actual Behavior - open a tab in a existing window and the page looks blank with "data;." on the url textbox.  ## Steps to reproduce - open any URL with chromedriver and C# selenium code.

column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 10  Selenium Version:  2.9.1  Browser:  Firefox   Browser Version:  50   ## Expected Behavior -  ## Actual Behavior -  ## Steps to reproduce - Since Firefox is working on multi process Firefox, it is deprecating all the existing XUL/XPCOM based addons. They are asking users to migrate to web extensions. They Provided a time line also. By Firefox 57 version they are going to deprecate completely. Can we Expect Selenium IDE with web extensions?? Many addons like Fire Bug, Fire Path says they are going to end the their addon's once multi process Firefox (Firefox 57) makes it's standard release. Is Selenium IDE is going to dead??

column3: JAR files seems to be missing for the java 3.3.1 version
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows 10  Selenium Version:   3.3.1 Browser:    Firefox & General    Browser Version:   General   ## Expected Behavior - The following JAR files should be included in the downloadable package: selenium-java-3.xx.x.jar selenium-java-3.xx.x-srcs.jar  ## Actual Behavior - The above files are not present which makes it unable to import libraries.  ## Steps to reproduce - 1. Download the java 3.3.1 file. 2. Unzip those files 3. These 2 JAR files are not included in the package: selenium-java-3.xx.x.jar selenium-java-3.xx.x-srcs.jar  4. Import all the other JAR files in the Eclipse SDK 5. Run the following code:    package demo;  import org.openqa.selenium.By; import org.openqa.selenium.WebDriver; import org.openqa.selenium.WebElement; import org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver; import org.openqa.selenium.htmlunit.HtmlUnitDriver;  	public class testFaceBookReg   	{ public static void main(String[] args)  	{  		WebDriver driver = new FirefoxDriver();  		driver.get("http://www.google.com/");  		WebElement element = driver.findElement(By.name("q"));  		element.sendKeys("mysql excel 2013");  		element.submit();	   	}  }   6.  I get these errors:  -> "The import org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver cannot be resolved" ->"FirefoxDriver cannot be resolved to a type" "The type java.lang.CharSequence cannot be resolved. It is indirectly referenced from required .class files"

column3: ReadExistingPreferences() exception occured due to duplicate preferences on 'user.js' config
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows (any)  Selenium Version:  3.0.0  Browser:  Firefox   Browser Version:  Any   ## Expected Behavior - Calling FirefoxProfile constructor with profile path, e.g.: var profile = new FirefoxProfile(%PATH_TO_PROFILE%);  We should get FirefoxProfile object instance.  ## Actual Behavior - An exception has been thrown: System.ArgumentException: An item with the same key has already been added.                          at System.ThrowHelper.ThrowArgumentException(ExceptionResource resource)                          at System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary`2.Insert(TKey key, TValue value, Boolean add)                          at OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxProfile.ReadExistingPreferences()                          at OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxProfile..ctor(String profileDirectory, Boolean deleteSourceOnClean)                          at OpenQA.Selenium.Firefox.FirefoxProfileManager.GetProfile(String profileName)  ## Steps to reproduce - Add duplicate strings on 'user.js' file in profile and call constructor with profile path. You use Dictionary to store user preferences but some 3-rd party applications like antiviruses can modify 'user.js' config with duplicate strings. It`s better to check if dictionary already contains key before adding.

column3: IE Driver Beta: Check proxyType case-insensitively
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows Selenium Version:  3.3 Browser:  Internet Explorer Browser Version:  all  IE Driver Beta: 3.3.99.3  ## Expected Behavior - Specifying `"proxyType": "MANUAL"` should be allowed.  The W3C spec actually doesn't say that yet, but it was supposed to say it :) I have sent a PR (https://github.com/w3c/webdriver/pull/870), and I will also patch the Java bindings to send in lowercase. But we should still let this be case-insensitive.  ## Actual Behavior - >D 2017-03-28 15:26:02:911 server.cc(338) Response: {"value":{"data":null,"error":"session not created","message":"Invalid capabilities in alwaysMatch: a proxy type named MANUAL is specified, but proxy type must be 'pac', 'noproxy', 'autodetect', 'system', or 'manual'","stacktrace":""}}

column3: JSON Node Configuration File
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows  Selenium Version:  3.3.1   Browser:  Chrome   Browser Version:  Latest    ## Expected Behavior - Selenium Grid JSON node configuration file should work with  Selenium 3  ## Actual Behavior - Selenium Grid 2 JSON node configuration file doesn't work with  Selenium 3  ## Steps to reproduce -  Hi,  Could someone please tell me what the difference is between version 2 and version 3 of the JSON node configuration profile?  **Version 2:** https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/selenium-2.53.0/java/server/src/org/openqa/grid/common/defaults/DefaultNode.json  **Version 3:** https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/java/server/src/org/openqa/grid/common/defaults/DefaultNodeWebDriver.json  I am trying to upgrade my version 2 profile, but I am not sure what parameters to change / keep. ``` {   "capabilities":   [ <%=   require 'json'   capabilities = []    if @google_chrome     capabilities.push(JSON.generate({       :browserName        => 'chrome',       :version            => 'ga',       :platform           => 'WINDOWS',       :maxInstances       => 5,       :takesScreenshot    => true,       :seleniumProtocol   =>'WebDriver'     }))   end    capabilities.join(',') %>    ],    "nodeTimeout": 120,   "host": "<%=@grid_client_host %>",   "port": <%=@grid_client_port %>,   "hubPort": 4444,   "hubHost": "<%=@grid_host %>",   "nodePolling": 2000,   "registerCycle": 10000,   "register": true,   "cleanUpCycle": 2000,   "throwOnCapabilityNotPresent": true,   "timeout": 30000,   "maxSession": 20  } ```
