column3: 64 bit FirefoxDriver does not launch the browser while running on 32 bit jdk
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows  Selenium Version:  3.0.1  Browser:  Firefox  Browser Version:  51 (and Any)  ## Expected Behavior - Firefox browser should launch. ## Actual Behavior - Firefox browser does not launch and shows the following exception ``` Exception in thread "main" org.openqa.selenium.WebDriverException: Cannot find firefox binary in PATH. Make sure firefox is installed. OS appears to be: VISTA Build info: version: 'unknown', revision: '1969d75', time: '2016-10-18 09:43:45 -0700' System info: host: 'agent100', ip: '101.102.103.104', os.name: 'Windows 7', os.arch: 'x86', os.version: '6.1', java.version: '1.8.0' Driver info: driver.version: FirefoxDriver 	at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.internal.Executable.(Executable.java:75) 	at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxBinary.(FirefoxBinary.java:60) 	at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxBinary.(FirefoxBinary.java:56) 	at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver.(FirefoxDriver.java:127) 	at com.abc.test.TestFF.main(TestFF.java:5) ``` ## Steps to reproduce - Run the following java program using a 32 bit jre on a machine with 64 bit Firefox browser. ``` package com.abc.test; import org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver; public class TestFF { 	public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception { 		FirefoxDriver ff = new FirefoxDriver(); 		ff.close(); 		ff.quit(); 	} } ```

column3: Cannot use firefox to create commands for scripts in Selenium
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Windows  Selenium Version:  2.9.1  Browser:  FireFox 51.0.1   Browser Version:     ## Expected Behavior - I should be able to right click anywhere on a web page on firefox and create commands that can be used in my selenium scripts such as "verify text".   ## Actual Behavior - Now what is happening is I right click and I see now selenium commands when using firefox. ## Steps to reproduce - I'm not sure what is going on so I don't know how to reproduce this issue.

column3: Unable to take screenshot of entire page by selenium 3.0.1
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Window 8 Selenium Version: 3.0.1 Geckodriver:   0.11.1 Browser:  Firefox 49.0.2  ## Expected Behavior - Capture the entire page  ## Actual Behavior - Capture the current window  ## Steps to reproduce - I upgraded my selenium from 2.42.2 to 3.0.1 find out that  `File scrFile = ((TakesScreenshot)driver).getScreenshotAs(OutputType.FILE);` can only capture the current window but before this version, I can capture the entire page.

column3: Unable to Record the enter text in WYSIWYG or TINYMCE editor
column4: ## Meta - OS:  window 7  Selenium Version:  2.9  Browser:  firefox   Browser Version:     ## Expected Behavior - when user enters something in the free text box(Editor box) then selenium ide should record the text, it should be work same as working for textbox  ## Actual Behaviour - Selenium ide does not record anything when user enters any text in editor  ## Steps to reproduce - Open any application which has editor Open Selenium ide Enter text in the editor textbox Check the selenium ide script

column3: error SSL_ERROR_BAD_CERT_DOMAIN when using FF51.x and new geckodriver
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Win8 x64  Selenium Version:  python +Selenium WebDriver + geckodriver 3.0  Browser:  Firefox    Browser Version:  51.1.x   ## Expected Behavior - I get some problem when I used new geckodriver with Python 3.5.2  with old driver I used our test server (with bad sertificate and I added it to the exceptions)  I used FF 47.0.1 with old driver on my job and all work well  `def setUp(self):         self.driver = webdriver.Firefox()         self.driver.implicitly_wait(50)         self.base_url = "https://......."         self.verificationErrors = []         self.accept_next_alert = True          def test_1(self):         driver = self.driver         driver.get(self.base_url + "/.........")`  ## Actual Behavior - I get an error  `File "D:\Python\python3x\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\webdriver.py", line 248, in get self.execute(Command.GET, {'url': url})   File "D:\Python\python3x\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\webdriver.py", line 236, in execute self.error_handler.check_response(response)   File "D:\Python\python3x\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\errorhandler.py", line 192, in check_response raise exception_class(message, screen, stacktrace) selenium.common.exceptions.WebDriverException: Message: Reached error page: about:certerror?e=nssBadCert&u=https%3A// ......... SSL_ERROR_BAD_CERT_DOMAIN%22%3ESSL_ERROR_BAD_CERT_DOMAIN%3C/a%3E%0A`   ## Steps to reproduce -   when I using Chrome with ChromeDriver or old driver (2.3) with FF 47.0.1 all work well

column3: @FindBys not returning elements when using with List
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Win7 x64  Selenium Version:  3.3.1  Browser:  Firefox   Browser Version:  49.0.2 (64)   ## Expected Behavior - Get a list of elements matching search criteria. ``` @FindBys ({     @FindBy (xpath = "father"),     @FindBy (xpath = "child") }) public List elementsList; ``` This should return a list of all "child" elements that are under "father"  ## Actual Behavior - returns null;  ## Steps to reproduce -  ``` @FindBys({ @FindBy(xpath = "//div[@id='some-id']"), @FindBy(xpath = "//div[@class='some class']") }) public List elementsList; ``` should return a list of "some class" elements (located by second xpath) that are under "some id" elements (located by first xpath).  ``` @FindBy(xpath = "//div[@class='some class']") public List elementsList; ``` This is working fine

column3: .send_keys predominately fails with IEDriverServer v3.3.0 (32bit), but ok with v3.3.0 (64bit)
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Win7 Pro SP1 64bit Selenium Version:  3.3.2 Bindings: Python v2.7.12 32bit or v3.5.2 32bit Browser:  IE  Browser Version:  11.0.9600.18617 (KB4012204)  ## Expected Behavior - .send_keys consistently works to populate file path and name into file uplodad dialog box (using latest IEDriverServer) ## Actual Behavior - .send_keys predominately fails to populate file path and name into file upload dialog box using IEDriverServer v3.3.0 (32bit) and v3.3.99.4.  (By predominately fails, I'm saying it fails 19 out of 20 times, maybe 1 in 20 it works ok)   In contrast, .send_keys seems consistently good using IEDriverServer v2.48 and v3.3.0 (64bit).  In a nutshell, the IE file upload dialog box hangs, with no path / file name entry, coincident with the .send_keys call.  ## Steps to reproduce -  `from selenium import webdriver driver = webdriver.Ie() # lets demonstrate this on a FileUpload page driver.get('https://www.websupergoo.com/file-upload-1.htm') # find the 'Browse' button page_upload_button = driver.find_element_by_name("fileField") # define a path and file name to upload local Win7 OS. file_to_upload = "C:\\foo.bar" # try to FileUpload to illustrate the cited problem behavior. FileUpload just hangs here page_upload_button.send_keys(file_to_upload)`

column3: Selenium IEDriverServer can not create driver instance more than 30
column4: ## Meta - OS:  win7 bit, win10 64bit Selenium Version:  latest Browser:   Internet Explorer Browser Version:  11 Python version: 2.7.11 IEDriverServer (x86 edition) protect mode all checked in security zone  ## Expected Behavior - I want to create at least 100 IE driver instances in one machine with follow test code: ``` for i in xrange(100): 	dcap = DesiredCapabilities.INTERNETEXPLORER.copy() 	driver = webdriver.Ie(executable_path=path_to_ie_driver_server,capabilities=dcap) ``` ## Actual Behavior - The code above can create about 29 driver instances in my dev pc, and then throw an exception ``` Traceback (most recent call last):   File "D:\Dev\PyCharm Community Edition\PyCharm Community Edition 2016.3\helpers\pydev\pydevd.py", line 1596, in      globals = debugger.run(setup['file'], None, None, is_module)   File "D:\Dev\PyCharm Community Edition\PyCharm Community Edition 2016.3\helpers\pydev\pydevd.py", line 974, in run     pydev_imports.execfile(file, globals, locals)  # execute the script   File "C:/workspace/tidy/credit.kolibre.creditreference.webcrawler/src/test.py", line 33, in      d = get_a_driver()   File "C:/workspace/tidy/credit.kolibre.creditreference.webcrawler/src/test.py", line 26, in get_a_driver     driver = webdriver.Ie(executable_path=r"D:\Dev\phantomjs-2.1.1-windows\bin\IEDriverServer.exe",capabilities=dcap)   File "D:\Dev\Python27\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\ie\webdriver.py", line 57, in __init__     desired_capabilities=capabilities)   File "D:\Dev\Python27\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\webdriver.py", line 92, in __init__     self.start_session(desired_capabilities, browser_profile)   File "D:\Dev\Python27\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\webdriver.py", line 179, in start_session     response = self.execute(Command.NEW_SESSION, capabilities)   File "D:\Dev\Python27\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\webdriver.py", line 236, in execute     self.error_handler.check_response(response)   File "D:\Dev\Python27\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\errorhandler.py", line 192, in check_response     raise exception_class(message, screen, stacktrace) selenium.common.exceptions.WebDriverException: Message: Unexpected error launching Internet Explorer. IELaunchURL() returned HRESULT 80070012 ('There are no more files.') for URL 'http://localhost:51782/' ``` ## Personal guess As I know, when selenium create driver instance, it will pass a `NEW_SESSION` command parameter It maybe not a selenium bug, cause I can reproduce it by manually create new session in IE(File-New session), and can only create 29 IE session too. And I found this problem was mentioned [here](http://superuser.com/questions/249733/running-more-than-30-ie8-sessions-with-nomerge) but not solved.  Thanks for any idea about this problem.

column3: Exception when starting standalone server for Edge with webdriver.edge.driver option
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Win 10  Selenium Version:  3.1.0  Browser:  Edge   Browser Version:  38.14393.0.0   ## Expected Behavior - Like selenium version 2.53.1, be able to start the server standalone jar with the edge driver location included as a system property. ## Actual Behavior - Exception is thrown when the -Dwebdriver.edge.driver= is included ## Steps to reproduce -  Start selenium-standalone-3.1.0.jar with the following command: `java -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.1.0.jar -role node -hub  -browser "browserName=MicrosoftEdge,platform=Win10,maxInstances=1" -Dwebdriver.edge.driver=C:\Jenkins\MicrosoftWebDriver.exe`  See screenshot for crash output. I had to redact the hub URL for company security. This same command worked pefectly fine in selenium 2.53.1.  ![selenium-crash](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8092276/23372208/4c95b642-fce0-11e6-8bd6-a67782578574.jpg)

column3: Edge not able to find element by XPath with embedded single-quote
column4: ## Meta - OS:  WIn 10  Selenium Version:  3.1  Browser:  Edge   Browser Version:  Latest   ## Expected Behavior - Like Chrome and IE 10+11, Edge should be able to find an element by XPath that contains an embedded single quote (see example). ## Actual Behavior - Not able to find element. ## Steps to reproduce -  If I try to find an element by this XPath (this is an example that illustrates what the real code is trying to do):  `By.xpath("//a[@href=\"javascript:rs('Hello W\'orld');\"]")`  Edge is not able to find this element as the XPath that gets sent to the driver is looking for the actual text "Hello W\\'orld" instead of "Hello W'orld". This exact setup works in Chrome and IE 10+11. The way that we build an XPath like this in the code is like this:  `By.xpath("//a[@href=\"javascript:rs('Hello W\\'orld');\"]")` (since we have to escape the \ in Java strings) -> `By.xpath("//a[@href=\"javascript:rs('Hello W\'orld');\"]")`

column3: Calling window.stop throws permission denied exception
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Ubuntu 16.04 Selenium Version: 3.3.2  Browser:  Firefox 45.0.2 with Geckodriver 0.15.0  ## Steps to reproduce - 1. Try to execute `browser.execute_script('window.stop();')` 2. Receive error `WebDriverException: Message: Error: Permission denied to access property "stop"`  I was calling this just before a call to `browser.get(url)` to ensure the browser wasn't still loading, and after a recent Firefox/Selenium update (I'm not sure which), this now throws an exception.

column3: Test times out on finding element but the screenshot shows the test in a completed state
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Ubuntu 16.04  Selenium Version:  3.0.0   Browser:  Chrome   Browser Version:  Chrome v 54.0.2840.100 (64 bit)  Chromedriver Version: 2.25  ## Expected Behavior -  When running tests I have a scenario which ends in   And I press "Submit" Then I should see "blah"  I expect that it submits the form via the submit button and the next page to be loaded is the show page of the item and that it contains the text "blah".  Any failures create a screenshot of the browser at the time of failure.  ## Actual Behavior - An exception is thrown at the stage " And I press "Submit" " stating that the element Submit could not be found.  The screenshot displays the show page for the item and that it contains the text "blah".   The only way this page can be rendered is if the submit button was pressed.  In summary, the test is failing because it says it cannot find the button to click but it is also clicking the button and completing the test scenario.   ## Steps to reproduce -

column3: Selenium does not execute in Java ExecutorService
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Ubuntu 16.04  Selenium Version:   3.0.1  Browser:  Chrome  Browser Version:  55.0.2883.75 (64-bit)  ## Expected Behavior -  Multiple Chrome windows should open.  ## Actual Behavior -  No Chrome windows open.   ## Steps to reproduce -  I'm unable to get Selenium+ChromeDriver working inside an ExecutorService. This is so I can run multiple processes. It works just fine if I run it as a JUnit test inside a single thread.  There are no errors -- it runs fine until the WebDriver driver = new ChromeDriver(), and then just quits. No exceptions thrown.  To reproduce, just execute doPool().   ```      @Test     public void doPool(){          ExecutorService executor = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(10);              executor.submit(() -> {                  testGoogleSearch();             });      }      @Test     public void testGoogleSearch() {         //System.setProperty("webdriver.chrome.driver", "/path/to/chromedriver");          String threadName = Thread.currentThread().getName();         System.out.println("Hello " + threadName);          WebDriver driver = new ChromeDriver();         driver.get("http://www.google.com/xhtml");         try {             Thread.sleep(5000);  // Let the user actually see something!              WebElement searchBox = driver.findElement(By.name("q"));             searchBox.sendKeys("ChromeDriver");             searchBox.submit();             Thread.sleep(5000);  // Let the user actually see something!              screenshot(driver);         }         catch (InterruptedException e) {             e.printStackTrace();         }      }     ```

column3: selenium.common.exceptions.WebDriverException: Message: Can't load the profile.
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Ubuntu 14.01 (64-bit)  Selenium Version: 2.53.6    Browser:  Firefox    Browser Version:  47.0.1 (64-bit)  Python Version: 2.7.6 ## Expected Behavior - 1. Open website  2. Print url  ## Actual Behavior - Getting the error:  >  > Traceback (most recent call last): >   File "test.py", line 8, in  >     driver = webdriver.Firefox(firefox_profile=profile) >   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/selenium/webdriver/firefox/webdriver.py", line 80, in __init__ >     self.binary, timeout) >   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/selenium/webdriver/firefox/extension_connection.py", line 52, in __init__ >     self.binary.launch_browser(self.profile, timeout=timeout) >   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/selenium/webdriver/firefox/firefox_binary.py", line 68, in launch_browser >     self._wait_until_connectable(timeout=timeout) >   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/selenium/webdriver/firefox/firefox_binary.py", line 108, in _wait_until_connectable >     % (self.profile.path)) > selenium.common.exceptions.WebDriverException: Message: Can't load the profile. Profile Dir: /tmp/tmp55V_vA/webdriver-py-profilecopy If you specified a log_file in the FirefoxBinary constructor, check it for details. >   ## Steps to reproduce -   ``` from selenium import webdriver from xvfbwrapper import Xvfb  vdisplay = Xvfb() vdisplay.start()  profile = webdriver.FirefoxProfile('/users/username/.mozilla/firefox/vhrv3vfz.Test') driver = webdriver.Firefox(firefox_profile=profile)  driver.get('http://www.sohu.com') print driver.current_url  vdisplay.stop() driver.quit() ``` In addition to this I've `geckodriver 14` installed and saved in `/usr/local/bin`. Also, I am running this on a remote server, so need to run firefox headlessly. Note that the combination of `selenium 2.53.6` and `firefox 47.0.1` was running fine before, and just suddenly began giving this error. Its also extremely unpredictable, sometimes the error is given for all the websites that I am checking, and sometimes only a few. Would be great if anyone can help me with this, thanks!

column3: No implicit wait of loaded page in firefox
column4: ## Meta - OS:  ubuntu 14  Selenium Version:   3.3.1  Browser:  Firefox/Chrome   Browser Version:  chrome 57.0.2987.98 , firefox 52   ## Expected Behavior - Selenium with chrome and firefox should have the same behavior ## Actual Behavior - when doing an action  on a webelement with firefox, it does not implicitly wait for the page to be fully loaded But when doing it on Chrome it wait for the page to be fully loaded before processing to the next command  ## Steps to reproduce - run this script on chrome and on firefox  from time import sleep  driver = webdriver.Firefox()  driver.get("https://www.youtube.com")  search_field = driver.find_element_by_xpath("//*[@id='masthead-search-term']") search_field.send_keys("meaning of life") search_field.submit()   for i in range(10):     print(str(driver.execute_script("return document.readyState")))     sleep(0.1)  driver.quit()

column3: Ubuntu/Linux sendKeys() sends incomplete keys to element
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Ubuntu Selenium Version:  3.0.1 Browser: Chrome Browser Version:   56.0.2924.87 (64-bit)  ## Expected Behavior -  Every key for a String used in the sendKeys method is sent to the element which is calling sendKeys()  ## Actual Behavior -  Some keys are not sent or sent to the wrong element.  **1.** In the case of one input element not all keys are sent to that element. The first keys usually make it, but after the 4th-7th key no keys are sent.  - Example: elem.sendKeys("1234567890") may result in the element only receiving 12345 or 1234590.   In this case the ChromeDriver logs show the expected keys are being logged. In this case I was sending 7185458. The element however only got 718. This is known by logging and watching the test.  *ChromeDriver logs* ` 05:19:46.410 INFO - Executing: [send keys: 11 [[ChromeDriver: chrome on LINUX (bc3b7e79d7b29c02d3b38ab834041a9f)] -> css selector: [data-test='input-main title (required)']], [7185458]]) ` ` 05:19:46.498 INFO - Done: [send keys: 11 [[ChromeDriver: chrome on LINUX (bc3b7e79d7b29c02d3b38ab834041a9f)] -> css selector: [data-test='input-main title (required)']], [7185458]] `  *My logs* ` [INFO ] - Entering mail title "7185458" on page. ` ` [INFO ] - Driver failed to enter text correctly. ActualText: 718. Expected text: 7185458 `  **2.** In the case of multiple  elements next to each other and sending a long character array, character by character, with a sleep of more than 100ms in between each call to .sendKeys() the WebElement for the first input may receive 12345 and the element immediately next to it will receive 678 then the first input will receive 90 resulting in 1234590 sent to the first element.    ## Steps to reproduce - For case 1: ```java  public static void test(){         try {             URL url = new URL("http://selenium.yourcompany.qa:4444/wd/hub");             WebDriver d = new RemoteWebDriver(url, DesiredCapabilities.chrome());             d.get("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page");             WebElement elem = d.findElement(By.cssSelector("input[type=\"search\"]"));             String input = "1230934265723403945";             elem.sendKeys(input);             sleep(10000);             d.quit();         } catch (MalformedURLException ignored){}     } ```

column3: JSON config default values is handled differently in Grid node compared to hub
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Tested on Windows 10 and Linux  Selenium Version:  3.0.1  Browser:  Irrelevant  Browser Version:  -   Starting nodes with JSON config requires all configuration parameters to be present in the JSON file.  If a parameter is missing the default value will not be used, instead it will be set to null.  This is not the case when running as hub. Then the default value will be used when a configuration parameter is missing from the JSON file.  ## Expected Behavior - Default configuration is used for grid nodes when using JSON config when a configuration parameter is not specified in the JSON file.  ## Actual Behavior - If a configuration parameter is missing from the node JSON config file the configuration parameter will be null.  ## Steps to reproduce - 1. Download selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1.jar  2. Download [DefaultNodeWebDriver.json](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/java/server/src/org/openqa/grid/common/defaults/DefaultNodeWebDriver.json)  3. Remove the line '"hub": "http://localhost:4444",' from the json file 4. Start node: "java -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1.jar -role node -nodeConfig DefaultNodeWebDriver.json" 5. The following exception can be seen:      org.openqa.grid.common.exception.GridConfigurationException: You must specify either a hubHost or hub parameter  ### Example of expected behavior If something similar is done to the hub it still starts with default values: 1. Download [DefaultHub.json](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/java/server/src/org/openqa/grid/common/defaults/DefaultHub.json) 2. Remove the line "port": "4444" from the json file. 3. Start hub: "java -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1.jar -role hub -hubConfig DefaultHub.json" 4. The hub starts on the default port 4444.

column3: Standalone server requires geckodriver even with "marionette: false"
column4: ## Meta - OS:  server: Debian 8 (jessie), client: openSUSE Leap 42.1 Selenium Version:  3.3.1 Browser:  Mozilla Firefox Browser Version:  45.8.0  ## Expected Behavior - A `WebDriver` instance to be initialized.  ## Actual Behavior - ``` Traceback (most recent call last):   File "", line 1, in    File "/srv/tests/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 92, in __init__     self.start_session(desired_capabilities, browser_profile)   File "/srv/tests/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 179, in start_session     response = self.execute(Command.NEW_SESSION, capabilities)   File "/srv/tests/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 238, in execute     self.error_handler.check_response(response)   File "/srv/tests/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/errorhandler.py", line 193, in check_response     raise exception_class(message, screen, stacktrace) selenium.common.exceptions.WebDriverException: Message: The path to the driver executable must be set by the webdriver.gecko.driver system property; for more information, see https://github.com/mozilla/geckodriver. The latest version can be downloaded from https://github.com/mozilla/geckodriver/releases Stacktrace:     at com.google.common.base.Preconditions.checkState (Preconditions.java:738)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.service.DriverService.findExecutable (DriverService.java:111)     at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.GeckoDriverService.access$100 (GeckoDriverService.java:38)     at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.GeckoDriverService$Builder.findDefaultExecutable (GeckoDriverService.java:112)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.service.DriverService$Builder.build (DriverService.java:302)     at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver.toExecutor (FirefoxDriver.java:233)     at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver. (FirefoxDriver.java:125)     at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver. (FirefoxDriver.java:150)     at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0 (NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:-2)     at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance (NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:62)     at sun.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance (DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45)     at java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance (Constructor.java:423)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.server.FirefoxDriverProvider.callConstructor (FirefoxDriverProvider.java:81)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.server.FirefoxDriverProvider.newInstance (FirefoxDriverProvider.java:63)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.server.DefaultDriverFactory.newInstance (DefaultDriverFactory.java:60)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.server.DefaultSession$BrowserCreator.call (DefaultSession.java:222)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.server.DefaultSession$BrowserCreator.call (DefaultSession.java:209)     at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run (FutureTask.java:266)     at org.openqa.selenium.remote.server.DefaultSession$1.run (DefaultSession.java:176)     at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker (ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1142)     at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run (ThreadPoolExecutor.java:617)     at java.lang.Thread.run (Thread.java:745) ```  ## Steps to reproduce -  ```python from selenium import webdriver  caps = webdriver.DesiredCapabilities.FIREFOX.copy() caps["marionette"] = False webdriver.Remote("http://turris-qa-lan-tester:4444/wd/hub", caps) ```  ## Additional info -  It seems that this bug was introduced in Selenium 3.3.0 because Selenium 3.3.0 fails as well while Selenium 3.2.0 works just fine. I guess that the root cause is that the server does not set the "legacy" flag if it gets `marionette: false` because I did not find a code (in 3.3.1) that calls `setLegacy` in this case and because setting the `webdriver.firefox.marionette` system property to `false` works as a workaround.

column3: Selenium-html-runner 3.0.1 : Address already in use (Bind failed)
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Red Hat Selenium Version:   selenium-html-runner-3.0.1.jar Browser:   Geckodriver  Hello,  I try to launch a simple test of selenium IDE with selenium-html-runner-3.0.1.jar in command line :  java -jar selenium-html-runner-3.0.1.jar -port 4445 -timeout 600 -userExtensions user-extensions.js -htmlSuite *firefox http://google.com searchtest.html firefox-results.html  I have download geckodriver and he is available. But every time I try to run this, I have this following error :   java.io.IOException: java.lang.RuntimeException: java.net.BindException: Address already in use (Bind failed)  It's look like he try to use 2 times the same port.  Can you help me?  This guy has the same issue as me but he haven't any response :  https://gist.github.com/bruceburge/b4b500d9672f88723f79ad2eb01ab350

column3: Selenium Server Standalone ignore timeout setting

Here is my different try :  java -Dwebdriver.server.session.timeout=3600 -Dwebdriver.server.browser.timeout=600 -jar /home/jenkins/selenium/selenium-server-standalone-2.53.1.jar -userExtensions user-extensions.js -htmlSuite *firefox http://xxx..com "Testcmd/TS.html" "firefox-results.html"  java  -jar /home/jenkins/selenium/selenium-server-standalone-2.53.1.jar timeout 600 -browserTimeout 600 -userExtensions user-extensions.js -htmlSuite *firefox http://xxx..com "Testcmd/TS.html" "firefox-results.html"  If we haven't this problem, our test will work perfectly, it's a great tool but I begin to despair. So please, if you can help me ?

column3: SAFARI: NoSuchWindowError: A request to use a window could not be satisfied because the window could not be found.
column4: ## Meta - OS:  OSX 10.11.6 Selenium Version:  3.3.0, VSCode, npm/javascript Browser:  Safari   Browser Version:  10.1 (11603.1.30.0.34)  ## Expected Behavior -  Should be able to manipulate the window via `driver.manage().window().setSize(1024,768)`  ## Actual Behavior -  **NoSuchWindowError: A request to use a window could not be satisfied because the window could not be found.**  ## Steps to reproduce - `$ mocha --require bootstrap`  bootstrap.js: ````javascript global.startWebdriver = function(browser) {   return new Builder().forBrowser(browser).build()     .then(function(driver) {       global.driver = driver;     }) } ````  test.js: ````javascript describe('suite', () => {   it('test', async ()=> {     await startWebdriver('chrome');     await driver.get('http://google.com');     await driver.manage().window().setSize(1024,768)     ...   }); }); ````  I am using babel & es7, and this works just fine for chromedriver, so if you think I am missing something regarding that configuration, it's probably just been omitted for brevity in my example

column3: Unable to press Right/Left/Up/Down key more than once using send_keys(Keys.Right)
column4: ## Meta - OS:  OSX 10.11.16(El Capitan) Selenium Version:  3.0.2 Browser:  safari 10 Browser Version:  11602.1.50.0.10   Unable to perform same key press event in safari (i.e no repetitive action can be performed using key press ).  Example: Unable to enter right key three times using code bellow.  driver.find_element_by_xpath("//body").send_keys(Keys.RIGHT) driver.find_element_by_xpath("//body").send_keys(Keys.RIGHT) driver.find_element_by_xpath("//body").send_keys(Keys.RIGHT)        There is no error present, just that the second key press event is not actioned. However if another direction key is sent in the sequence then that works, but once a key direction is used then the same direction key doesn't work in the same safari driver session.   Example, if the following is executed in a sequence in a single safari driver session, then:  driver.find_element_by_xpath("//body").send_keys(Keys.RIGHT) #Works driver.find_element_by_xpath("//body").send_keys(Keys.RIGHT) #Doesn't Work driver.find_element_by_xpath("//body").send_keys(Keys.LEFT) #Works driver.find_element_by_xpath("//body").send_keys(Keys.LEFT) #Doesn't Work  Example 2: driver.find_element_by_xpath("//body").send_keys(Keys.RIGHT) #Works driver.find_element_by_xpath("//body").send_keys(Keys.LEFT) #Works driver.find_element_by_xpath("//body").send_keys(Keys.RIGHT) #Doesn't Work driver.find_element_by_xpath("//body").send_keys(Keys.UP) #Works driver.find_element_by_xpath("//body").send_keys(Keys.LEFT) #Doesn't Works  ## Expected Behavior - Bellow code should move focus to 2nd postion driver.find_element_by_xpath("//body").send_keys(Keys.RIGHT) driver.find_element_by_xpath("//body").send_keys(Keys.RIGHT)   ## Actual Behavior - focus is moved once.  Note: The above example and steps works fine with the Firefox.

column3: avoid using `element.innerText`?
column4: ## Meta - OS:  OSX Selenium Version: 2.53.0 Browser:  chrome Browser Version:  53.0  ## Code  ``` // text = "Welcome!" var headerText = $("h1").text(); ``` ## Expected Behavior - `expect(headerText).toContain("Welcome!");`  ## Actual Behavior - `expect(headerText).toContain("WELCOME!");`  according to the docs, it seems like [WebElement#getText](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/ceaf3da79542024becdda5953059dfbb96fb3a90/java/client/src/org/openqa/selenium/WebElement.java#L143) uses [innerText] (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Node/innerText) which is not a standard feature. I wonder if there's any reason for choosing `innerText` over [textContent](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Node/textContent)?

column3: Chromedriver creation throwing http.client.BadStatusLine: ''
column4: ## Meta - OS:  OSX Selenium Version:  3.0.1 Browser:  chromedriver (2.24.1) using Google Chrome  Browser Version:  54.0.2840.71 (64-bit I think)  ## Steps to reproduce -  Code: Bash: ``` source venv/bin/activate python ``` python ``` from selenium import webdriver driver = pythonscripts.md() ``` python pythonscripts.py file ``` def md():     return webdriver.Chrome("./venv/selenium/webdriver/chromedriver") ```  ## Expected Behavior -  Creates a new chromedriver instance, and stores it to variable `driver`. This was what it was doing last time I used it on October 24, 2016. ## Actual Behavior - Creates new chromedriver instance, and throws `http.client.BadStatusLine: ''` error. `driver` is not defined.  I also tried changing pythonscripts.py's md() method to: ``` def md():     try:          return webdriver.Chrome("./venv/selenium/webdriver/chromedriver")      except Exception:          return webdriver.Chrome("./venv/selenium/webdriver/chromedriver") ```  This creates two new chromedriver windows, throws two `http.client.BadStatusLine: ''` errors, and `driver` is still not defined.  ### Traceback: ``` Traceback (most recent call last):   File "", line 1, in    File "/Users/brydenr/server_scripts/cad_tests/pythonscripts.py", line 68, in md     return webdriver.Chrome("./venv/selenium/webdriver/chromedriver")   File "/Users/brydenr/server_scripts/venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/chrome/webdriver.py", line 69, in __init__     desired_capabilities=desired_capabilities)   File "/Users/brydenr/server_scripts/venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 92, in __init__     self.start_session(desired_capabilities, browser_profile)   File "/Users/brydenr/server_scripts/venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 179, in start_session     response = self.execute(Command.NEW_SESSION, capabilities)   File "/Users/brydenr/server_scripts/venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 234, in execute     response = self.command_executor.execute(driver_command, params)   File "/Users/brydenr/server_scripts/venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/remote_connection.py", line 407, in execute     return self._request(command_info[0], url, body=data)   File "/Users/brydenr/server_scripts/venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/remote_connection.py", line 439, in _request     resp = self._conn.getresponse()   File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.4/lib/python3.4/http/client.py", line 1171, in getresponse     response.begin()   File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.4/lib/python3.4/http/client.py", line 351, in begin     version, status, reason = self._read_status()   File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.4/lib/python3.4/http/client.py", line 321, in _read_status     raise BadStatusLine(line) http.client.BadStatusLine: '' ```

column3: PageFactory setup fails when running tests in multiple classes
column4: ## Meta - OS:  OSX Selenium Version:  3.0.1 Browser:  Chrome Browser Version:  55.0.2883.95 (64-bit)  ## Expected Behavior -   ## Actual Behavior - I have a PageFactory setup and multiple test classes, i.e. HomePageTests.class SearchResultsTests.class ProductDetailsTests.class etc.  If I'm running tests in a single class everything is working as expected. However if I include both classes in the same suite in testng.xml file, then first class runs as expected, but when tests switch to second class it fails with NullPointerException. I've tried initializing page factory elements in various ways and places and still can not find a solution to using page factory with multiple test classes.   ## Steps to reproduce - a sample of the code can be found here: [pf_example.zip](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/files/676685/pf_example.zip)

column3: Chrome window is closed if test suite is failed
column4: ## Meta - OS:  OSX  Selenium Version: 3.0.0 ruby bindings    Browser:  Chrome  Browser Version:  53.0.2785.143 (64-bit)   Browser window is closing if test was failed. it causing problems with debugging failed tests.   ## Expected Behavior - Browser window remains open until `driver.close` is called.  ## Actual Behavior - Browser closed once test is failed.  ## Steps to reproduce - execute this test: ``` require 'selenium-webdriver' require 'minitest/autorun'  describe 'Selenium' do   it 'should not close browser window' do     driver = Selenium::WebDriver.for :chrome     driver.navigate.to "http://google.com"     element = driver.find_element(:name, 'q')     element.send_keys "Hello WebDriver!"     element.submit      puts driver.title     driver.title.must_equal "OHAI!"   end end ```

column3: Inconsistent StaleElementException after Redirect
column4: ## Meta - OS:  OSX  Selenium Version:  3.0+  Browser:  Firefox  Browser Version:  47+  Python Version: 3.3, 3.4  ## Expected Behavior - Selenium should be able to follow a redirect and verify html on each page once the redirect is completed.   ex -  ```     beerdb_link = self.browser.find_element_by_id('beerdb')     beerdb_link.click()     self.browser.implicitly_wait(5)     page_heading = self.browser.find_element_by_tag_name('h1')     self.assertIn("Homebrew Materials Database", page_heading.text)  ```  ## Actual Behavior - I'm seeing some failures throughout my tests on different lines throwing `selenium.common.exceptions.StaleElementReferenceException` when checking for text after a redirect even after an implicitly_wait call. Each test failure is on one of 2 lines and does not fail consistently--  ``` /Users//workspace/Envs/hashtagbrews/bin/python "/Applications/PyCharm 2.app/Contents/helpers/pycharm/django_test_manage.py" test functional_tests.test_simple_model_search.SimpleHopSearchTest.test_user_can_search_hops_page /Users//workspace/PycharmProjects/hashtagbrews Testing started at 7:34 AM ... Creating test database for alias 'default'...  Error Traceback (most recent call last):   File "/Users//workspace/PycharmProjects/hashtagbrews/functional_tests/test_simple_model_search.py", line 40, in test_user_can_search_hops_page     self.assertIn("Homebrew Materials Database", page_heading.text)   File "/Users//workspace/Envs/hashtagbrews/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webelement.py", line 73, in text     return self._execute(Command.GET_ELEMENT_TEXT)['value']   File "/Users//workspace/Envs/hashtagbrews/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webelement.py", line 494, in _execute     return self._parent.execute(command, params)   File "/Users//workspace/Envs/hashtagbrews/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 236, in execute     self.error_handler.check_response(response)   File "/Users//workspace/Envs/hashtagbrews/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/errorhandler.py", line 192, in check_response     raise exception_class(message, screen, stacktrace) selenium.common.exceptions.StaleElementReferenceException: Message: The element reference is stale. Either the element is no longer attached to the DOM or the page has been refreshed.  Destroying test database for alias 'default'...  Process finished with exit code 1 ```  ``` /Users//workspace/Envs/hashtagbrews/bin/python "/Applications/PyCharm 2.app/Contents/helpers/pycharm/django_test_manage.py" test functional_tests.test_simple_model_search.SimpleHopSearchTest.test_user_can_search_hops_page /Users//workspace/PycharmProjects/hashtagbrews Testing started at 7:37 AM ... Creating test database for alias 'default'...  Error Traceback (most recent call last):   File "/Users//workspace/PycharmProjects/hashtagbrews/functional_tests/test_simple_model_search.py", line 49, in test_user_can_search_hops_page     page_heading = self.browser.find_element_by_tag_name('h1').text   File "/Users//workspace/Envs/hashtagbrews/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webelement.py", line 73, in text     return self._execute(Command.GET_ELEMENT_TEXT)['value']   File "/Users//workspace/Envs/hashtagbrews/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webelement.py", line 494, in _execute     return self._parent.execute(command, params)   File "/Users//workspace/Envs/hashtagbrews/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 236, in execute     self.error_handler.check_response(response)   File "/Users//workspace/Envs/hashtagbrews/lib/python3.4/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/errorhandler.py", line 192, in check_response     raise exception_class(message, screen, stacktrace) selenium.common.exceptions.StaleElementReferenceException: Message: The element reference is stale. Either the element is no longer attached to the DOM or the page has been refreshed.  Destroying test database for alias 'default'...  Process finished with exit code 1 ```  I was able to verify that this is working as expected on selenium 2.53 with Firefox 46.   ## Steps to reproduce - Run the following test (with or without implicitly_waits):  ``` import unittest from selenium import webdriver  class TestSelenium(unittest.TestCase):      def setUp(self):         self.browser = webdriver.Firefox()      def tearDown(self):         self.webdriver.quit()      def test_selenium_redirects(self):         self.browser.get('http://www.w3schools.com')         self.browser.find_element_by_link_text('LEARN HTML').click()          h1_text = self.browser.find_element_by_tag_name('h1').text         self.assertIn('HTML', h1_text)  if __name__ == "__main__":     unittest.main() ```  Result: ``` selenium.common.exceptions.StaleElementReferenceException: Message: The element reference is stale... ```

column3: Selenium Actions drag and drop not working on chrome browser

column3: I can't get selenium-webdriver (Javascript) with chromedriver working on Mac OSX
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Mac OSX  Selenium Version:  3.0.1 (Javascript API)  Browser:  Google Chrome   Browser Version:  54.0.2840   ## Expected Behavior -  Open Google's web page and write something in the input field.  ## Actual Behavior -  Google's web page opens, but nothing is written (the get call doesn't finish).  ## Steps to reproduce -  Copy & paste from my stackoverflow question: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/40664398  I'm trying to do some functional testing using selenium-webdriver in Google Chrome navigator on Mac OSX, but I have problems while trying to interact with the navigator.  I've simplified the problem into a similar one: I need to open the Google main page and write something in its input, so I execute this node script:  ``` require('chromedriver');  var webdriver = require('selenium-webdriver'),     By = webdriver.By,     until = webdriver.until;  var driver = new webdriver.Builder()     .forBrowser('chrome')     .build();  driver.get('http://www.google.com/ncr'); driver.findElement(By.name('q')).sendKeys('webdriver'); ```  The npm dependencies are:  ``` npm install selenium-webdriver chromedriver ```  The results of the execution are: the Google Chrome browser opens (so the chromedriver seems to work), but the input field isn't written, because the get call never finishes executing. So the browser can load a given web page but after that I can't interact with it.  Of course, I've also tried to download and install manually the chromedriver, locating the binary file in `/usr/local/bin` and `chmod +x` it, but the result is the same.  However, if I try the same in Safari (removing the first require line and using `'safari'` for browser instead of `'chrome'`) it works! But I need to test it in Google Chrome!  Also, I have tryied the same example using Java and Google Chrome, and it works! It's a problem related with the selenium webdriver Javascript implementation? Or its integration with chromedriver...?

column3: Selenium doesn't display the stacktrace from geckodriver exceptions, because the key is cased differently
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Linux (Ubuntu 14.04) Selenium Version:   3.3.1 Browser:   Firefox / geckodriver 0.15.0  ## Expected Behavior - If geckodriver throws an exception with a stacktrace, selenium should display that stacktrace in the message for the WebDriverException it generates.  ## Actual Behavior - The message is empty, even if a stacktrace is present.  It seems the selenium code looks for the key 'stackTrace' in an exception JSON passed from a webdriver. See https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/py/selenium/webdriver/remote/errorhandler.py#L173 However geckodriver uses 'stacktrace', all lower case, as per the W3 spec: https://www.w3.org/TR/webdriver/  I haven't checked every single one, but other languages appear to do the same thing. Would a PR checking for both keys be accepted? If so, is it legit to just patch one language's code, or does this cause more problems than it solves? Thanks.

column3: [Suggestion]: Better support for containers
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Linux (coreos)  Selenium Version:  2.53.1, 3.0.1  Browser:  Chrome  Browser Version:  53+ (64-bit)  ## Problem -  I am trying to run Jenkins and Selenium in a kubernetes cluster. It's fairly easy to get them to talk to one another... But my tests make use of downloads and uploads. This leads to problems, because a test container will try to upload a file which the browser container doesn't have access to and vise versa. And thus, my tests fail.  My assumption was that I could create a single hub, and scale up or down the number of selenium nodes I needed... But, if there's no easy way to share files with selenium drivers, like watir, and the browsers, it seems like I would need to resume using selenium standalone.    ## Solution? -  In my ideal world, I think selenium should better support the distributed paradigm, by providing interfaces for file transmission. If I use watir to upload a file, it would be great if selenium could transmit the file to the browser container, and then allow the browser to perform the action. Similarly, it would be nice if, after downloading a file, selenium transmitted the file, from the browser container, to the watir driver.  I suppose other people work around this problem by using docker options like `volumes-from` (which kubernetes doesn't support), managing network file systems between containers, or colocating all processes in a single container, removing the need for network file systems. I think it would be nice if this were supported out of the box instead.  On the other hand, I might have missed something the community has already figured out?

column3: Selenium Node doesnt parse hub configurations properly when you have custom capability matcher
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Linux  Selenium Version:   3.0.1 Browser:   Chrome  Browser Version:   55.0.2883.87  ## Expected Behavior - Selenium Node Should be able to parse the hub config irrespective of capabilities ## Actual Behavior - Timeout from hub not honored as parsing the hub config emits below warning  00:03:36.450 WARN - error getting the parameters from the hub. The node may end up with wrong timeouts.Error with the JSON of the config : String io .sterodium.extensions.capability.CustomCapabilityMatcher could not be coerced to class: java.lang.Class   ## Steps to reproduce - hub json ``` { 	"success": true, 	"capabilityMatcher": "io.sterodium.extensions.capability.CustomCapabilityMatcher", 	"newSessionWaitTimeout": -1, 	"throwOnCapabilityNotPresent": true, 	"cleanUpCycle": 5000, 	"custom": {}, 	"host": "10.0.9.2", 	"maxSession": 50, 	"servlets": ["io.sterodium.extensions.hub.proxy.HubRequestsProxyingServlet", "com.ariba.es.ai.hub.proxy.servlets.SeleniumApiProxyServlet"], 	"browserTimeout": 0, 	"debug": false, 	"jettyMaxThreads": -1, 	"log": "log/hub_7777.log", 	"port": 7777, 	"role": "hub", 	"timeout": 300000, 	"newSessionRequestCount": 0, 	"slotCounts": { 		"free": 1, 		"total": 1 	} }  ```  Node JSON ``` {   "capabilities": [     {       "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver",       "extension.sikuliCapability": true,       "browserName": "firefox",       "maxInstances": 1,       "version": "50.0",       "platform": "MAC"     },     {       "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver",       "extension.sikuliCapability": true,       "browserName": "chrome",       "maxInstances": 1,       "version": "55.0.2883.87",       "platform": "MAC"     }   ],   "loadedFromFile": "node_5555.json",   "proxy": "com.groupon.seleniumgridextras.grid.proxies.SetupTeardownProxy",   "maxSession": 1,   "port": 5555,   "register": true,   "unregisterIfStillDownAfter": 10000,   "hubPort": 7777,   "hubHost": "MyHubIPHere",   "host": "MyNodeIPHere",   "nodeStatusCheckTimeout": 10000,   "downPollingLimit": 0 } ``` When i debugged the code I found that it fails in this method ```  public static GridHubConfiguration loadFromJSON(JsonObject json) {      try {       GsonBuilder builder = new GsonBuilder();       GridHubConfiguration.staticAddJsonTypeAdapter(builder);       return builder.excludeFieldsWithoutExposeAnnotation().create()         .fromJson(json, GridHubConfiguration.class);     } catch (Throwable e) {       throw new GridConfigurationException("Error with the JSON of the config : " + e.getMessage(),                                            e);     }   } ``` Its because I have used a custom capability matcher class that helps us to execute SIKULI UI tests in grid. Workaround for me was to copy the jar containing " io .sterodium.extensions.capability.CustomCapabilityMatcher" and add it to class path of node. Why selenium grid imposes us to copy a jar file to node where its not at all used. Just to parse the json we need to copy the jar file and add it to class path. Please fix it

column3: NetExport+FireBug+Firefox Har file Generation Issue In Selenium GRID
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Hub(Linux), Node (Windows)  Selenium Version:  2.53  Browser:  Firefox  Browser Version:    To generate Har file in Selenium i'm using  Firefox+Firebug+NetExport_Extension. Following the code which is setting profiles for firefox to generate har file.  profile.setPreference("extensions.firebug.netexport.alwaysEnableAutoExport", true); profile.setPreference("extensions.firebug.netexport.autoExportToFile",	true); profile.setPreference("extensions.firebug.netexport.autoExportToServer", false); profile.setPreference("extensions.firebug.netexport.defaultLogDir",dirPath.toString());  dirPath= Pointing to Workspace in HUB machine, like -/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/Omniture-GRID/FileUpload/NetExport  So whenever tests are executing without Grid  i'm able to get HAR file generated in above mentioned dirPath. But issue is coming when I'm running this code in Grid Environment. In Grid execution workspace is created in HUB machine and on the other hand browser is opened in Node machine thats why HAR file is not getting generated in Hub machine. But as per our Implementation we are checking in dirPath(/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/Omniture-GRID/FileUpload/NetExport) if a har file is generated in the given path.  Needs a solution for this on early basis.  ## Expected Behavior - Har file should get generated in HUB path /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/Omniture-GRID/FileUpload/NetExport  ## Actual Behavior - Har is not getting generated

column3: Avoiding getting `'NoneType' object has no attribute 'path'` on selenium quit()?
column4: ## Meta - OS:  Cygwin 32 bits on Windows 7  Selenium Version:  3.0.2  Browser:  Firefox   Browser Version:     ## Expected Behavior - When running Selenium Webdriver Python script, one shouldn't get any exception related messages after executing self.driver.quit().   ## Actual Behavior - When running Selenium Webdriver Python script, one gets a 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'path' after executing self.driver.quit().   ## Steps to reproduce -  $ cat demo_NoneType_attribute_error.py # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- from selenium import webdriver import unittest  class TestPass(unittest.TestCase):     def setUp(self):         self.driver = webdriver.Firefox()      def test_pass(self):         pass      def tearDown(self):         print("doing: self.driver.quit()")         try:             self.driver.quit()         except AttributeError:             pass  if __name__ == "__main__":     unittest.main()  $ python demo_NoneType_attribute_error.py doing: self.driver.quit() 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'path' . ---------------------------------------------------------------------- Ran 1 test in 19.807s  OK  $   See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40998945/how-to-avoid-getting-nonetype-object-has-no-attribute-path-on-selenium-qui/41011364?noredirect=1#comment69390283_41011364 for problem description and possible **solution**.

column4: ## Meta - OS:  CentOS 7.2   Selenium Version:   3.0.1  Browser:  Firefox  50.0   Browser Version:   50.0   ## Expected Behavior - Test would run OK ## Actual Behavior - Sometimes test would fail with connection refused, it is clearly not test issue, it is possible about selenium or Firefox issue  ## Steps to reproduce -  Can not give a easy steps to reproduce, it can sometime happen. (maybe 3 in 10 times)   ``` request = > driver_class =  driver_kwargs = {'firefox_profile': }      @pytest.yield_fixture     def driver(request, driver_class, driver_kwargs):         """Returns a WebDriver instance based on options and capabilities""" >       driver = driver_class(**driver_kwargs)  /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pytest_selenium/pytest_selenium.py:107:  _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _  /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/firefox/webdriver.py:145: in __init__     keep_alive=True) /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py:92: in __init__     self.start_session(desired_capabilities, browser_profile) /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py:179: in start_session     response = self.execute(Command.NEW_SESSION, capabilities) /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py:236: in execute     self.error_handler.check_response(response) _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _   self =  response = {'status': 500, 'value': '{"error":"unknown error","message":"connection refused"}'}      def check_response(self, response):         """             Checks that a JSON response from the WebDriver does not have an error.                  :Args:              - response - The JSON response from the WebDriver server as a dictionary                object.                  :Raises: If the response contains an error message.             """         status = response.get('status', None)         if status is None or status == ErrorCode.SUCCESS:             return              value = None         message = response.get("message", "")         screen = response.get("screen", "")         stacktrace = None         if isinstance(status, int):             value_json = response.get('value', None)             if value_json and isinstance(value_json, basestring):                 import json                 try:                     value = json.loads(value_json)                     status = value.get('error', None)                     if status is None:                         status = value["status"]                         message = value["value"]                         if not isinstance(message, basestring):                             value = message                             try:                                 message = message['message']                             except TypeError:                                 message = None                     else:                         message = value.get('message', None)                 except ValueError:                     pass              exception_class = ErrorInResponseException         if status in ErrorCode.NO_SUCH_ELEMENT:             exception_class = NoSuchElementException         elif status in ErrorCode.NO_SUCH_FRAME:             exception_class = NoSuchFrameException         elif status in ErrorCode.NO_SUCH_WINDOW:             exception_class = NoSuchWindowException         elif status in ErrorCode.STALE_ELEMENT_REFERENCE:             exception_class = StaleElementReferenceException         elif status in ErrorCode.ELEMENT_NOT_VISIBLE:             exception_class = ElementNotVisibleException         elif status in ErrorCode.INVALID_ELEMENT_STATE:             exception_class = InvalidElementStateException         elif status in ErrorCode.INVALID_SELECTOR \                 or status in ErrorCode.INVALID_XPATH_SELECTOR \                 or status in ErrorCode.INVALID_XPATH_SELECTOR_RETURN_TYPER:             exception_class = InvalidSelectorException         elif status in ErrorCode.ELEMENT_IS_NOT_SELECTABLE:             exception_class = ElementNotSelectableException         elif status in ErrorCode.INVALID_COOKIE_DOMAIN:             exception_class = WebDriverException         elif status in ErrorCode.UNABLE_TO_SET_COOKIE:             exception_class = WebDriverException         elif status in ErrorCode.TIMEOUT:             exception_class = TimeoutException         elif status in ErrorCode.SCRIPT_TIMEOUT:             exception_class = TimeoutException         elif status in ErrorCode.UNKNOWN_ERROR:             exception_class = WebDriverException         elif status in ErrorCode.UNEXPECTED_ALERT_OPEN:             exception_class = UnexpectedAlertPresentException         elif status in ErrorCode.NO_ALERT_OPEN:             exception_class = NoAlertPresentException         elif status in ErrorCode.IME_NOT_AVAILABLE:             exception_class = ImeNotAvailableException         elif status in ErrorCode.IME_ENGINE_ACTIVATION_FAILED:             exception_class = ImeActivationFailedException         elif status in ErrorCode.MOVE_TARGET_OUT_OF_BOUNDS:             exception_class = MoveTargetOutOfBoundsException         else:             exception_class = WebDriverException         if value == '' or value is None:             value = response['value']         if isinstance(value, basestring):             if exception_class == ErrorInResponseException:                 raise exception_class(response, value)             raise exception_class(value)         if message == "" and 'message' in value:             message = value['message']              screen = None         if 'screen' in value:             screen = value['screen']              stacktrace = None         if 'stackTrace' in value and value['stackTrace']:             stacktrace = []             try:                 for frame in value['stackTrace']:                     line = self._value_or_default(frame, 'lineNumber', '')                     file = self._value_or_default(frame, 'fileName', '')                     if line:                         file = "%s:%s" % (file, line)                     meth = self._value_or_default(frame, 'methodName', '')                     if 'className' in frame:                         meth = "%s.%s" % (frame['className'], meth)                     msg = "    at %s (%s)"                     msg = msg % (meth, file)                     stacktrace.append(msg)             except TypeError:                 pass         if exception_class == ErrorInResponseException:             raise exception_class(response, message)         elif exception_class == UnexpectedAlertPresentException and 'alert' in value:             raise exception_class(message, screen, stacktrace, value['alert'].get('text')) >       raise exception_class(message, screen, stacktrace) E       WebDriverException: Message: connection refused  /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/errorhandler.py:192: WebDriverException  ```   **Note**  I think it was an old issue,  like in selenium 2.53.x  `WebDriverException: Message: The browser appears to have exited before we could connect. If you specified a log_file in the FirefoxBinary constructor, check it for details.`    Googled The  https://snakeycode.wordpress.com/2016/06/11/selenium-and-firefox-problems/ the link said selenium and Marionette could solve that issue. Right now, we did not see the `The browser appears to have exited` , However, we have a new issue above 'WebDriverException: Message: connection refused'

column3: FirefoxDriver is incorrectly treated as remote
column4: ## Meta - OS:  all Selenium Version: 3.3.0 Browser:  Firefox Browser Version: **all**  ## Expected Behavior -  `selenium.webdriver.Firefox` runs a _local_ instance of the browser, ergo the internal property `_is_remote` should be False.  In 3.3.0, it isn't, due to a logic error in the constructor: `_is_remote` is set to False at the very beginning, but the superclass constructor (which is `RemoteWebDriver`, as the remoting _protocol_ is used) is called at the very end, which clobbers the value to True.  This breaks any script that attempts to upload files.  I suspect this bug was introduced with support for GeckoDriver (and thus the need to dynamically switch between FirefoxRemoteConnection and ExtensionConnection).  ## Steps to reproduce -  ``` >>> from selenium.webdriver import Firefox >>> ff = Firefox() >>> ff._is_remote True >>> ff.get('data:text/html,') >>> el = ff.find_element_by_id("foo") >>> el.send_keys("/bin/ls") Traceback (most recent call last):   File "", line 1, in    File ".../site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webelement.py", line 345, in send_keys     value = self._upload(local_file)   File ".../site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webelement.py", line 548, in _upload     raise e selenium.common.exceptions.WebDriverException: Message: POST /session/59ac3c55-0ff1-4c1a-82b5-d08448db6caa/file did not match a known command ```

column3: Python: RemoteConnection with keepalive ignores HTTPS
column4: ## Meta - OS:  All Selenium Version:  3.0.2 Browser: Remote Browser Version: N/A  ## Expected Behavior - `RemoteConnection('https://foo.bar/', keep_alive=True)` sends all its commands over a secure HTTPS connection.  ## Actual Behavior - `RemoteConnection('https://foo.bar/', keep_alive=True)` sends all its commands over an insecure HTTP connection.  ## Steps to reproduce - Use `RemoteConnection('https://foo.bar/', keep_alive=True)` to connect to a secured selenium server.

"/", "\\" window_handle = RAutomation::Window.new(:title => /#{window}/i) window_handle.text_field(:class => field_input, :index => 0).set file  ```              ## Actual Behavior -  Above code works with Selenium and doesn't work with SeleniumGrid  ## Steps to reproduce -  1. column3: Portable Firefox - Selenium connection problem
column4: ## Meta - OS:   Windows 7  Selenium Version:   Selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1 Browser:   Portable Firefox Browser Version:   V 51.0.1   ## Expected Behavior -  Should open a webdriver connection and there to Google.com  ## Actual Behavior - Only Firefox profile page will open and "org.openqa.selenium.SessionNotCreatedException" exception  ## Steps to reproduce -   System.setProperty(GeckoDriverService.GECKO_DRIVER_EXE_PROPERTY," Path to \\geckodriver.exe");    DesiredCapabilities capabilities = DesiredCapabilities.firefox();  capabilities.setCapability("firefox_binary","path to FirefoxPortable.exe");  WebDriver driver = new FirefoxDriver(desiredCapabilities); driver.get("http://www.google.com");      Screenshot of actual output : ![firefoxerror](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5535949/22885602/167f518c-f220-11e6-97d8-10404bf4354d.jpg)    Exception in Eclipse:  Feb 13, 2017 6:01:43 PM org.openqa.selenium.remote.ProtocolHandshake createSession INFO: Attempting bi-dialect session, assuming Postel's Law holds true on the remote end Feb 13, 2017 6:22:50 PM org.openqa.selenium.remote.ProtocolHandshake createSession INFO: Falling back to original OSS JSON Wire Protocol. column3: Node config does not see driver executable after upgrade.(Windows only)
column4: ## Meta - OS:   Windows 7  Selenium Version:  3.0.1  Browser:  Internet explorer, chrome, firefox  ## Configs in Selenium -node  2.x.x- ``` {   "capabilities":       [         {           "browserName": "firefox",           "maxInstances": 8,           "version": "47",           "platform": "WINDOWS",           "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"         },         	{           "browserName": "chrome",           "maxInstances": 8,           "version": "51", 	  "platform": "WINDOWS",           "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"         },         {           "browserName": "internet explorer",           "version": "11",           "platform": "WINDOWS",           "maxInstances": 8,           "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"         }       ],   "configuration":   {	     "Dwebdriver.ie.driver=C://Selenium/Node/IEDriverServer32.exe": "",     "Dwebdriver.chrome.driver=C://Selenium/Node/chromedriver.exe":"",     "maxSession": 16,     "port": 5555,     "register": true,     "registerCycle": 5000,     "hubPort": 4444,     "hubHost": selenium.internal.company.com   } } ``` ## Modified Configs for Selenium -node 3.x.x- ``` {   "capabilities": [     {       "browserName": "firefox",       "maxInstances": 8,       "version": "49",       "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"     },     {       "browserName": "chrome",       "maxInstances": 8,       "version": "54",       "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"     },         {           "browserName": "internet explorer",           "version": "9",           "maxInstances": 8,           "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"         }   ],     "platform": "WINDOWS",     "Dwebdriver.ie.driver=C://Selenium/Node/IEDriverServer32.exe": "",     "Dwebdriver.chrome.driver=C://Selenium/Node/chromedriver.exe":"",     "Dwebdriver.gecko.driver=C://Selenium/Node/geckodriver.exe":"",     "maxSession": 16,     "port": 5555,     "register": true,     "registerCycle": 5000,     "hub": "http://selenium.internal.company.com:4444" } ``` ## Working configuration for Selenium - node (Linux node) ``` {   "capabilities": [     {       "browserName": "firefox",       "maxInstances": 8,       "version": "49",       "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"     },     {       "browserName": "chrome",       "maxInstances": 8,       "version": "54",       "seleniumProtocol": "WebDriver"     }   ],     "platform": "LINUX",     "Dwebdriver.firefox.bin=/opt/firefox/firefox-bin": "",     "Dwebdriver.chrome.driver=/opt/selenium/chromedriver": "",     "Dwebdriver.gecko.driver=/opt/selenium/geckodriver":"",     "maxSession": 8,     "port": 5555,     "register": true,     "registerCycle": 5000,     "hub": "http://selenium.internal.company.com:4444" }  ```  ## Steps to reproduce - - Start the node - Select any browser   And it trows an error ``` 10:06:49.786 WARN - Exception: The path to the driver executable must be set by the webdriver.gecko.driver system property; for more information, see https://gi thub.com/mozilla/geckodriver. The latest version can be downloaded from https:// github.com/mozilla/geckodriver/releases ```

column3: Potential bug with wait()
column4: ## Meta - OS:   MacOS Selenium Version:    Browser:  Firefox  Browser Version:  Latest version, tmk  ## Expected Behavior -  I am looking to upload a file to a Node.js server, using the following Node.js code:  ```js  before('upload file', {timeout: 30000}, h => {       driver.get(cdthost + '/#!/home');       let acq = acqs[0].companyName === 'DUMMY_ACQ' ? acqs[1] : acqs[0];       let acqId = acq._id;       driver.findElement(By.id(`open-editing-acqId-${acqId}`)).click();       let file = path.resolve($root + '/csv-data/IT-DE-Jasper.csv');       let el = driver.findElement(By.id(`import-file-acqId-${acqId}`));       driver.wait(until.elementIsVisible(el), 1000);       el.sendKeys(file);       driver.findElement(By.id(`submit-file-acqId-${acqId}`)).click();       return driver.wait(function () {         return Promise.delay(100);       }, 2000);   }); ```  What perplexes me is that when `driver.wait() `is called, the timeout will start running immediately. Instead of waiting for all the previous calls to resolve, it appears to start the timeout right away.   Does that make sense?  In other words,  ```js   driver.doSomething1() // takes 5 seconds   driver.doSomething2()  // takes 4 seconds   driver.doSomething3() // takes 5 seconds   return driver.wait(function(){         return Promise.delay(100);   }, 2000); ```  what seems to happen is that this will timeout because 2000 ms < is than 5+4+5 seconds.  Something is wrong, am I doing something wrong?  What I would expect is if y > x, then this will never timeout, am I right, or am I right?  ```js   return driver.wait(function(){         return Promise.delay(x);   }, y);  ```

column3: WebDriverException.getMessage() is sometimes very-very slooooooooooooow
column4: ## Meta - OS:   Any Selenium Version:   2.x, 3.0.0, 3.0.1 Browser:   Any  ## Expected Behavior - Method `WebDriverException.getMessage` must be fast! Always. It must not depend on system/network configuration.  ## Actual Behavior - Sometimes method `WebDriverException.getMessage` is very, very slow because it tries to resolve host name/IP and add this "system information" to the error message.  ## Steps to reproduce -  Given a machine with `/etc/hosts` file that **does not contain its hostname**. For example, my laptop currently has name: ```bash >hostname  Andreis-MacBook-Pro-3.local ```  But file `/etc/hosts` does not contain this name: ```bash >cat /etc/hosts 127.0.0.1	localhost Andreis-MacBook-Pro-2.local ```  In this case, method `WebDriverException.getMessage` is very-very slow because it tries to resolve current host name:  ```java "main@1" prio=5 tid=0x1 nid=NA runnable   java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE 	  at java.net.Inet6AddressImpl.lookupAllHostAddr(Inet6AddressImpl.java:-1) 	  at java.net.InetAddress$2.lookupAllHostAddr(InetAddress.java:928) 	  at java.net.InetAddress.getAddressesFromNameService(InetAddress.java:1323) 	  at java.net.InetAddress.getLocalHost(InetAddress.java:1500) 	  - locked <0xbf3> (a java.lang.Object) 	  at org.openqa.selenium.WebDriverException.getSystemInformation(WebDriverException.java:72) 	  at org.openqa.selenium.WebDriverException.createMessage(WebDriverException.java:63) 	  at org.openqa.selenium.WebDriverException.getMessage(WebDriverException.java:53) ```  I believe it's **not needed**. Selenium **should not** try to resolve host name.  Selenium **should not** add host name to the exception message. It's **not a Selenium job**.   It's responsibility of QA engineer who runs tests to configure proper logging and other infrastructure.   ## My proposal  I suggest to remove method `WebDriverException.getSystemInformation`, or at least remove host name resolving from it.

column3: Selenium Grid node does not honour chrome_binary setting
column4: ## Meta - OS:    Hub on Linux (suse 11.4) & nodes on windows (win2k8R2) Selenium Version:      Selenium 3.2.0 - GRID Browser:                     Chrome 53 & 56 (but the version is not important for this issue)  ## Expected Behavior - - 2 different chrome are installed on a node:       version 56 installed on the chrome default path       version 53 installed on a specific path (example: d:\softs\chrome\chrome.exe)   We should be able to run a test on a specific Chrome version, just by adding the version in the desiredCapabilities of the test case, whatever this chrome version binary is installed on the node. The only condition should be that the node configuration settings have a "chrome_binary" value defined, like firefox with the "firefox_binary" value.  This was working with Selenium 2.x after a fix: (cf: https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/commit/41a9d29bc3bb6f4d8d4ad25b291fadb99619a1c8)  Seems this not works anymore with Selenium 3.x.   ## Actual Behavior -  - 2 different chrome are installed on a node:       version 56 installed on the chrome default path       version 53 installed on a specific path (example: d:\softs\chrome\chrome.exe)  - with Selenium Grid 2.x, we can specify the chrome binary path in the node configuration, so the HUB can find the chrome binary when a test is specifying the chrome version in the RequiredCapabilities. (cf: https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/commit/41a9d29bc3bb6f4d8d4ad25b291fadb99619a1c8)  - with Selenium Grid 3.x, this don't work anymore.     => if the test specify only the version 53 in the desiredCapabilities, the HUB display the test running on the 53 version, but this is the binary installed in the default path which is used (aka v56).  FAILED     => if the test specify the version 53 and the correct specific chrome path, then the binary of v53 in the specific chrome path is used. PASSED     => if I remove the v56 of default path (so just v53 on specific path on the node), and the test only specify the v53 version, then the node fails with error "cannot find Chrome binary". FAILED.   So is it possible to find a way to have the HUB able to construct a correct chromeOptions with a "binary" value correct when the node configuration specify this for a specific browser version ? Or does this means that we can't, with Selenium 3.x, use different browser versions on the same node (so this is a limitation of the 3.x version versus the 2.x version which allow this) ?  Regards Olivier

column3: Selenium-RC documentation page displayed encoded format text if we navigate from Sel-IDE help content in http://www.seleniumhq.org/ website
column4: ## Meta - OS:   Windows8 , 64 bit   Browser:    Internet Explorer,  Firefox , Chrome  Browser Version:    IE11 , Forfox 50 , Chrome 55  ## Expected Behavior - Selenium-RC documentation text should displayed in English language   ## Actual Behavior - Selenium-RC documentation text displayed in encoded format  language  instead of English language   ## Steps to reproduce - 1. Navigate to http://www.seleniumhq.org/ 2. Click on Documentation tab 3.  click on "Executing Selenium-IDE Tests on Different Browsers" link under Selenium IDE section 4. Click on "Run Selenese tests"  Note  : Direct page navigation is working fine[ Documention -> Selenium RC ] http://www.seleniumhq.org/docs/05_selenium_rc.jsp    Selenium-RC documentation ![selenium-rc-documentation-page](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/24540827/21132622/d856dd80-c0c9-11e6-9bf2-c69e5cf5aafe.png)  text displayed in encoded format  language  instead of English language

For example:  self.driver.find_element_by_id("aa")  If there is no element called aa, then, the program will freeze until timeout condition is true

column3: Passwords not being sent
column4: ## Meta - OS:   Windows7 Selenium Version:   2.9.1 IDE Browser:   Firefox  Hi  Note that the issue i am having is related to a "unsupported" firefox version, but i dont think the problem is related to the version itself  I have a screen that contains two inputs for passwords with different names. password and code. I have automated the script filling both inputs and clicking on the submit button.  IDE script looks correct, with both passwords populated, and when running it, i can see that both passwords are filled in the screen, but, capturing the request, i can see that only the first password is sent   Browser Version:   50  ## Expected Behavior - When a screen contains two inputs with passwords, send both passwords in the request ## Actual Behavior - Only the first password is sent ## Steps to reproduce - 1 - Use a page that contains two password in the same screen 2 - Record the execution, populate both passwords and submit the request 3 - Play the script. Only the first of the two passwords is being sent

column3: Selenium 3.1.0 node incorrectly detects own ip address
column4: ## Meta - OS:   Windows, Linux Selenium Version:   3.1.0 Browser:   Chrome, Firefox, Edge  Browser Version:   any  ## Expected Behavior - When selenium node connects to hub, it registers itself with the ip address bound to the same interface that was used to make connection.  ## Actual Behavior - Selenium uses different ip address when host contains more than one network address. This results with selenium hub to time out when trying to connect back to node, workaround is to force using specific ip address by providing it as -host parameter  ## Steps to reproduce - 1. Start selenium hub in on host one in network, 2. On node host make sure there is more that one network interface available (eg. virtualbox host only interface) 3. Start node connection 4. Node is able to register in hub, but it is listed with ip address bound to other interface (that one from virtualbox interface)

column3: java.net.SocketTimeoutException encountered during IE driver execution using selenium WebDriver
column4: ## Meta - OS:   Windows Server 2008 R2 DataCenter Selenium Version:   3.3.1 Browser:   Internet Explorer  Browser Version:   IE 11.0.9600.18537  ## Expected Behavior - My test suite containing 117 test case should be executed without any crash of IEdriver. IEDriver version - 3.3.0  ## Actual Behavior - **Execution stops intermittently. Error log gives the following log. 2017-03-31 00:17:52,904 ERROR [Log] Error occured during IE browser execution: java.net.SocketTimeoutException: Read timed out Build info: version: 'unknown', revision: '5234b32', time: '2017-03-10 09:00:17 -0800' System info: host: 'VM-LW-ATAF1', ip: '10.10.70.156', os.name: 'Windows Server 2008 R2', os.arch: 'amd64', os.version: '6.1', java.version: '1.8.0_121' Driver info: driver.version: InternetExplorerDriver 2017-03-31 03:17:54,303 ERROR [Log] TestCaseID =PSC-2.6,TestStepID =TS107 | Not able to Close the Browser --- java.net.SocketTimeoutException: Read timed out Build info: version: 'unknown', revision: '5234b32', time: '2017-03-10 09:00:17 -0800' System info: host: 'VM-LW-ATAF1', ip: '10.10.70.156', os.name: 'Windows Server 2008 R2', os.arch: 'amd64', os.version: '6.1', java.version: '1.8.0_121' Driver info: driver.version: RemoteWebDriver**  As per input from various forums and github I have modified the registry values of both MaxUserPort (Maximum value) and TCPTimedWaitDelay(30 seconds) ## Steps to reproduce - There is no specific steps to reproduce. You need to execute the test suite for hours. Once I found the issue after 3 hours and 2 mts. This time may vary.

column3: Firefox profiles with RemoteWebDriver
column4: ## Meta - OS:   Windows Server 2-12 R2  Selenium Version:   3.0.1  Browser:   Firefox 47.0.1   Browser Version:   47.0.1  ## Expected Behavior - When running tests from .Net client all is well, tests run as expected.  Once tests are completed, the firefox profiles generated on the target Grid nodes in temp directories should be deleted.  ## Actual Behavior - The firefox profiles generated in C:\users\\AppData\Local\Temp\ with name anonymouswebdriver-profile are not deleted once the tests complete.  Each one of these dir are ~4 MB which very quickly adds up to considerable space.  When running under 2.53.1 this did not occur, is this a reoccurrence of an earlier bug?

column3: Actions KeyDown/KeyUp not supporting all modifier keys
column4: ## Meta - OS:   Windows 7/8/10 Selenium Version:   DotNet Webdriver 3.3.0.0 Browser:   Safari Browser Version:   10  ## Expected Behavior - I can use any modifier key in "Actions" methods like "KeyDown/KeyUp" ## Actual Behavior - Only Keys.Shift, Keys.Control, Keys.Alt are supported (See SingleKeyAction.cs) ## Steps to reproduce - new Actions(Driver).KeyDown(Keys.Command).Perform();  The Java WebDriver implementation has this fixed in "SingleKeyAction.java" since march 2014. See: https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/commit/9b57e72b4a75349b0c52b9010be79c2fa68bebee#diff-b99bb200e128addef65be0b35a8c8612
