ode_modules\selenium-webdriver\lib\webdriver.js:1027:25)     at Driver.get (C:\Users\joshua.grant
ode_modules\selenium-webdriver\lib\webdriver.js:795:28)     at Object. (C:\Users\joshua.grant\google_search.js:10:8)     at Module._compile (module.js:409:26)     at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:416:10)     at Module.load (module.js:343:32)     at Function.Module._load (module.js:300:12)     at Function.Module.runMain (module.js:441:10)     at startup (node.js:139:18) ```  Changing the browser type from `firefox` to `chrome` ran without issues (with a ChromeDriver properly installed in my machine). It appears this is an issue with the WebDriverJS not locating the Firefox EXE path on Win 10 by default.

column3: Click() does not return any response on Safari 10.0.1, selenium 3.0.1
column4: ## Description The click method does not return any response on the Safari 10.0.1, Python Selenium 3.0.1 on OS X El Capitan.   ## Meta OS:  OSX El Capitan 10.11.6 (15G1108) Selenium Version:  3.0.1 (installed from https://pypi.python.org/pypi/selenium) Browser: Safari Browser Version:  10.0.1 (11602.2.14.0.7) (64 bit)  ## Expected Behavior The button is clicked.  ## Actual Behavior No response is returned. No error message is returned  ## Steps to reproduce 1. Initiate the Safari WebDriver 2. Find an element by ID 3. Execute the click() function  ## Python script ``` from selenium import webdriver  driver = webdriver.Safari() driver.get('http://localhost:8000') element = driver.find_element_by_id("submit") element.click() ```

column3: Ruby bindings start Chromedriver with logging enabled by default
column4: ## Actual Behavior  Currently Ruby bindings by default start Chromedriver with logging enabled. With logging enabled Chromedriver memory  usage grows significantly as it runs. I reported this issue to Chromedriver [here](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromedriver/issues/detail?id=1425) but they didn't fix it.  They said: `I would suggest you to file a bug with selenium webdriver for ruby bindings. Ruby library should be changed so that it does not enable logs by default.` ## Expected Behavior  Two possible fixes: - Ruby bindings don't start Chromedriver with logging enabled by default - Chromedriver fixes an issue with memory growth if logging is enabled ## Steps to reproduce  Run the following script:  ``` ruby require 'selenium-webdriver' driver = Selenium::WebDriver.for :chrome 10000.times do |i|   driver.navigate.to "about:blank" end ```  [By the end of this "chromedriver.exe" will have ~200 MB taken](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromedriver/issues/attachment?aid=241600&inline=1)

column3: Exception: Firefox option was set, but is not a FirefoxOption:
column4: # Setup  OS: Centos 7 Selenium version: 3.0.1 Bindings: Python using remote driver Browser: Firefox 49.0.2 Driver: geckodriver v0.11.1  # Description When setting the binary or profile in the webdriver.firefox.options.Options(), once the option is passed along it's rejected with   ``` Driver info: driver.version: FirefoxDriver         at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver.populateProfile(FirefoxDriver.java:205)         at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver.extractProfile(FirefoxDriver.java:168)         at org.openqa.selenium.firefox.FirefoxDriver.(FirefoxDriver.java:135)         ... 14 more 14:51:51.354 WARN - Exception: Firefox option was set, but is not a FirefoxOption: {binary=/usr/bin/firefox, } ```  code   ``` 		dcap = DesiredCapabilities.FIREFOX.copy()  		dcap["marionette"] = True  		fpoptions = webdriver.firefox.options.Options() 		fpoptions.binary = webdriver.firefox.firefox_binary.FirefoxBinary()  		fpoptions.binary._start_cmd = "/usr/bin/firefox"  		  		fp = webdriver.FirefoxProfile() 		fp.set_preference("browser.cache.disk.enable",False) 		fp.set_preference("browser.privatebrowsing.autostart", True) 		fp.update_preferences() 		fpoptions.profile = fp 		dcap.update(fpoptions.to_capabilities())                  browser = webdriver.Remote(command_executor="http://127.0.0.1:4444/wd/hub",proxy=proxy,desired_capabilities=dcap) ```

column3: Can't get the screenshot of the current element
column4: # Meta -  OS:  Windows 10    Selenium Version:  2.53.6    Browser:  Chrome    Browser Version:  53.0.2785.116 m (64-bit)   ## Expected Behavior -  Gets the screenshot of the current element as a binary data. ## Actual Behavior -  It raise WebDriverException  ``` python Traceback (most recent call last):   File "C:\python2.7\lib\site-packages\IPython\core\interactiveshell.py", line 2885, in run_code     exec(code_obj, self.user_global_ns, self.user_ns)   File "", line 1, in      element.screenshot_as_png   File "C:\python2.7\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\webelement.py", line 400, in screenshot_as_png     return base64.b64decode(self.screenshot_as_base64.encode('ascii'))   File "C:\python2.7\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\webelement.py", line 390, in screenshot_as_base64     return self._execute(Command.ELEMENT_SCREENSHOT)['value']   File "C:\python2.7\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\webelement.py", line 461, in _execute     return self._parent.execute(command, params)   File "C:\python2.7\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\webdriver.py", line 236, in execute     self.error_handler.check_response(response)   File "C:\python2.7\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\errorhandler.py", line 163, in check_response     raise exception_class(value) WebDriverException: Message: unknown command: session/b29be55e0ac21893f180da11ac203787/screenshot/0.20772185933294707-1 ``` ## Steps to reproduce -    with python2.7  ``` python from selenium import webdriver driver= webdriver.Chrome() driver.get("http://www.google.com") element = driver.find_element_by_id('lst-ib') print element.screenshot_as_png ```

column3: Exception: connection refused (--marionette)
column4: # Meta Selenium Version: 3.0.2 Geckodriver: 0.13.0 Python : 2.7 Centos : release 6.8 # My script ``` from selenium import webdriver from selenium.webdriver.firefox.firefox_binary import FirefoxBinary binary = FirefoxBinary('/pwd/geckodriver') browser = webdriver.Firefox(firefox_binary=binary) browser.get('http://seleniumhq.org/') print(browser.title) ``` When I execute my script, Selenium throws an exception (see below). - selenium.common.exceptions.WebDriverException: Message: connection refused - Geckodriver log :     error: Found argument '--marionette' which wasn't expected, or isn't valid in this context         Did you mean --marionette-port?   USAGE:     geckodriver --marionette-port    For more information try --help

column3: Cooke import error when using phantomjs
column4: # Meta  OS: MacOS Sierra Selenium Version: 3.0.1 Browser: Phantomjs version 2.1.1 Languague: Python 2.7  # Expected Behavior  I should be able to import cookies exported from the driver without having to reformat them.  # Actual Behavior  If I dont make sure the `domain` of the cookie starts with a `.` i get the following error: `WebDriverException: Message: {"errorMessage":"Unable to set Cookie", ...` I only get this error when using phantomjs, chrome driver works perfectly.  # Steps to reproduce ```     for cookie in driver.get_cookies():             driver.add_cookie(cookie) ```  # Hacky Solution ```     for cookie in driver.get_cookies():                 # phantomjs cookies need to be prepended by a '.' for some strange reason                 if cookie['domain'][0] != '.':                     cookie['domain'] = '.' + cookie['domain']                 driver.add_cookie(cookie) ```
